Dear Mr. Orr:

We duly note contents of your letter of July 30th, relative to the proposal to deduct cost of certain alterations from the balance due us and also paragraph in your letter of July 26th relative to water tanks.

We unhesitatingly affirm that these tanks are properly designed pneumatic tanks and that the connections are not an unreasonable distance from the bottom.

To support the above statement, we enclose blue prints showing how the tanks were made. It is true that the outlets are not at the actual bottom. This was done by the Vulcan Iron Works who made them, to allow for settlement of sediment as it has been found that nearly all water storage systems collect sediments. It was only during the past winter that we had experience in moving a similar tank which had collected in only two years use, over six inches of solid matter in the bottom. This was a tank manufactured by the Vulcan Iron Works.

Where the outlet is put in the bottom of the tank, the gauge glass is placed to allow for the water line to be about the center of the tank as shown by yellow pencil on blue print submitted. In order to offset loss of storage by placing the outlet at the bottom, you will notice the couplings for water gauge are set near the top to allow for a much higher water line, and by this method owing to the water contents being increased at the center of the tank, the amount of storage is greater than if the water line kept to the center and the outlet at the bottom.
If such a simple matter as changing the outlet would make the system work, it would not be necessary to substitute low down tanks for flushometers and we contend this feature was the controlling factor and not the position of the outlets. Another disadvantage under which the system is, or was working, is that there were no means of keeping up the air contents, and unless this is done, the amount of aeration will ultimately use up the air cushion. It is quite possible that owing to a low down tank being used, less water is wasted and the using up of the small reserve at the bottom, with this feature added, will lessen the number of times pump has to be in operation; and excepting for this difference, the system is working no better now than when we left it, though it should still have and we always maintained this was necessary, some means to increase the amount of air in the tanks.

We do not think it is fair to us, for the Department to make an arbitrary assumption that we are to blame and to deduct money from us without first giving us an opportunity of stating our case. It appears to us somewhat as a "try it on the dog" policy, which would hardly be expected from the Department of Indian Affairs.

We trust however, from explanations offered herein, that you will agree with us that our design for the tanks is on the whole, reasonably correct, and not the cause of the trouble, and therefore, that no deduction will be made from the balance due, but that same will duly be forwarded to us intact.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

President.

The Secretary;
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Sometime last Spring Rev. T. Ferrier informed me that there was an appropriation of some $11,000.00 in the estimates for this school to be applied on plant, the money to be used in erecting farm buildings. I may say that we are badly in need of accommodation for our hogs. So far we have done our best to put up pens out of odd pieces of lumber and any old buildings which could be converted to this purpose. At present with the winter coming on it is necessary to do something. We have about 125 hogs with more coming on. As the Department will realize hogs form a very profitable industry on a farm such as this where we are trying to be self-supporting. I would be glad of some information in regard to the plans of the Department in this respect. It will be necessary to do something for our hogs if we are to continue in this branch of farm work with profit. We would be glad to submit to the Department a sketch of the buildings we require.

Yours Truly;

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, August 27, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the advisability of erecting a hogpen at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, is being asked for a recommendation in this connection and you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 27, 1924.

Sir:

The Rev. Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School reports that a hogpen is urgently required. I should be pleased if you would make a recommendation in this connection and, if you are in favour of such a building, indicate how the work can best be undertaken.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing you a pencil sketch of what will be suitable for a hog pen at Edmonton. The dimensions are 56' x 22'. In addition to this they need about a half dozen outside brooding pens which will cost about $125.00 each. The management will undertake to construct these buildings under the supervision of the principal by day labor, the department furnishing the material and probably one experienced carpenter.

We are very anxious to have this building under way at the earliest possible date. I trust the department will be able to consider this proposition favorably.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Rev. T. Ferrier
Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools and Hospitals in Canada
Ottawa, September 2, 1924.

I wish to refer to my letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the request for a hogpen at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Dear Sir;

I think that I should inform you that the roof of this building is leaking very badly during rainy seasons. Whenever it rains heavily the water comes through in a regular little stream, particularly at the steeple. This is of course because of faulty construction and no doubt is due to carelessness on the part of the builders. In order that this be remedied and thus save floors and ceilings from damage I would recommend that this be seen to. It is chiefly at the steeple, but other places also leak.

Yours Truly,

J. F. Woodsworth
Principal.
Ottawa, Sept. 11, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the leaks in the roof of the Edmonton School, I beg to say that I have notified the contractors to give this matter their immediate attention.

Sir:-

I have your letter of the 27th of August, informing me that the Rev. Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School reports that a hogpen is urgently required.

I cannot believe that it is so urgent that it cannot wait until I have an opportunity of visiting the Edmonton Agency. We have got along so far with a temporary pigsty and I think the matter should be held in abeyance until I visit the school, when I will decide what is required.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I am enclosing you my son's account in triplicate for $50, being the balance of the $250 agreed upon as mentioned in your letter of October 25th, 1921.

Mr. Charles May, building superintendent for the Department at Ottawa, in connection with the erection of the Industrial School for Indians, called on behalf of the Department accompanied by the contractor and had the plans revised in order to economize considerably on construction. This revision was approved and adopted by the Department. The plant is in good working order and giving the utmost satisfaction.

I should be glad, therefore, if you would forward my son's account, for the balance, to the Department for its attention.

With kindest regards, I am,

Yours very truly,

In response to your communication of the 11th inst., we will investigate the alleged defects in the roof.

November 14th 1924.

The Secretary;
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

When the farmer's residence was built there was installed in it the old furnace which was taken out of the old house. This is a very small furnace and quite unsuited for heating the house. We did the best we could under the circumstances to save getting a new furnace at the time but it has proved inadequate. I can buy a new furnace for $103.00 which would be entirely satisfactory. I think it would also be possible to sell the old furnace to a neighbor for $30.00 or so. If possible I would like permission to install a new furnace in this house.

Yours Truly;

J. F. Woodsworth
Principal.
Ottawa, Nov. 19, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and installation in the farmer's residence at the Edmonton Residential School of the furnace which you state you can obtain at a cost of $103. We note that this furnace will be satisfactory and that you can obtain the same at the above mentioned cost, which amount should not be exceeded. You may arrange for the installation of the new furnace, the labour for which should be performed without cost to the Department.

When forwarding accounts for the new furnace, which should be in duplicate and properly certified, you should show thereon the deduction of the amount received from the sale of the old furnace.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

November Nineteenth
Nineteen-Twenty-four.

Dear Mr. Orr:

We have now completed alterations to the tower at the above building and believe now there will be no further trouble with water. As the work we have done is quite out of the contract and beyond any obligations imposed on us as contractors, we think we should be paid for it. Mr. Gardner Smith is in agreement with us that the same work was necessary at Gardston and it has been done as an extra to contract. We are awaiting a small charge from Mr. Woodsworth for some lumber he supplied to our men and as soon as we receive this, we will forward the account, and trust it may receive your approval and be duly paid.

May we now ask that the long delayed final payment of $1000.00 be forwarded to us. We would very much like to have this cleaned up before the end of this year and trust your kind assistance may enable this to be done.

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED

December 12th 1924.

The Secretary:
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

My engineer has drawn my attention to the fact that our high pressure boiler has not been inspected. This is the boiler that is used to operate the laundry. He has taken this matter up with the chief boiler inspector but this officer does not feel free to act as he is a provincial inspector and this is a Dominion Government institution.

As this inspection involves some expense I would be glad for authority to have our boiler inspected. This is necessary for our work as well as for safety.

Yours Truly;

J. P. Woodsworth,
Principal.
Ottawa, December 18, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the inspection of the high pressure boiler at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. In reply I have to say that you may arrange with the provincial inspector to make periodical inspections of both boilers at the school. These boilers should be inspected once each year. You should forward properly certified accounts covering the fees charged by the provincial inspector in this connection, together with a copy of the inspector's report on the condition of the boilers. Please arrange for an early inspection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

The Secretary;

Dear Sir;

Re. your circular letter of September 5th 1924 in reference to sewage disposal systems.

I may say that we have frequently examined the system including the manholes and the outlets. The system seems to be working fairly well.

The only item in connection with the septic tank which may require some attention in the near future is the condition of the gravel in the large chamber, just before the sewage leaves the tank. The water does not appear to filtering through as it should and is now largely running over the manhole at the top. This is a matter with which we can do little until the summer time when gravel should be changed. The trouble seems to be that the gravel and sand put into the septic tank was too fine and has become clogged. Next summer when the water running through is small in quantity, a carload of new gravel might remedy this difficulty. However at present the situation is not particularly serious.

Yours Truly;

J. F. Woodsworth.
Principal.
Ottawa, Jan. 9, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo advising me of the present condition of the sewage disposal system of the Indian Residential School at Edmonton, Alta.

As suggested in your communication you may arrange when convenient for the charging of the gravel filter bed in the tank, which you state is not of the dimensions required to insure the proper operation of this system.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLennan

Pursuant to our conversation with reference to a stock barn at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, I have to authorize you to expend $4,500.00 this fiscal year in the purchase of materials. I beg to inform you that Mr. Commissioner Graham has been authorized to purchase from the appropriations for the present fiscal year the materials considered necessary for the erection of a stock barn at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Arrangements will be made for the necessary funds in next year's appropriations to be available in April, next, to cover the cost of the labour.

Rev. J. F. Woodsworth,
Indian Residential School,
EDMONTON, Alta.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith certificates Nos. 32031-32-33 covering inspection of one high pressure vertical boiler and two 1000 firebox heating boilers at the Indian Residential School, Edmonton.

Will you please see that these certificates are given to the engineer so that he can have them posted up in the boiler room.

I have to report that all three boilers, together with their fittings, are in good condition, the steam gauges are correct and the safety valves accurately set.

The only additional fitting required is a protector over the water gauge glass of the high pressure boiler. This is a measure of prevention against accident to anyone close to the boiler in the event of the glass breaking under pressure.

The way in which the boilers perform under steam shows that the water from the present well is not very satisfactory, and if it were possible to have a reservoir constructed to collect rain water from the roof of the building this would be a considerable advantage. Water from wells in that district has in several instances been found quite unsuitable for boilers, and has been the cause of "pitting" taking place, and the risk of that would be obviated by the use of rain water.

I am enclosing account in triplicate for the sum of $22.50, this being the amount of inspection fees payable to the Department of Public Works.

Your obedient servant,

J. F. Cargill
Inspector of Boilers.

Dear Sir;

Herewith please find enclosed Voucher No. 2II in favor of Department of Public Works of Alberta for $22.50.

For your information I also enclosed letter of Inspector with his recommendations. I consider the one connected with the water supply very important. We have had to melt snow all winter for the high pressure boiler.

Ottawa, January 22, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing Voucher No. 212, in favour of the Revillon Wholesale, Limited, for $161.86. I am returning two of their itemized accounts, which total $20.61 and are apparently for window glass. The Department expects Indian residential schools to make replacements of this kind, except in the case of hail or catastrophe, and meet the expense from per capita earnings. A cheque for $141.25, in favour of the Revillon Wholesale, Limited, will be directed to you under separate cover. I have also noted that an account for postage was paid by the Department a few weeks ago. Please do not forward any more vouchers in this connection, as the Department has discontinued the practice of paying vouchers for stamps used at Indian residential schools.

Now that the Edmonton Indian Residential School is in operation, I have to request that you will conform to the practice at other Indian residential schools in the matter of drugs used in the dispensary for Indian children. Every quarter, you may requisition to the Department for the medicines and drugs that will be required. The requisitions should be in triplicate and should be certified by the medical officer of the school. The Department will arrange for competitive prices and will award the business. If you have to make small purchases of drugs from time to time, the accounts should be met from per capita earnings. If a large quantity of drugs is required, in the case of an epidemic or other emergency, the Department's authority for immediate local purchase should be secured.

The Department will favourably consider accounts, which should be submitted quarterly, in connection with the maintenance of the plant at the institution. Emergency purchases of lumber and hardware, which are necessary to the upkeep of the Department's property, should be made to good advantage from Revillon Wholesale,

Rev. J. F. Woodworth,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alta.

- Marshall Wells -
Marshall Wells, or any other firms that will give satisfaction. The business should be distributed - each firm getting the business for a quarter or for six months in turn. The account, in duplicate, should be recapitulated by the firm given the business, but should be in sufficient detail so that it will show the type of goods that have been purchased. It should be properly certified by yourself and submitted, under cover of a supporting letter, to the Department for payment. A cheque will then be issued and directed to the firm in question. The foregoing refers to small emergency purchases in connection with plant. When you have requested and received authority to make purchases of a larger nature, competitive prices should be secured, and when you are submitting the certified account in duplicate, in favour of the firm awarded the business in each case, you should support it with a statement showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

When submitting accounts which are to be paid by the Department, please be guided also by Circular Letter of the 12th instant. Your compliance with these requirements is requested by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
Sir:

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Edmonton School, in which he informs me that he has been granted authority by the Department to erect a barn at the Edmonton School.

I am also in receipt of a plan from Mr. Woodsworth showing the class of building he desires, and I quite agree to the plan.

We have the most elaborate barn in Western Canada at the Edmonton School now, and the Department had very little to say in its erection. I do not propose spending any more money at this point than is absolutely necessary. We will give them a good barn to accommodate the number of cattle that should be kept at the school, but there will be nothing fancy. We have built good barns for St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, and it was along the lines of these barns that I had proposed building the one at Edmonton.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, February 10, 1925.

Sir:

I have your No. 403-11A of the 4th instant, with reference to a cow barn at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. The Rev. I note that you agree with the sketch submitted by the Rev. Principal and that you will proceed with the activity which was authorized in the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of this file number of the 15th ultimo.

Ottawa, Ontario,
February 12, 1925.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have your letter of the 14th instant with regard to the construction of the cattle barn for the Edmonton School, and agree with you that it is unnecessary to have running water pass in the front of the cattle stalls, and litter carriers to carry away the manure at these Indian schools.

The boys could surely do the necessary work around the barns to take care of the stock without all this modern equipment.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Commissioner of Indian Affairs,
REGINA.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., February 14, 1925.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant with regard to the proposed barn at the Edmonton School.

In looking over my letter to you of the 4th instant, I find there is an omission of a word. What I wish to say is that I do not quite agree with the plan submitted. It is altogether too large, in my opinion. I am seeing Mr. Woodsworth at Calgary on Monday, and I will discuss this matter with him and arrange to have the necessary material paid for out of this year's appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Woodsworth:

We billed the Department with the cost of making alterations to the louvres of the tower to keep out snow and rain, which owing to the peculiar situation near to an inclined roof, caused wind to blow snow and rain upwards into the louvres. The Department have written us, in order to establish the fact that the work was done, they would like to have our accounts forwarded to them through you.

We are therefore, sending you our account in duplicate and would be glad if you will kindly check them up so far as you are able, with a special reference to the fact that material was delivered, that mechanics were employed and that the work was done as we have outlined, and forward them to Ottawa.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd inst., I do not think that any trouble you have heating the building is due to radiation. The amount of radiation to each room was specified by Mr. Orr and if the Stansfield Plumbing and Heating Co. put it in as shown on his plan, I think there will be no question of the capacity of the plant for the work. You are no doubt aware that our building is on a very exposed location and has no protection whatever, from the very cold winds. In addition to this, more than the usual number of windows are hung to give ventilation in the summer, that with the slight unavoidable shrinkage due to winter heat, more cold air passes through the windows under wind pressure than the radiators can readily overcome.
If the windows were fitted tight enough to overcome this, it would be impossible to operate them in the summer time as the air being moister than causes a certain amount of swelling. It is our opinion that windows in a building so exposed should have metal weatherstripping which we believe will more than pay its cost in fuel and I think the Department has this under consideration.

Regarding the moisture on the walls, I am sure that the trouble you have mentioned is due to conditions outlined in our previous letter.

The gutter of the School we are now building at Kamloops has been re-designed, to avoid this troublesome feature. You may not be troubled the same way each year, but so long as climatic conditions are such that the gutters fill and freeze, they will have to be repaired each spring.

If there are any other matters we can advise you on, we will be very glad to do so on hearing from you.

Yours very truly,

With further reference to my memorandum of the 5th instant regarding the recent fire at the Edmonton Residential School, I received yesterday a telegram from Mr. Graham advising that the lighting plant at the school was completely ruined, and that it would cost as much to rebuild as to install a new plant. He recommended the installation of a two unit three and six K.W. Lister equipment at a cost of $4,000 installed. I then wired Mr. Graham advising him that the cost of the 8 K.W. The laundry was last visited by a member of the staff at 10:45, who reports that she found everything in good order, and that there was no fire in the store nor had been for six hours previous.

I am leaving for Hobbema in a few minutes and perhaps will go from there to Onion Lake before returning to Regina. I will report to you further how the work is progressing when I return.

I arrived here on Wednesday morning and went out to the School at once. I found that the Laundry and Engine Room were completely gone, nothing but the walls standing, and most of these will have to be taken down as they are badly burnt. I made a thorough examination of the Laundry equipment and Engines and am thoroughly convinced that nearly everything will have to be replaced. Fortunately, I met C.A. Lister, President of the Lister Lighting Company here - in fact he waited here over a day to meet me. He had with him an expert on machinery and they convinced me beyond doubt that the plant was a complete loss, and that it would take more to rebuild it and put it in shape than it would buy a new one at the cost at which he was prepared to supply the Department with one. I wired you submitting the price which was $4,000. This is, therefore, $1,000 less than it would cost the Department had they been buying through the regular channels. Of course this means installed so that the Department would be put to no additional cost for this work. The proposed machine is to be a two unit one, three and six K.W.

As for the laundry machinery: It is just possible that the Flatwork Ironer can be rebuilt, but this remains to be seen. I am having an expert look over this machine and anything else that might be worth while fixing. Of one thing I am sure, and that is that the Washers are completely gone and I have taken it upon myself to order one of the same make that was destroyed, and have succeeded in borrowing a small engine which will operate this machine as soon as it arrives from Toronto, which should be in the course of ten days.

As for lighting, the Lister Company have loaned me a small engine that they had here, and I intend having this put up in the furnace room by tonight and we will then have lights on in the building.

I brought from Regina with me Henry George, whom we have had in our employ all last summer, and he is now at work with four men, and I expect in about two weeks' time we will have the building covered in and perhaps in three weeks' time completed. I may say for your information that the building can be considered a complete loss from the ground up, and it would be easier to put up a new building than to take down and rebuild, which we are forced to do.

In regard to the cause of the fire I am completely at a loss to account for it. There is a little laundry stove in the laundry. This was allowed to die down about eleven o'clock in the morning. When I visited the Edmonton School a short time ago, the Principal complained to me about the windows, claiming that the frames were very badly put in and were not filled in up to the brick; that you could feel the draft blowing in under the sills three to four feet away. I looked into the matter myself and I found such to be the case. There was a space of an inch between the tile and the frame of the sash and the brick also.

My own opinion is that it will end in all the sash having to be taken out before a good job can be made. I do not know that the specifications called for this filling in, but even if they did not it was the duty of the Building Inspector to see that it was done if he knew his business. My opinion is that he did not know his business at all, and the Department cannot expect to get much for $6.00 a day when we are paying ordinary carpenters $8.00. It seems to me that on important jobs of this kind we cannot be too particular in getting number one men to supervise the work. I have recommended a man as Inspector for the Onion Lake School, but this particular man happens to be unfitted for heavy work; however, we cannot always get this class of man as Inspector.

There is another matter I wish to bring to your attention, and that is the inadequate water supply for fire protection at the Edmonton School, and it seems to me that we should sink another well at this institution and put in a force pump halfway between the school and the stable. This could connect with the line that leads between the present pumphouse and the school, so that in the event of one well giving out the other could be brought into action. The second well could also look after the requirements of the school. I consider this a very important matter. With three or four hundred children in a place of this kind we cannot be too careful.

Dear Sir,

The fire at the Edmonton School revealed the condition of the outside frames of the windows and doors.

The window frames have not been properly plastered or pointed up. The frames themselves are set back from the brick veneer. In some cases the brick moulding does not even cover the entire space. The result is the air freely enters around the brick moulding and circulates freely behind the bricks. Thus the space between the brick veneer and the hollow tile, instead of being a dead air space, causes air to circulate freely around the entire building, except where the bricks may be close to the walls. Consequently the air enters the building in strong drafts around every outside window and door.

This must be remedied before we attempt to heat the building another winter. It can be done by removing the brick moulding and the inside casing from all outside windows and doors and properly plastering and pointing up the space. Why this was not done by the contractor and executed by the inspector when constructed is beyond my comprehension.

From the experience the management had in the new Cocual-sleetza School at Sardis, during the severe weather last winter, I feel sure that this same condition prevails in all the outside windows and doors and the same remedy must be applied to this building before the coming winter.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

Re INDIAN SCHOOL, EDENSTON, Ref. 110-0-5.

Following our letter of July 9th, 1925, we now submit our final conclusion on matters referred to in your communication of July 6th and to Mr. Maclean's letter of March 16th, 1925.

As previously reported, we have had a thorough investigation made respecting the complaints made by the Principal, which we find are based on three general items:

1. Draught through and around outside doors and windows.
2. Leak in roof due to broken slates.
3. Moisture in walls, presumably from gutters.

Mr. Woolsworth's report is not very flattering to us as contractors. We do not think, however, that anyone with a knowledge of the building industry would substantiate his reflection of blame against us. We will deal with the items in the order they are named above:

1. It may be true there may be considerable leakage of air between sash and frame, and some between frames and brickwork. As stated before, it is impossible to provide against such things unless special provisions are made, which result in additional cost. Sash must be made loose enough to work without friction. The Edmonton building was so fitted. It is impossible to leave sash and doors in such a condition that no adjustment is necessary. The work was finished in the Fall, the dampest time of the year, and it is to be expected that both sash and frames have by this time settled into a condition of permanence. A general tightening up of
the window stops will do much to lessen the amount of draught. We would suggest, however, if more than this is required, it will be necessary to fit weather-stripping to the windows. This is the established practice of the Winnipeg School Board. All their buildings are weather-stripped, as it is realised that on windows not so treated leakage of air cannot be prevented.

With regard to air finding its way around frames, this is a feature that can scarcely be termed bad or even faulty construction. A certain amount of shrinkage is absolutely unavoidable, and, in addition to this, the construction of the walls, namely, a veneer of brick on hollow tile, makes it harder to provide a draught-proof connection without going to greater cost than is called for by contract.

Where more preventative measures are required, they are specified generally under one of the following heads:

The removal of brick-moulds and pointing by:
(a) Ordinary mortar,
(b) Takum packing, covered by mortar,
(c) Sealing of apertures between frame and brickwork by Elastigum or other plastic substance.

All of these provisions cost money; nothing of the kind is asked for in our Specifications. We left a standard piece of work fully complying with the Contract. The fact that more is required to suit the Principal does not justify him in attributing his trouble to "bad construction," etc. We are sure you will understand that competition in the building trade in Western Canada leaves no margin whatever for performance of work not specified, however much it is otherwise desirable that it be furnished.

We should be pleased to weather-strip all the windows and outside doors on the building for the sum of £1,973, and if it is desired to remove brickmoulds and point spaces behind them, to do this on a cost-plus basis.

2: The roof leaks are due to slates broken by hail or frost. All of them are due to breakages in valleys or where two surfaces meet at opposed planes. This may be caused in several ways:

(a) Snow on roof melting in sunlight, and freezing after sun's rays have disappeared, and so repeating daily until an accumulation of ice is formed under edges of slates, and at edge of each surface.

(b) Action of frost.

(c) Hail.

We find the asbestos slates or shingles are extremely brittle in very cold weather, and like natural slate gives trouble under similar conditions. We followed makers' instructions implicitly. From twenty years' experience and actual observation
in building work in the West, we find that wherever slate is used there is trouble from winter breakage from one source or another. There is no doubt that asbestos slates as used at Edmonton are in same category; in fact, we think they are not as efficient as slates under our climatic conditions. We could quote many Western authorities in support of statement that asbestos or slate shingles are not proof against damage by winter. This refers to valleys and such places where different planes meet in such a way as to hold snow and ice.

(3): The moisture on walls appears to be due to a frost-burst gutter through ice formation, or to ice blocking conductor pipe. It is not attributable to any departure or omission of work that is required by contract.

From the foregoing, we submit that matters complained of by the Principal are due to causes outside of our responsibility under contract. We feel convinced a fair appraisal of the situation by the Department will confirm our statements.

In September or August, 1924, we did some work on the Tower for the Department, and at that time we had our men go over the roof and take care of any small items they could find which needed attention.

May we ask that balance outstanding and due us on this Contract be paid? It is two years since building was taken over, and we should appreciate having final payment, which is really needed by us at the present time.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have a number of requests to make of the Department.

1st- Artemus Wood, pupil No. 38 was taken with very sore eyes by Dr. Holmes the Medical Officer considered it advisable that he be taken to the hospital for a few days for treatment, as the case required constant treatment. I trust my action is acceptable to the Department.

2nd- For some time we have had difficulty with our water supply. The stream from the well was very slow and small. It was necessary to pump several hours a day in order to meet our needs. I had Mr. Weaver, the man who installed our pump and drilled the well, come and examine the well. He said the thought it needed new leathers and rubbers so we pulled the pump out, and however it was found that the working parts of the cylinder were badly worn and in order to correct the leak it would be necessary to get a new cylinder. New rubbers and leathers made no difference. This was done and we now have the well in splendid working condition. Pretty much as it was years ago. It has worked six years now on the first cylinder and the sand and grit has badly worn the parts. I trust my action is approved by the Department. It was the only thing to do.

I may say in regard to well matters, that we should have another well before long. For both house and farm requirements it is too great a tax on the one well. I believe Mr. Commissioner Graham has taken this matter up with the Department before now. We have a splendid well and a good system but it is not enough. I was talking the matter over with Mr. Weaver, and he said another well could be put down close to the one we already have and operated by line shaft.
from the same engine. We have still considerable well piping left from the old well—to go a long way. He says that he knows of a pump jack at the Government farm at Old River which can be purchased very reasonably, we can repair the old cylinder and have a new well for comparatively small cost. If the Department is disposed to consider a new well I shall be glad to give a diagram and prices.

3rd—We are in bad need of a little paint and varnish around the floors and walls. We can do all the work ourselves if we have the material.

4th—We would like to put in a few partitions and make a few changes in some parts of the building. I think V joint would do for the most part. A carpenter would probably be needed for a few days. We would like to put one partition at the boys' stairway. At present the dust and noise from the basement is very annoying. It would also make quite a difference to the drafts which at present exist. I think this would be quite an improvement. We would also like the space behind the basement stairways closed up. These corners form splendid catch-alls and also hiding places. We could use the spaces very well for storing cleaning materials which should be under lock and key. I shall be glad to have permission to go ahead with these changes.

5th—we should have a little plumbing done. A new sink in the room off the staff dining room, and some repairs to the big kitchen range.

I trust that the Department will consider favorably these requests. In spite of their number, the cost will not be very great.

Yours Truly,

J. P. Woodsworth,
Principal.
Ottawa, February 23, 1926.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, concerning repairs at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Your action in securing a new cylinder for the pump at the well is approved. I should be pleased if you would indicate what materials would be necessary and estimate the cost for the following improvements mentioned in your letter:

1. Painting and varnishing.
2. Partitions.
3. New sink for staff dining room.

It is always advisable to forward estimates of the cost of any improvements or repairs requested.

Concerning the advisability of sinking a second well, I should be pleased if you would forward the diagram and estimate. I am not hopeful that this can be authorized at the present time, as our funds are extremely limited and there is no provision for this purpose in our Main Estimates, 1926-27.

Dear Mr. Scott:

With reference to your instructions regarding the incurring of expenditures, I wish to quote an extract from a letter received this morning from J. F. Woodsworth, Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, as follows,

"In a recent letter from Mr. Ferrier, he informed me that there was provision in the budget for fencing and buildings at this school. He also stated that you have instructions to carry out these repairs."

I have no authority of this kind, and I think Mr. Ferrier should be so informed. I have instructions to carry out what repairs I think are necessary.

The Principal goes on to say that there is considerable fencing to be done and posts to be purchased, as they have nothing but willow posts on the place at present. Willow posts are what we are advocating all through our schools, with the occasional cedar posts, and these are what will be used at Edmonton unless I am instructed to the contrary.

I regret that this matter is not yet thoroughly understood by Mr. Ferrier, as it only means trouble and unpleasantness for me.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that I left here on August 28th, to visit some of the Western Agencies.

EDMONTON SCHOOL, EDMONTON AGENCY.

I found a great improvement in the grounds at this school since my last visit. The Principal has given a great deal of attention to this improvement. The children at this school appear to be quite healthy, and I am told they are advancing well in their classroom work. The building was clean throughout, and everything in the way of machinery was in splendid working order. The Principal would like to have some slight changes made in the main hall. The stairs leading from the main hall to the basement are open, and he would like to have the doors fixed in with a door at the head of the stairs so there is a tremendous amount of draft passing all the time, which makes it almost impossible for us to live during the severe weather. I quite agree that this change should be made. It would not take much money for this work, and if you will give me the necessary authority I will see that it is done. The farm work in connection with this institution is up to its usual standard; it could not be much better. I am told that approximately ten thousand dollars worth of grain was raised here this year.

The difficulty in recruiting is evident here; there is trouble in getting the children from the Hobbs Agency. Some of the children who attended the Methodist Day School are now attending the Roman Catholic Boarding School, as the parents claimed they were Roman Catholic before they even entered the Day School on the reserve. There were a number of children still on the reserve who should have been in the Edmonton School, and I gave instructions to the Agent to see that they were sent without delay, and these instructions will be carried out.

W. M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, October 5th, 1926.

Sir:

Relative to that portion of your report of the 17th ultimo on the Edmonton Indian Residential School regarding the request made by the Principal to have some changes made in the main hall, I beg to say that you may incur the expenditure necessary in having the stairs leading from this hall to the basement boxed in with a door at the head of the stairs, in order to prevent draughts passing up and down these stairs and to make the building warmer during severe weather.

No unnecessary expense should be incurred and as much of the labour as possible should be performed by the school management. Vouchers in the usual manner covering the cost of the material, etc., should be forwarded.

It is noted that the general conditions at this school are satisfactory and that there has been much improvement in the grounds surrounding the school.

Your obedient servant,

No. 306, in favour of the Brew Machine Company, for $56.15, covering an emergency repair to the pump; No. 306, in favour of the Norwood Foundry Company, for $15.00, covering emergency repairs to the kitchen range; and No. 307, in favour of Reed & Turnbull, for $35.85, covering emergency repairs to the furnace in the Principal's residence - are being paid. Vouchers Nos. 303 and 304, which are returned herewith, are for minor repairs and the amounts are inconsiderable. These should either be paid by the school management from the per capita or other earnings or you should adopt the plan in use at certain other Indian residential schools where the department endeavours to pay for all unavoidable repairs to the mechanical plant. The practice referred to is to deal with one plumber, one electrician, one hardware, one lumber firm for a stated period and, at the end of each quarter, submit certified accounts in duplicate from these firms, covering the materials and services supplied and rendered during the three months period. It is not necessary for me to point out that this method is preferable to a continual stream of accounts from various firms, all for small amounts. When the quarterly accounts are being forwarded, you should exercise care so that no items are included which should properly be met from the per capita grant.

In order that this letter may be a more complete writing concerning the Department's wishes relative to accounts, may I remind you that authority for expenditures other than minor ones should be secured from the Department before purchase, except in emergencies. You should secure competitive prices from the best available local sources when making purchases which involve expenditures of more than Fifteen or Twenty Dollars.

Yours obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir;

The Rev.T. Perrier, Inspector of Indian Schools, under the United Church, wrote me from your office while in Ottawa regarding the carking of the windows of this school. He asked me to write you regarding the mode of repair.

I have a good contractor who has done work for us here, and whose judgment I trust. He says that he can make a very thorough job of the windows and completely stop the draft by taking out the inside frames and filling the space between the brick and the casings with plaster. Yesterday he took one of the windows out and showed me what was necessary and I am convinced it is right. This will not necessitate removing the brick mould nor the windows from the outside which would be a very long and costly job. He states that neither caulk nor gun composition would be satisfactory, which I think is correct. This man could start in right away and fix these windows up at a cost of $2.50 per window; this will include labor and material. I would strongly recommend that this work be done at once. The man is free just now but intends soon to take other work when the spring opens up. An immediate reply will be appreciated.

I enclose a sketch of the portion of the window to be filled with plaster. At present there is little or no filling at the windows and the wind and air has free access to the rooms. The wonder is that we have been able to keep the building warm during these winter months.

Yours Truly,

J.F. Woodworth,
Principal.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

April 8, 1927.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

There has been considerable correspondence regarding the windows of the Edmonton Indian Residential School. It appears that shrinkage is responsible for considerable draught and, in a high wind in the coldest months, it is extremely difficult to keep parts of the building at all comfortable. The Church authorities and the Rev. Principal have been in correspondence with the Department as to what remedial action can be taken. There is now a recommendation that the inside frames be taken out and the space between the brick and the casing filled with plaster. A local conscientious man, in whose judgment the Rev. Principal has confidence and who has done work at the school before, offers to undertake the work at a cost of $2.50 per window. This will include labour and material. Mr. Orr recommends that this offer be accepted.

There are some 250 windows and the cost of this improvement will be approximately $625. In view of the urgency of the matter, I wish to recommend that you give your authority. I have lately learned that $1000, which will be voted for an improvement at the Fort Simpson Indian Residential School, will not be expended this year, so funds will be available. These institutions are both under the management of the United Church.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, April 14, 1927.

J. F. WOODSWORTH,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alta.

"Reference your letter twenty-ninth, you may have windows main building fixed at cost of two dollars and fifty cents each."

You may arrange to have this work carried out, when convenient, and the cost, including the labour and material, should not exceed the sum of $2.50 per window. When the work is completed, please prepare and forward accounts, in duplicate, stating the number of windows. The account should read as follows:-

Memorandum:

With reference to the request for a grant of $5,000 for the erection of a farm instructor's cottage at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, I have to report that there is no specific provision in the Estimates. There is an item of $1,600 for an ice house and cold storage, which has also been requested by the church authorities.

There is an item of $5,000 for a double classroom at the Morley Indian Residential School, which is under the same auspices. I understand that the church authorities consider the cottage at Edmonton as more urgent. It might be advisable to get Mr. Commissioner Graham's recommendation as to which of the two buildings should be erected this year. I shall be pleased to have your instructions in the matter.

Dear Sir;

Herewith please find enclosed a picture for your information, of the one of the windows as left by the contractor and which we are having repaired, by the authority of the Department. This is a sample window. It is no wonder that we could not keep warm. In fact it is a wonder that there is any heat in the building whatever.

I find that the outside of the windows are very open and admit of a great deal of cold. Just as bad as the inside. I have given instructions to the carpenter to fill up some of these windows on the outside. This will probably cost about $50 for a window more, but it will make the job fairly complete. After a good deal of consideration I decided that this was necessary as there was nothing to stop the wind from getting all around the brick work and for an extra $50 I am sure it will be worth while. I request the permission of the Department to this extra. It will not be more than about $50.00 extra.

Yours Truly,

Sir:

I have your 110-0-5 of the 5th instant with reference to the proposed residence at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, enclosing an architect's drawing and giving an estimate of the cost, and I am of the opinion that the Department should not be called upon to erect a house such as is asked for. The suggestion of Mr. Woodsworth is that the house which is at present occupied by the Farmer, Mr. Goodland, and which is perhaps a better house than eighty per cent of our Farmers have and better than many of our agency houses, be abandoned by the present occupant and used as a dwelling for a married farm labourer whom it is proposed shall be employed instead of a single man, and that the proposed new building be given to the Farmer. I am utterly opposed to this. As I have said, the Farmer has a good house and if living quarters are required for a married labourer a simple cottage of the bungalow type might be built at a cost of $3500.00 at the outside and perhaps less if the school will supply the labour which they proposed putting into the house which is now asked for. It is unbelievable that a request of this kind should be made and I am quite satisfied that if the Minister or the Deputy Minister could see the building which is now occupied by Mr. Goodland they would agree that a new residence for the Farmer is quite unnecessary. As for having the school authorities undertake the work, I have already expressed the opinion that it would be a mistake to do this. There has been a great deal of talk going on at Edmonton ever since the outbuildings at this school were erected, and I think to delegate any additional work to the school authorities would be bound to cause comments.

Dear Mr. Woodsworth:

Re home for your farming instructor:

My own thought is that a cottage not exceeding $3,500 or $4,000 at the most is about all we should expect from the Department. If this money is spent for material and some skilled labor, together with the labor contributed by the school, ought to contract a house worth about $6,000 in the city of Edmonton. This suggestion is in harmony with the policy I have always pursued in the construction of out-buildings in connection with our residential schools, viz., the Department furnishes the material and the management the labor. If you are not prepared to furnish the greater part of the labor and the whole is let by contract you will have a much inferior house.

In any case, the enclosed plan is more expensive than I would feel justified in asking the Department for. I am addressing a letter to the Department at Ottawa and enclosing you a copy of the same. July 29, 1927.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Funds are available for the erection of a farmer's residence at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Mr. Commissioner Graham recommends that he be authorized to erect a building which will be suitable for the farm instructor's assistant. He estimates the expenditure at $3500.

The Superintendent of United Church Indian Schools and the Reverend Principal at Edmonton are anxious of erecting a better and bigger residence. They have submitted plans with a full estimate of the cost, showing that approximately $5000 will be the expenditure. They are prepared to erect this building, using school labour, if the Department will pay the bills for the material and a little expert labour to the amount of $3500. The reason for this proposal is that they wish to have a new building for the present farm instructor, Mr. Goodland, who has been at Indian residential schools under the United Church for about 20 years. The assistant farm instructor, for whom a residence is needed, would then move into Mr. Goodland's present home.

Mr. Commissioner Graham is opposed to this proposal. He considers that the home in which Mr. Goodland is now living is quite satisfactory. He suggests that the Department authorize him to erect a labourer's cottage and he will keep the cost below $3500.

Personally, I believe it advisable to cooperate with the various school managements in the matter of erection of outbuildings. If they will provide all the rough labour and hauling, our outbuilding programme will be less expensive than if the work is done directly by the Department. In this particular instance, each scheme means an expenditure of $3500; but the church's proposal means a better building. Please let me have your instructions.

Duncan C. Scott

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,

REGINA, SASK., Sept. 26th, 1927

Dear Sir:

Acting on instructions contained in your letter No. 403-11A M, dated the 16th instant, I proceeded to the Edmonton Indian Residential School and made a careful survey of the building, and beg to submit the following report:

FIRE ESCAPES:

There are at present two fire escapes situated at the back end of the main building. These are iron stairways reached from a window in a staff room at each end of the hall, and terminating about six feet from the ground. In case of fire, the children would have to cross a hall from their dormitories and pass through a staff room, and in the event of these staff room doors being locked there would be no means of reaching the escapes. It is, in my opinion, a very poor and inadequate arrangement.

The building comprises a basement, first floor, second floor and attic, and there are four dormitories—two at each end on the second floor. I would suggest that a fire escape be provided for each of the four dormitories. Before leaving Edmonton I ascertained that there could be built by the Edmonton Iron Fence and Fire Works Company, I am attaching hereto a sketch of a single fire escape, and one section of each would be fitted with poles from the ground to the bottom of window sill is 34 feet. The fire escape would consist of an iron platform 2'6" wide by 8' long. This platform would have an iron railing around it 3 ft. high, and would be attached to the side of the building flush with the bottom of the window sill, using screws to the wall with heads 6" x 1" long, which would hold it firmly. At each end of the platform there would be an opening 2'6" square, through which a 5-inch iron pole would be placed from the ground vertically, and would be attached to the side of the building with brackets, to a height of five feet above the platform. This would enable the children when sliding down the pole to get a firm grip upon before leaving the platform. It would be necessary to have a window, the position used for these fire escapes is obtained, hung on hinges, with an easily operated fastener and opening outward so that there would be no danger of jamming. The price given me for four sets of these fire escapes, fully installed on the building, was $450.00.

W. W. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
The present fire protection consists of two stand-pipes which run vertically from the basement to the attic floor. These stand-pipes are connected with the automatic pressure tanks in the boiler-room on each floor. Fifty feet of canvas hose is attached to each stand-pipe, thus providing for two streams of water on each floor. This hose is folded in racks and I found it in poor condition, as it had cracked at the folds and was looking badly. It will have to be replaced with hose of better quality, and I had Underwriter's Insurance Company send me a sample which they tested in Edmonton. The trouble with this arrangement appears to be that the supply of water would be very limited, and in the event of the supply pipe between the pressure tanks and the stand-pipes becoming damaged, the water supply would be cut off and the apparatus would, therefore, be useless. It would seem to be advisable to provide independent water storage facilities for fire fighting and protection purposes only.

I, therefore, obtained an estimate for the construction on the east of a concrete water storage tank and an independent unit for fire protection, consisting of an engine, centrifugal pump, and 300 feet of hose. In obtaining the estimate for a storage tank I included my plans sufficient storage for domestic water for connection with the boilers in the school. The water from the well could be used in these boilers, and they have been having their supply for this purpose from a slough. I would suggest a concrete tank 18 ft. wide by 40 ft. long, sunk ten feet in the ground. This tank would have a partition dividing it, and one end would be for hot water storage and the other to provide water storage for fire protection. It would be covered with a reinforced concrete slab ten feet above the ground level and with a plank roof at the ground level. After consulting with experienced men it is thought that by providing this air space of two feet between the concrete covering and the roof of the tank it would eliminate the danger from freeze. It is proposed to attach the supply pipe to the present pipe from the well to the pressure tanks. The connection would be made outside the building, so that when it was desired to fill the storage tank the water could be shut off from the pressure tanks and diverted to the storage tank. This would provide a direct flow from the well to the storage tank, without any connection with the building.

Regarding fire fighting equipment: After consulting with an experienced engineer connected with the firm of Compton's Limited, in Edmonton, I find that an independent unit could be used in connection with this outside storage tank, consisting of a 12 hp. Gas Engine, 2" Centrifugal Pump, and 300 feet of hose. The storage house is 10' x 10' and could be built on the east outside of the main building. With regard to the pump, a Dayton-Dow 2" centrifugal pump is rated to pump water at the rate of 110 gallons a minute, and at the nozzle of a 300 foot hose will give 45 pounds pressure and will throw a stream of water 64 feet vertically and 47 feet horizontally. By having an independent...
an independent unit of this capacity outside the building, any part of the building could be reached from the outside without interference from the fire. The unit could, by obtaining additional hose, be used in connection with protecting the outbuildings.

The following is an estimate of the cost, based on actual prices quoted. It might be possible to have these prices reduced when calling for actual tenders on the work:

- Tank, 12x6x20, complete with partition, reinforced concrete slab and plank roof $1300.00
- Pump house ........................................... $400.00
- 12 h.p. 'Novo' Engine .............................. $485.00
- Dayton-Bond 2" Centrifugal pump ............... $200.00
- 200 ft. smooth bore rubber-lined hose - 'Underwriters', to carry 50 lbs. pressure $142.00
- 3/4" Nozzle and extra coupling .................. $9.00
- Lining, 3" - 100 feet ............................. $75.00
- 2 - 2" Unions ......................................... $1.00
- 4 - 2" Elbows ......................................... $3.00
- 3 - 2" 'T's' ............................................ $2.70
- 50 feet - 2" pipe .................................... $10.50
- 1 Foot Valve ........................................... $4.70
- 2 Gate Valves .......................................... $4.00
- 3 2" Valves ............................................ $25.00
- Digging drains ........................................ $75.00

Total ...................................................... $2753.00

The foregoing estimate was as accurate a statement of the cost as I could arrive at, and I think will cover the expenditure.

I may say that I examined the building with a view of ascertaining if it would be advisable to place a storage tank in the attic for fire protection purposes, but find that the building is not constructed to carry the weight, and it would entail a considerable expenditure.
expenditure to reinforce the building and make it strong enough for that purpose. The independent turret that I have outlined could be utilized as a means of protection for the employees' residences, and as I have said, by getting additional hose, the outbuildings as well. This matter was taken into consideration in planning the scheme.

With reference to the fire escapes suggested, I would inform you that a similar arrangement is installed at the Conneaut Boarding School. When fire broke out in that school at three o'clock in the morning on November 26, 1915, the sisters and children left the building by way of the fire escape in very few minutes. It is, in my opinion, much more convenient than an iron stairway on the outside of the building.

I trust that the foregoing report will convey the information desired by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. Harrison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., Sept. 30th, 1927

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the fire protection at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, which report was made by Mr. Inspector Murison on instructions from this office.

With regard to the standpipes, I am quite satisfied that these are sufficient, provided extra care is taken by the Principal to see that the pressure is always kept on, and that immediately an alarm is given the pumps are started in order to keep the pressure up as much as possible. The Principal has had instructions on this point. Regarding the condition of the hose, this is not a surprise to me, as these hose go out of order in a very short time and unless closely watched and kept in repair they are next thing to useless. I have instructed the Principal to obtain new linen hose, which is highly recommended. The two existing fire escapes are not placed in the proper position; they should be at a point where they can be reached from a hall, and not from a bedroom as they are at the present time and this change should be made. I am also of the opinion that we should have sliding poles from a gallery at each dormitory. A price for these is submitted in the Inspector's report and is reasonable. With your authority I will take steps to have these changes made.

We have circularized all the schools about keeping their fire apparatus in good shape and inspecting same from time to time, and the necessity of having fire drill quite frequently.

Yours very truly,

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo together with a report from Inspector Morrison on the fire protection at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. You may arrange immediately to have the pole fire escapes provided for the dormitories. If you will examine the plans or the building you will notice that there are no fires maintained in the main building. The boiler room is located in the rear wing at the extreme end and at the farthest point from the main building. The kitchen and laundry are also located in this wing. The building itself is semi-fireproof construction and the electric wiring is all in conduit.

It was pointed out to me while I was there that the efficiency of the present fire escapes was affected by the way in which the doors leading on to the platforms were hung. Since my return I have examined the plan of this building, and find that if the doors had been hung in accordance with the plan they would not in any way block the fire escape. Dear Mr. Scott:-

I have your No. 110-0-5, of the 6th instant, with regard to the fire escapes on the Edmonton Indian Residential School, and reply to say that I have already taken steps to have the new pole fire escapes placed.

With regard to the existing fire escapes, before making the change of doors I feel I should go further into this matter, as I cannot understand how they will interfere with the escapes if they are properly hung. To change them to open inwards as you suggest would be a mistake and would, in fact, be against the law in this province, and in all probability the Alberta law is the same in this regard. Chapter 179 of the Revised Statutes of Saskatchewan, Section 2, reads as follows,-

"In all churches, halls, houses or other buildings heretofore or hereafter constructed or used for holding public meetings or as places of public resort or amusement, and school houses of more than one storey in height, all the doors shall be so hinged that they may open freely outward, and all gates or outer fences if not so hinged shall be kept open by proper fastenings during the time such buildings are publicly used, to facilitate the egress of people in case of alarm from fire or other cause."

Some years ago we had instructions from the Department to change all doors opening inward to open outward, and in several instances changes of this kind were made. I have a letter

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
a letter today from Father Levern, principal of the Peigan R.C. Indian Residential School, on the subject of fire escapes, in which he makes the following comment,

"All the doors leading to the fire escapes open in; I have always been wondering why Mr. Gardner Smith allowed the contractor to make that mistake."

I have examined the plans of the two recently constructed schools on the Peigan Reserve and find that the doors do open inward.

I am quite satisfied in my own mind that I should bring this matter to your attention before making any changes, and that the doors at the two residential schools mentioned should be made to open outward instead of inward. Kindly give me your instructions in the matter.

I notice in your letter you state that the boiler room is located in the rear wing at the extreme end and at the farthest point from the main building. While this certainly lessens the danger of fire, it is not a positive guarantee that fire will not originate elsewhere; in fact the last and only fire we had at this school started, not in the boiler room, but in the electric wiring in the conduit, which goes to show that fire might start anywhere in the building.

When we have the four pole fire escapes erected I feel that we will have a reasonable amount of protection, and rather than use the escapes with the doors opening inward I would suggest that we keep them locked and not use them at all, unless a change is made on the lines I suggested, viz:- have them entirely re-constructed so that there will be means of having the doors to open properly.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

REGINA, SASK., October 18th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Scott:

After the disastrous fire at Beauval, I have been reviewing the means we have at our disposal for the protection of life and property at our various residential schools, and on the 14th instant, I wrote you on the subject of the exits to the fire escapes at the Edmonton Residential School and those at the R.C. Residential School on the Peigan Reserve.

On looking at the plans of the St. Philips School, on the Keesekoonse Reserve, I find that the exit doors here also are provided to open inwards. I think this condition ought to be changed at once and before the school is occupied. The opening inwards of exits to fire escapes is considered bad practice in this western country, and I cannot recall an instance, in a modern building, where exit doors are not deliberately made to open outwards. In addition to this precaution, they are usually provided with double doors, not single, fitted with suitable bolts, which, when moderate pressure is exerted, will at once release the catches and allow the double doors to swing open freely. The type of bolt used is of such construction that the doors cannot be opened from the outside but only from the inside by the exertion of the pressure referred to. The arrangement for opening outwards minimizes the possibility of delay or panic, and the release of the bolts is accelerated when the doors are double, and therefore correspondingly lighter. These types of bolts and doors are so commonly used that I cannot understand how they escaped the attention of the Architect's Department.

I should, while on the subject, comment on the fact that, in many instances at our schools,

Duncan C. Scott, Bsc.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
the exits are reached through a small private room where access to them might be rendered extremely difficult by the carelessness, fright or timidity of the occupant. If provided for at the ends of the passage-ways, they are infinitely more easily accessible and direct.

At schools, where exit doors open inwards, changes ought to be immediately made which will preclude the possibility of a crush at an exit being so great as to render impossible the opening of the door.

Yours very truly,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir;

Herewith please find enclosed the following Vouchers:

Voucher 363 for $246.05 in favor of Hayward Lumber Co., Ltd.
Voucher 364 for Marshall-Wells Alberta Co., Ltd. for $120.52
Voucher 365 for $31.51 in favor of German's Ltd.
Voucher 366 for $46.16 in favor of The Edmonton Paint and Glass.

I may say that these accounts have been incurred in the erection of the farmers house, now completed.

These accounts are somewhat in excess of the amount authorized but I have found it quite impossible to keep exactly within the appropriation. As indicated in a former letter we have done all the rough labor work, and have employed but one carpenter. The wages of this carpenter was low in comparison with the work he did.

Being a brick house there were items of expense which we could not escape and which I did not foresee in the estimate. Sand for plaster and mortar, cement, and general supplies have accounted for all expenditure. You will find enclosed accounts for paint etc. The tenders from Marshall-Wells, and Edmonton Paint and Glass were practically the same so I bought for both to suit our preference.

I trust these accounts are correct and that the Department will pass them for payment.

Thanking you for past courtesies,

Yours Truly;

J. F. Woodsworth
Principal.

Ottawa, August 8, 1928.

Sir:

I have to inform you that it was represented to Mr. Ferrier, of this Department, when he was in Edmonton during July, that a cement soft water storage tank is urgently required at the Indian Residential School. Rev. Mr. Woodsworth pointed out that this could be placed in the ground to the west of the boiler room and that he would be prepared to undertake it at a cost of $500. At present, they are pumping soft water for use in boilers and other machines by hand and the arrangement is very poor. Please let me have a recommendation in this connection without delay, as it has been represented that the improvement is quite urgent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:—

I have your No. 110-0-5, of the 8th instant, with reference to the matter of providing a cement storage tank for soft water at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, at a cost of about $600.00. The size of the proposed tank is not mentioned, and it is, therefore, impossible to judge whether this is a reasonable cost or not. I shall take steps to find out just what the Rev. Principal expects to have built for this money. I cannot see that there is any great urgency for this work. I have visited this school on several occasions, and our Inspectors have also visited it, and no representation of this kind has been made, and I cannot agree that there is such urgency as your letter would indicate.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I recently received a request from the Rev. Principal of the Indian Residential School at Edmonton to arrange for the purchase of a Ford Sedan car for the Farmer, Mr. H. Goodland, at the regular discount rate granted to officials of the Indian Department. I was able to arrange for the purchase of a Chevrolet Sedan for the same party in April, 1927, and took up the matter of the purchase of the Ford with the Canadian Motors, Limited, here and expected that there would be no difficulty. I am, however, in receipt of a letter from the local Manager stating that they are unwilling to make delivery of a Ford car to Mr. Goodland on a discount basis, unless the sale is covered by a Departmental requisition.

I am of the opinion that Mr. Goodland is practically an employee of the Department, or in any event he works in an institution which is conducted under the supervision of this Department and that the car would be used a great deal on business connected with the school, and, therefore, there should be no objection to a sale being made to him at the discount rate. I think the Department will agree with me and I shall be glad to receive authority to be allowed to officially order the car for Mr. Goodland.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

There is an item in the Main Estimates for the finishing of the top floor of the Edmonton Indian Residential School. You will remember you approved of the scheme of sending some of the pupils of Brandon to this institution for the coming year or so, until the new building in Manitoba was ready. It will be necessary to effect this improvement before these pupils can be accommodated, and it is now timely to have the work commenced. If you approve of the scheme, Mr. Orr will examine the proposal forwarded by the church authorities, at an estimated cost of nearly $2,000, plus a little plumbing and lighting. The school management is prepared to effect the alterations on a day labour basis (with the exception of the lighting and plumbing) with an expenditure of only $200 for expert labour.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir,

The Department has received a letter from the Reverend Mr. Perrier enclosing an estimate for the finishing of the top floor of the two wings of the Edmonton School. The estimate amounts to $2,000 outside of the necessary electric wiring, plumbing and heating.

In looking over the plans and checking up the cost it is considered that a much greater amount will be required to fix up the two wings, including the plumbing, heating and wiring. Before further consideration can be given to the matter, I would ask you to please obtain and furnish me with a detailed estimate of the work required, including the necessary wiring which will have to be done in rigid metal conduit, the additional heating and the plumbing. It will also be necessary to provide adequate fire escapes for the dormitory, and it is suggested that this can be done by the installing of the pole type escape at the rear of the wings. The fire escapes can also be made to serve the dormitories on the first floor. You should include in the estimate a price for the fire escapes.

I would appreciate having this information at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,
