COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., April 2nd, 1929.

Inspection report on Schools in Edmonton Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that I visited the Edmonton Indian Residential School on Saturday evening, January 26th, and remained there until Tuesday, the 29th, and made a general inspection of the institution. Although I have visited this school on several occasions on special business, this is the first report I have submitted since March 3rd, 1924, just previous to the arrival of the first pupils at the school.

The Rev. J. F. Woodsworth has been in charge as Principal since the school was built. He is a hard worker and, after an examination of his accounts and records, I consider him a capable business manager. He has the interests of the school very much at heart and his time is very fully occupied. He acts as recruiting officer, keeps the books and records, and exercises general supervision over the activities in the school and on the farm. I found the staff composed of capable men and women. He is very fortunate in having such a good staff at the present time. Mr. Goodlands, who has held the position of Farmer at Branden and at this school for a period of about 30 years or more, has charge of the outdoor work, and Miss MacDonald, the Matron, is giving very satisfactory service. I found her very devoted to her duties and her time appeared to be occupied very fully from 6 o'clock in the morning until the children retired to bed.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
to bed. The engineer, Mr. Angel, is a very capable man and I found the equipment under his charge being kept in first class condition.

BUILDINGS.

I found the school building clean and tidy from the basement to the attic, and although the thermometer ranged from 45 to 55 degrees below zero during the period of my visit, the building was warm and comfortable.

Since my last visit four pole fire escapes have been installed with access to them from the dormitories. I found the fire equipment in good shape.

Some time ago I submitted a report on the water supply situation at this school, and I would again respectfully direct your attention to this question. There is only one well at this school. It is a very excellent well and the water is good for domestic purposes, but has too much soda content for use in the boilers and soft water has to be supplied. During the past winter, in the cold weather, the pump in this well broke and the school was without a water supply for three days. They had to haul ice for domestic purposes. This situation would be rather bad in the event of a fire taking place at such a time, and I would recommend strongly that a second well be sunk so that in the event of one pump getting out of order, and there is no doubt that it will in time, there would be the second well to fall back upon. The only water storage is provided in two 1100 gal. pressure tanks, and in the event of fire this would become exhausted in about 15 minutes. It seems to me that a cement water storage tank should be provided. I would also point out that we have no facilities for storing soft water at this school, and although...
although we have a large roof surface, the rain fall during the summer is allowed to go to waste. A cement tank would provide storage for soft water which could be used in the boilers and would make unnecessary a great deal of labour which now has to be done to keep the boilers supplied with soft water.

The electric lighting plant continues to give excellent service, and the laundry equipment is in good condition.

When visiting the dormitories it was noted that the mattresses which were originally supplied were in very poor condition; in fact, they are worn out and should be replaced. Even ticks filled with fresh straw would be much better than those now in use.

FARM.

There is now a total of 500 acres under cultivation. The crop seeded last season consisted of 110 acres of wheat, 125 acres of oats and 40 acres of barley, which yielded 3,000 bushels of wheat, 5,500 bushels of oats and 1,500 bushels of barley. The grain was badly damaged by frost. The potato crop was good and they secured 2,000 bushels. The live stock includes 14 work horses, 35 cattle and 60 hogs.

They were milking 12 cows at the time of my visit. The boys do the milking under supervision. It was noted that the girls are not taught to milk cows. It is important that both the boys and the girls should become proficient in this work.

The accommodation for the cattle is not adequate. There are only 24 stalls in the barn for 35 cattle. A lean-to shed might be added to the barn at comparatively little cost to provide housing for the young
EDMONTON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

FARM (CONT'D.)

Young stock. The cattle on hand were in very good condition. The hogs are a fine lot and nearly all that have been fattened for the Edmonton market have graded "Select" and No. 1. There are no poultry kept at this school, the reason given being that they have not been provided with a hen house. There is plenty of feed available, and I think that they should have a sufficiently large flock of hens to supply eggs for the institution.

GENERAL.

There was no sickness amongst the pupils at the time of my visit. I attended their church service on Sunday and remarked that I did not hear any of the children coughing during the service. They presented a clean, well dressed, healthy and happy appearance. There were 58 boys and 63 girls in residence at the time of my visit and 2 girls attending high school in Edmonton, making a total enrolment of 113.

In conclusion I may say that I was very pleased to note the smooth manner in which the institution was running, and consider that this school is a credit to the Department.

W. Morrison

Superintendent of Indian Agencies
Dear Mr. Scotti-

I am enclosing herewith a report of an inspection of the schools in the Edmonton Agency, which was made by Mr. Inspector Murison.

You will see from this report that the situation at the Edmonton Indian Residential School is all that could be desired and that the work is carried on in a satisfactory manner. The Inspector draws attention to the matter of the water supply at this institution, and I may say that, in my opinion, there is no necessity for digging another well, which might entail an expenditure of five or six thousand dollars. It does seem necessary, however, to have an additional supply of water on hand and it seems to me that we should have a reservoir near the school into which the water from the well could be pumped and from there would be pumped into the pressure tanks. On the other hand there might just be a supply of water pumped to a large underground tank for storage purposes, if we could be assured that this water would be used from time to time and the tank refilled so that it would be sure to be fresh. 1100 gallons of pressure does not seem to be enough for fire protection. I think in this you will agree with me.

I would also draw your attention to what the Inspector says about the state of the mattresses in the dormitories. Good mattresses should be supplied in an institution of this kind that is so much before the eyes of the public. It gives a very bad impression to people-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Bupt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
people passing through these dormitories to see such poor beds. I think that fairly good mattresses could be bought for $3.50 each.

The farm at this institution is well conducted. The only regrettable feature is that the children are not being taught to milk the cows. This matter has already been taken up with you as it was brought to my attention by one of our Travelling Nurses. I do not feel like recommending that the Department build another barn at this school, as I think they should get along with what they have. I think the reason given by the Principal for not having hens is a very poor one. He knows perfectly well that had he made a request to the Department for a henhouse he would have had one. We can put up a henhouse there for about $300.00, built on the same principle as those at the University, and at our other schools.

With reference to the St. Albert School, everything there was found in good order as usual. You are quite familiar with the promises that were made to the Sisters with regard to the building of the laundry and what proportion of the expense the Department would bear, so it is unnecessary for me to go into this matter. You will be pleased to note, however, that the laundry has been completed and is apparently highly satisfactory.

On the whole the report on these two schools is quite satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir;

I have to report that on Tuesday Morning April 9th, the sucker rods of our pump parted. Since then we have been without water and have only now got the pump operating and water once more into the school. We found that the coupling at a depth 80 feet had given out. This made it necessary to pull up the sucker rods and also the heavy 4" pump casing. The work is very heavy and cannot be done in any case under two days with everything going well. If anything went wrong we might be out of water for an indefinite length of time. With the amount of water to be pumped, the inevitable friction, and the weight of the machinery, we may expect these breaks from time to time. Each time it is a lower coupling which gives out, and this requires so much more time. It is now about five years since the well was completely out so the couplings have become loose, and there requires considerable readjustment.

Now I wish to point out that the well is a first class one. The water supply is all that can be desired as far as it goes. (we pump close to 10,000 a day at the present time). The pump is alright, but very heavy and requiring time to move it to say nothing of labor and machinery:- It is however the fact that we are liable without warning to be left without water for days or longer that is the serious fact, and this in a community of some 150 people to say nothing of stock or sanitary conditions, and also possible fire. I might say that just at the time we had the plasterers and they required about 20 barrels of water a day. In order to meet the need we had to take every boy out of school and carry water from the sloughs and ditches by the road side. This should not happen whenever any little repair of the pump is necessary, and yet we cannot do otherwise. I think it is
unnecessary for me to further emphasize our need as these facts are doubt more or less familiar to you. The fact is we need another well which can be used as a relief well or an alternate. This is required immediately and I herewith request authority to arrange for test holes to be put down and if satisfactory another well be drilled. If this is agreeable to the Department I would be glad of a wire to that effect. In the meantime if the Department wishes one of their inspectors might visit me and make a report on the matter.

This well is quite another matter from further tanks, or rain water supply, or overhead stand-pipe, it is the matter of a water supply in case of a temporary break. We should get right at this in view of the coming of the Brandon children.

I may say that we did all the work ourselves this time, the only expense being some tools and pulleys which were necessary, the accounts for which I shall forward later.

Yours Truly;

[Signature]

Principal.

Calgary, May 10th, 1929.

The Commissioner of Irrigation,
Department of the Interior,
Calgary, Alta.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the water supply and fire protection apparatus at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Date of Inspections - May 1 & 2, 1929.

The school is a four-storied structure of brick and hollow tile; there are about 150 children in residence there, and an additional 100 from Brandon are to be brought there temporarily during alterations at Brandon.

The water supply is obtained from a well about 320 ft. north of the school itself; while the quality leaves something to be desired, the quantity appears to be adequate. About 10,000 gals. per day appears to be used at present, and it seems fair to assume that another 6,000 gals. will supply the additional pupils expected.

I am informed that the well has yielded 40 gals. per minute on test without any diminution or 57,600 gals. per day.

The reason why a second well is needed is that the machinery for raising the water out of the present well is in very poor condition and likely to break down at any moment; the power head is of an obsolete type and worn out while the piping and rods in the well have given much trouble and have had to be pulled out upon several occasions with makeshift equipment. The supply might be cut off for several days (or even weeks) while repairs are being made, and as the two pressure tanks (the only storage) only contain one hour's supply it will be realized that the situation is serious.

The best remedy is a second well; the only alternative is storage which would cost more than a second well is likely to do for anything more than a day's supply; moreover the soda or other salts in the water make its taste more unpalatable after storage.

The best site for the proposed new well appears to be near the northeast corner of the boiler house. While of course a well alongside the existing one would be more certain of striking a supply, it might be that it would reduce the yield of the first. Moreover for several reasons it would be more convenient to have the pumping machinery handy to the existing boiler room and electric light plant.

The proposal made by Mr. Woodsworth, the Superintendent, in which I concur, is to attempt to find water in the site selected at 175' to 200' (the depth of the existing well) and,
if unsuccessful, to move over to the locality of the existing well, without spending any more on exploration work.

To drill say a 3" test hole, fail to find water, and then drill at the second site might cost $1,200 and I should recommend that authority be given Mr. Woodsworth at the earliest possible moment to spend up to that amount on drilling. The case is urgent and the design of the rest of the system depends on where water is found. Well drillers are in great demand in Alberta at present, and if one can be found it would be unwise to let the opportunity slip.

From the fire protection point of view the situation is equally serious. There are two (1½") fire hydrants on each floor, eight in all dependent upon the same well and pump driven by a 7 B.H.P. engine.

To reach the top floor it would have to raise the water 160 feet in the well and then lift it about 56 feet in the building; there would be the friction in 175 feet of 4" pipe, 330 feet of 3", 100 feet of 2" and 30 feet of 1½". The volume and pressure obtained would be very small.

As the fire-nozzles are attached to the domestic service pipes, any failure in these due either to extra pressure or incidental causes, would reduce still further the volume and pressure available.

To remedy these conditions the following plant is proposed.

(1) As already mentioned drill new well and install power head.

(2) Construct storage tank for fire purposes, also rain-water tank having capacities of 21,500 and 11,300 gallons, respectively, as at Onion Lake School.

(3) Install fire protection pump with a capacity of about 50 gals. per min. with a full head at the nozzles.

(4) Install 14 B.H.P. engine with fast and loose pulleys at each end to work either new well power head or fire pump.

(5) Increase number of pressure tanks from two to four.

(6) Provide direct connection from five pumps to hydrants apart from service pipes.

(7) Provide hose so that outlying buildings may be reached from hydrant in pumphouse.

(8) Provide chemical protection as at Onion Lake.

(9) Repair pumping machinery at existing well including new power head.
In accordance with the wishes of Mr. Woodsworth, the Superintendent, and Mr. Angel, the plant engineer, it is proposed to install the new fire fighting pump and engine immediately north of the present boiler house. The writer has weighed the advantages and disadvantages of this course, and agrees with them that these advantages outweigh the danger of fire in the building making the pumping plant inaccessible. The saving of time in reaching the plant and the ease of starting in a warm building are important factors and the new pumphouse (which will be mostly underground) will be of fireproof construction.

Consideration has been given to the idea of driving the new service pump electrically, but Mr. Angel, the plant engineer, states that it would overload his plant. By the method proposed the 14 H.P. engine primarily intended for driving the fire pump, will also operate the new well lift. This will save the expense of a second engine or motor. When pumping against the pressure tanks for ordinary purposes it will use about 5 H.P. and it seems probable that this light duty will insure its being ready for use, better than if it stood idle. The consumption of gasoline will only be slightly greater than that used by a smaller engine. When pumping into open tank it will only require about 1½ H.P. so that in case of a fire it might run both pumps if desirable.

The following is an estimate of the cost of the proposed works.

(1) Drill and case new well (including allowance for test hole or holes.) allow $1,200

(2) Rainwater and well water tank as at Onion Lake School 4,000 -

(3) Concrete pump house and pressure tank shelter (north of present boiler house). 2,000

(4) Plant in new pump-house

1-14 B.H.P. engine Lister twin cylinder vertical
1 fire pump. Lister 6" x 6" double
1 Myers self oiling power head with rods, etc.
2 pressure tanks each 3'6" x 15'0"
1 Hydrant with Nozzle Hose hanger, etc. 2,600

(5) Piping valves, etc. 1,100

(6) Repairs to existing well & power head, allow 400 -

(7) 500' linen fire hose with couplings to reach other buildings 250

(8) Chemical equipment as at Union Lake 250

(9) Additional cost if well has to be near existing well $400 to $700 700

12,500

In concluding I should like to urge the necessity of this work being started at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

(signed) F.R. BURFIELD.
Sir:

In further reference to your letter of April 22 regarding the water supply system for the Edmonton Indian Residential School, I have received a report on this subject from the Commissioner of Irrigation, copy of which is enclosed.

The inspection of conditions was made as soon as possible after your instructions had been received, but owing to the fact that there was considerable detail to be obtained before plans could be prepared, it was found necessary to have further information obtained on the ground before submitting the report and plan showing the general layout of the existing plant and the proposed additional plant required.

From this report you will note that the water supply condition at present is unsatisfactory and unreliable. Additional storage facilities to cope with fire conditions and an additional source of supply are needed in order to take care adequately of the school's requirements. The Commissioner advises that the scheme now outlined in the report herewith is along the lines discussed with Mr. Woodsworth, principal of the school, and that it appears to be adequate in every respect. He further points out that the existing pumping plant at the well is in such a condition that it is urgent that steps be taken immediately to provide a supplementary supply.

I beg to recommend, therefore, that the scheme now being presented in the attached report be adopted and authority given to proceed with the work at as early a date as possible. The cost is estimated at $13,750., and I presume would have to be carried out by contract.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

MAY 27, 1929.

Commissioner Graham has reported that the water supply system at the Edmonton School is not satisfactory and recommends that an additional well be provided. The Reverend Principal has also reported that an additional well is required.

The Dominion Water Power Branch were asked to have one of their District Engineers visit the Edmonton School and submit a report and recommendation for the water supply system for this building. This report has now been received and they recommend the digging of a second well and the providing of a storage tank for fire protection purposes, two additional pneumatic tanks and a fire pump together with extra fire fighting apparatus. They estimate the cost of this work at $13,750.00. It is evident from their report that some action should be taken immediately to remedy the existing conditions. If you approve of the work being carried out, I would recommend that the Dominion Water Power Branch be authorized to instruct their Engineers to proceed with the work on a day labour basis.

Dear Sir;

The finishing of the top floor is nearly completed and all has gone along in accord with the plan as outlined in my letter. Few if any extras have been found necessary. In connection with the plumbing there have been some necessary alterations in other parts of the building however to accommodate the extra children (1) We require extra kitchen space. This is found in a room next to the kitchen. I wish in this an extra sink and a door, or opening, put between the kitchen and the present bake room. This is easily done and will enable one officer to control the whole. (2) We will require more room in the lavatory for both boys and girls. I have suggested a galvanized trough connected with the sewers on both boys and girls side. This is the least expensive and most effective method which I can suggest. I also ask for a drain in the basement floor for flushing the floors. There is none at present, which is a great inconvenience. These are the only extras which I ask. They are very necessary and I have thought and planned about them for a long time and consulted with the plumber as to methods and costs. I trust the Department will approve of these changes.

Yours Truly:

Dear Sir;

Herewith please find enclosed the following voucher:

No. 325 in favor of The Edmonton Iron Fence and Wire Works for $559.80. This is the fire escapes as mentioned in my letter of March 5th; See your letter No. II0-0-5 of March 18th 1929.

No. 326 in favor of Hillas Electric Co. for $189.50. This is a trifle better than my estimate as per Colin Allan.

No. 327 in favor of Beckett, Plasterer, for $1726.50.

My estimate for this job was over $2300.00 done on metal lath. (See your letter). However I did my best to cut down the number of yards for the metal lath. Just allowing them to plaster on the tile, when possible. Then in place of plaster we used the Beaver Board which just requires the paint. In this way there was quite a saving. I also cut the figure down $50.00 by using our own labor, which was not in my original estimate. The sand of course in this job was supplied separately by the Department.

No. 328 in favor of The Edmonton Paint and Glass Co. Limited for $129.38. This paint account includes paint for the finishing of the top flat and also for the painting of the machinery shed.

See your letter of September 24th 1928, No. II0-0-5. There is also included material for a little repair work and painting and the usual freshening up around the buildings. The school supplied all labor. I may say that it also includes the necessary annual going over of the children's dormitories, infirmary, and the bath rooms after the years use. The material was kept down to what was actually required.

I trust these accounts are satisfactory.

Yours Truly,

J.G. Woodsworth,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Herewith please find enclosed Voucher No.411 in favor of
the Standard Heating and Plumbing Co., Limited, for $2072.67.

This is for the contract in connection with finishing upper
floor and some necessary extras. See my letter of March 5th, and
your reply of March 15th. Also my letter of May 15th and your reply of
July 9th.

I fear that my action in the case of the extra plumbing is
out of harmony with your letter of July 9th. The latter came somewhat
as a surprise to me as I felt that the silence of the Department from
May 15th constituted a sanction to my request. I know that this may
appear to assume too much on my part, but the extras were urgent and
I hope to show that these extras are necessary. I quite admit that I
have overstepped my authority.

The item of $86.62 is for repairs to the radiators in the
chapel which were caught by the frost during one of the severe spells
last winter. I let the matter go at the time, but felt that when
the plumbing were here they should have been repaired. The item of
$8.25 was a broken register face in the basement leading to the air
flue. This was being used as a catch all and sometimes I found
matches and other dangerous things in it. I considered it should be
repaired. The item of $45.75 involved drain in each of the play
rooms—boys and girls side. When the school was built there was no
drain put in and no way of flushing out the play rooms. Since the
drains were put in things have been much easier. In the case of
the item for $74.33. This should have been in the contract. I was
under the impression that it was. This was an extension of the water pipe for fire protection, and is on all the other floors. I was sure that the Department would wish this connection made.

The next item of $14.30 is for an extra sink in a room adjoining the kitchen. In the first place I asked how much the sink would cost and was told that one was available for $15.00. One of a little different model, and that this was just half price. I considered that $15.00 was reasonable. I did not expect the labor and fittings would cost so much. However this has made a wonderful difference in our kitchen convenience. The next item of $500.40 came as a great surprise to me. I wanted a little extra space for wash basins. I did not want anything elaborate, merely a trough to hold granite basins and spill them down the sewer. After talking the matter over with the plumbers we decided on galvanized iron troughs to be connected with existing sewers. It must be remembered that we have over 200 children in attendance and only twelve basins in each wash room for their use, and only the two wash rooms. Now this is my story. Your reply did not come until really too late to alter my request and in the meantime these conditions were facing me. Of course I would not have gone ahead if I had received your letter sooner. Officially I have no excuse, but with the facts in the case I trust this amount will receive consideration. I have asked your inspector or Mr. Morrison to come in and see things when he is through next and if necessary make a report as to the necessity of the extras. I say say that this is the only amount which has exceeded the estimate and in most cases I have kept things down. If the Department wishes to investigate kindly pay the contract and let the other stand open.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, September 19, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing two vouchers in favour of the Standard Heating and Plumbing Company. I note your explanation concerning the extras. It is true that there was some delay in replying to your request of May 15th. The Department has decided to pay the amount in full and to await Mr. Inspector Hurison's report on the necessity of the extra plumbing which was undertaken. When this report is received, it will then be decided whether or not the amount of some of the extras should be deducted from the per capita grant of the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

October 5th, 1929.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report in connection with the repairs and replacements as well as the new building erected at the Edmonton Residential School during the past summer.

Owing to the increase in pupilage through the transfer of 83 children from the Brandon Residential School in July last it was found necessary to provide additional accommodation and facilities for caring for these children. This has been arranged by converting the waste space on the top or attic floor into dormitories, Bath rooms, Washrooms and Bath rooms. The East and West wings have been converted into large well lighted and attractive dormitories for the boys and girls respectively with accommodation for 44 beds in each. The necessary radiators have been installed and connected up with the heating system. The water standpipes have been extended and provided with the necessary hose for fire fighting and a toilet provided in each dormitory. Clothes rooms with access to them from the dormitories and baths have been provided.

Four staff rooms, two each for male and female members of the staff have been provided adjoining the dormitories.

A bath room at each end of the hall has been fitted up. Ventilation is provided through the windows. I visited the dormitories in the morning and found the air fresh and sweet. Pole fire escapes with easy means of access thereto have been installed.

The space in the centre of the top floor is being used for storage purposes and there is now no space under the roof of the same building which is not being utilized for a useful purpose. The plastering finishing and plumbing work has been well done.

There were some alterations and installations made which were not included in the original estimate which I will explain in detail.

During the severe weather last winter a number of sections in the radiators in the chapel burst and had to be replaced. 23 new sections have been installed and this entailed an expenditure of £60.00. Tile work had to be done.

Two floor drains, one in the hall and one in the boys' playroom were installed. The floors in these rooms are concrete and are washed with a hose. The drainage necessary to carry off the water was and should have been provided when the building was first erected. These cost £45.00.

The replacement of a broken register fan in the basement leading to the air flue was necessary to prevent it from being used as a depositary for rubbish. This costing, on account of the difficulty of obtaining a suitable fan, was £15.00.

The kitchen space has been added by constructing an access to two small rooms by removing partitions converting the rooms which had been of little use into much needed kitchen space. A sink was installed at a cost of £114.35 and the work in connection with making and finishing the openings was done by the school staff. The added space was much needed and I consider that the expenditure was necessary owing to the increased work brought about through the increased pupilage.

W. W. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Saskatchewan.
The facilities for washing in the boys and girls wash rooms have been added to by the installation of four sinks made with heavy castings from one single iron frame. These sinks have been fitted with taps and drain connections to the existing pipes and ordinary wash basins are used in these troughs.

There are now 230 children in residence and some more will be arriving shortly. There are 107 girls in residence now and only 12 wash bowls were available for their use. It will be readily seen that some provision had to be made to meet the situation and the above remarks applies to the new wash room. The new installation is strong, convenient and very suitable. The cost $640, appeared high to me but upon examining the detailed account of material supplied and work performed everything appears to be in order.

I am satisfied that the additional washing facilities are necessary to house the increased population.

A new barn house, implement shed and threshing machine house have been completed. The barn in addition to the horse barn has been converted into a very good storage house.

The Pump Jack formerly in use has been disposed of and a Myers Pump Jack installed in its place. This is working very satisfactorily. When making the new installation it was found that the water level in the well has not changed during the past nine years.

The question of providing a water storage tank for an emergency supply and for fire protection is in my opinion an important one and every consideration that might be given consideration. The water supply in the present tanks is barely sufficient for domestic requirements and they have to be pumped full at least ten times each day.

In the event of fire the supply from the pressure tanks would not last long.

I am informed that the matter of providing cold storage facilities is receiving consideration by the Department.

There are no facilities for keeping fresh meat or other supplies at this institution and they are very necessary.

As time goes on and the farm and live stock industries develop the need for adding to the accommodation becomes a pressing necessity. In this connection I would point out that a fine herd of 45 heads of cattle has been built up and the present barn could provide room for half that number. An addition to the barn is necessary in order that they cattle may be retained and the herd kept up.

Another hog house similar to that now in use is required to provide for the development of this industry and to care for the hogs on hand. There are 150 pigs on hand at the present time and they are a fine lot. The raising of hogs forms a valuable source of income for the school.

About $800.00 in canned food supplies were provided through the live stock industry last year.

The light rainfall affected the returns from the farm and garden. The Farm produced 900 bushels of wheat, 5000 bushels of oats, 1500 bus barley and a large quantity of very good quality of green feed. The wheat out turn was disappointing being about one third of a crop.

The quality of the potatoes is excellent and between 1500 and 2000 pounds have been secured. The garden produce was generally small owing to the dry summer.

It gives me pleasure to state that I consider that the general conditions at this school are very satisfactory and reflect great credit to Mr Woodworth's management.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted,

I have the honour to be, Sir

Your obedient servant,

W. Morrison
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Sir:-

I have just received a letter from Mr. Murison, written to me from Edmonton, which reads as follows,-

"When I was leaving Edmonton for Saddle Lake I saw Mr. Woodsworth at the station and he informed me that he had received a letter from the Department in which they stated that they were awaiting a report from me in connection with the renovations to the school building. I therefore stopped off here and am submitting my report in duplicate herewith."

I beg to say that I had received no instructions from the Department, and I do not think it was the intention of the Department that Mr. Woodsworth should give these instructions to Mr. Murison, as they should have come through this office. I did not tell Mr. Murison to go to the Edmonton school, nor did he intend going there. Am I wrong in asking that instructions of this kind pass through this office, so that my files may be complete and I shall know what is going on in the field?

Mr. Murison's report is herewith submitted without comment from me, as I presume the Department does not wish me to comment on the matter or they would have written to me.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

W.W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, October 12, 1929.

Sir:

I have your 403-114 U of the 8th instant, with reference to a recent report of Mr. Inspector Murison's on extra plumbing undertaken at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

I may say the Rev. Principal wrote that he had asked Mr. Inspector Murison to make a report on this when he was next at the school. The Department replied to his letter in part as follows: "It has been decided to pay the amount in full and to await Mr. Inspector Murison's report on the necessity of the extra plumbing which was undertaken. When this report is received, it will then be decided whether or not the amount of some of the extras should be deducted from the per capita grant."

Of course, there was no intention that Mr. Woodworth should give instructions to Mr. Murison. The Department expected to find reference to the extra plumbing in Mr. Murison's next report on the Edmonton school.

Mr. Murison reports that the additional plumbing fixtures were really necessary, and, as the Department has paid the account, no further action is necessary.

As our estimates are now being prepared, I should like to have a special report from you regarding the needs at this school. The Department is favourably considering the providing of improvements to the water supply system. Mr. Murison in his recent report speaks of the need for cold storage facilities, an addition to the cow barn and a second hog pen. Please let me have your recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th ultimo No. 110-C-5 asking for a special report regarding the needs at the Edmonton School in the way of cold storage facilities, improvements to the water supply system, an addition to the cow barn and a second hog pen.

You are probably aware of the fact that they have a splendid well at the Edmonton School. A new pump has been installed that is giving perfect satisfaction, so that as far as the water supply is concerned it is ample. If anything should go wrong with the pump an expert could be obtained from Edmonton in a very short time to put it right, and I am not looking for anything to go wrong. The question of fire protection is one that might be considered by the Department. Mr. Paulin, and others who are familiar with the situation at Edmonton say that we could easily provide another pressure tank within the school. This would not take up much room and would mean another 1500 gallons of water under pressure all the time. This would be much better than to have a tank in the ground outside, and should not cost much money if handled in the right way.

With regard,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
With regard to cold storage; every school should have a cold storage plant of some kind. One of the modern plants should be installed and there may be space available at the school at the present time where refrigeration could be put in.

I do not think that an addition to the cow barn is necessary. What we do need is a cheap shelter for young stock, to keep them out of the wind, but to erect a barn would be a useless expenditure of money. I understand the additional space is required for young stock, yearlings and two-year-olds.

With regard to the matter of a second hog pen, I would point out that we have a wonderful hog pen at this school, 50 ft. long, with 10 compartments 10' x 10', five on each side, which will hold all the pigs that should ever be kept at an Indian school. These schools are not meant to be money-making institutions, and as the present hog pen will provide accommodation for from 50 to 60 hogs I am quite sure it is not necessary that we should build a second one.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir - Re Water Supply Indian School, Campbell, Alberta.

The writer is in receipt of your telegram of this date in reference to the above Institution and is pleased to submit the following report.

In our opinion the compressed air system recently installed is altogether inadequate for an Institution of this kind and not suitable for such a series of buildings.

There is installed at the present time two tanks 4' diameter by 18ft. long which when full hold about twelve hundred gallons each. These tanks are new, but neither of these tanks nor compressed air water system, one third of the capacity of each tank is filled with air which leaves space for only eight hundred gallons of water in each tank, as water supply to the different buildings. The tanks installed are about large enough to supply two houses and perhaps the Kitchen of the School.

We have had considerable experience with compressed air water systems and our candid opinion is that they are not at all suitable for an Institution of this kind.

Our recommendation to you would be to use a steel tank erected on a steel tower on a suitable foundation with a capacity of about 50000 gallons which would give an ample water supply and fire protection, which is not provided for at the present time and which you should certainly have. We would suggest that this tank be erected at about 110 to 115 ft. from bottom of tank to grade line. Such an installation could be erected at a cost of about Twelve Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($12,500) complete with conduits, discharge casing around supply, heating pipe and soil, foundation etc.

Our Provincial Government have adopted the outside water tower, as recommended above, for all of their Institutions outside the City.

Yours truly,

The Standard Heating & Plumbing Co., Ltd.

Dear Sir:

As an engineer in charge of this plant I find it my duty to
and without apology to condemn the water system absolutely, an
inadequate to do the work required of it. Having had considerable
experience I am fully acquainted with the situation here, and having
given the whole system a careful and thorough test find that the water
system is nothing but a sad failure. The water supply tanks are
of such small capacity that it is impossible to furnish water to
supply more than half our needs. To do this the pump is kept running
almost continuously. The pressure tanks are hoax in so far as
service is concerned, they simply cannot furnish the plant with the
necessary water supply. In case of fire no protection whatever would
be available with the present tank system. Toilets are completely
out of order and will require a thorough cleaning and overhauling
before they can function again. At present they all shut off. I can
see no remedy for our serious difficulty but large storage tanks where
large volumes can be drawn without imperilling the supply.

The hot water is another problem to be met. The present
jacket heater is much too small for general purposes being but a
regular household size only.

I trust you will give these matters your immediate
attention and that we will soon have the difficulty remedied.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

It is with regret that I must inform you that the water system of this plant is absolutely inadequate to do the work required. Briefly I make the following report after carefully and diligently giving it a fair trial. When full the water tanks carry a capacity of a little over 2000 gallons. Air and dead water take up about 2/5 of this space, leaving but a very small quantity of water to function. This makes it impossible to keep up constant and continuous pressure to supply all demands of the plant unless the pump is kept working constantly which is out of the question. Last week it was necessary to pump at least every hour of the day in order to supply water demanded, which resulted in muddy water being drawn from the well, an evidence of excessive pumping. Whereas large supply tanks would do away with the difficulty.

In consequence of this muddy water the toilets are now shut off and will require a thorough cleaning before proper working-order can result. Under present conditions, even if the pump were kept running at full speed no fire protection would be possible under the present system.

Again—After carefully trying out the jacket heater, I find that this is much too small to heat the water required for general purposes. A much larger heater will be necessary to supply hot water demands.

Trusting that you may give this your most careful attention at the earliest possible date;

I am Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Re: the present water system.

I regret to inform you that the water system as installed in this school has entirely failed to meet the requirements of the institution. At the time of the opening some one hundred and fifty persons were present including the parents of the children. Although every preparation for the event had been made the water system entirely failed to stand up to the needs. During the last two weeks with a normal attendance of some eighty-five people we are now without the use of the flush closets throughout the building. This is entirely due to the fact that the pressure system has been totally inadequate to operate the system. I would draw your attention to the fact that the toilets are dependent for their satisfactory operation on the constant pressure of the water. When this fails the closets fail to flush and there is not only a great waste of water, but also danger from disease and unsanitary conditions. For some time we did our best to operate these closets by turning them on and off by hand, but at last this proved such an intolerable task that they were finally shut off and used only with pails. It will be seen that in a new institution this is a very serious matter not only from the standpoint of health, but also endangering the life of the pupils as there is absolutely no fire protection from this source. The difficulty lies in the fact that the pressure tank system is inadequate, with our demand it is absolutely impossible to keep the pressure. To maintain our partial supply it has been necessary for the engines to pump from eight to twelve times a day. This without the laundry being in operation and without the use of the flush closets. A few gallons of drain takes the pressure off to such an extent that the whole system is rendered inoperative.

In order to relieve the situation for the time outside closets will be necessary.

I would suggest that in view of the uncertainty of this system we should have some kind of a gravity system installed. This seems to be the only method adequate to meet the situation.

I would also add that the water supply itself, that is the well, seems to be safe. In spite of the abnormal strain upon it the supply is keeping up and except for the temporary failing of the water there has been no indication that it is giving out. At present it is pumping at the rate of about 25 gal. a minute. I trust that it will be possible to have this system changed without delay.

Yours truly,

M.F. Woodsworth
Principal.

Dear Mr. Stewart -

As requested by you I visited the new school here yesterday, and I regret to say that conditions there are anything but satisfactory. The water system is utterly inadequate to supply the needs of the institution, and to use the words of Charles May, Sup't. of Construction, "It is no good and never will be", although it is constructed in accordance with specifications received from Ottawa.

I was not satisfied taking the word of Mr. May alone on this matter, and I called up Mr. Gould, a Master Plumber, who had charge of the installation of this system, and he was equally as emphatic as Mr. May, and said that the system would never work satisfactorily; that it was a poor one and did not meet the situation, and he feels quite satisfied that the whole plant will have to be changed.

At the time of my visit none of the lavatories were working on the top floor, simply because no pressure could not be put to that point, and when pressure of 65 lbs. is put on the tanks it goes down in no time. The Engineer in charge of the works - a competent man - tells me that he has to go from nine to eleven times a day to keep pressure in the tank, and even when he does this it is not satisfactory. There is also a tremendous waste of money there, not only in the new building but on the outbuildings. Over $10,000 has been spent on a well 175 ft. deep. The barn cost between fifteen and eighteen thousand dollars; four barns could be built for this money, of the same size. There is a building outside that is used as a garage and work shop combined. This cost thousands of dollars. There has been waste all along the line, and if this matter had been in the hands of business men, thousands of dollars would have been saved.

Dear Mr. Stewart:

With reference to the water situation at the Edmonton School, Mr. Paulin the plumbing expert has just returned after having spent four or five days at the Institution, and I am delighted to inform you that he has been able to at least find out what is wrong, and before leaving had the pressure system working fairly satisfactorily. But before it will be a complete job, some work will have to be done on the plant.

First of all, I may tell you that the two pressure tanks are not pressure tanks at all; they are hot water tanks with manholes, which should not have been supplied. Instead of being tapped for the supply in the bottom, as a regular pressure tank would be, they are tapped on the end and about eleven inches up. The result of this is that there are about 300 gallons of dead water in the bottom of the tank that is not used at all - might just as well have been so much lead; so this 300 gallons are to be taken off of the capacity of the tank, leaving about 900 gallons of actual space. Of this two thirds of the space would, under ordinary conditions, contain water and one third air. In addition to this Mr. Paulin discovered that both these tanks were water-logged; that is, they had too much water in them and not enough air. This is caused by there being no way to regulate the proper proportions of air and water in pumping. He procured a booster airpump, and had this installed, and the proper proportions will now pump into the tank. What will have to be done at once is to retap these pressure tanks at the bottom, close up the present opening, and tighten up the manholes in some way, as these allow a certain amount of air to escape.

Flushometer lavatories are used in this building, but in order to make the system satisfactory Mr. Paulin recommends that we use low-down tank lavatories. These can be attached to the present fixtures without any great trouble or expense. The present lavatories could be sold at almost as much as they cost, as they have not been used to any great extent. Mr. Paulin thinks that on the whole a system like this would be more satisfactory, owing to the irregular pressure that naturally takes place in a system of this kind, as when anything goes wrong...
there is a great waste of water. Of course Mr. Paulin makes it clear to me that the flushmeter is a good closet under other conditions, but in connection with this particular system, he thinks that it would warrant the department making this change.

Kindly advise me if I may have seventeen tank lavatories sent up, and also whether Mr. Paulin is to take a man from here to put the system in Al shape. You might advise me by wire.

I may assure you, in conclusion, that there is ample water at this Institution, the well was pumped for four and one-half hours, at the rate of 1200 gallons an hour. There was no noticeable depreciation in the water and it came out as clear as crystal. Another test was made for seven and one-half hours with the same result.

I may also add that the system could be made even more efficient if say a 5000 gallon storage tank were installed. This tank would be made of concrete and lined with asbestos. The pump could be worked to this tank and from this tank it could be drawn off with an automatic electric pump, which would always keep the pressure up to a certain point. Of course this would be an ideal system, and it would take probably $1000 to $1500 to do this. If you wish to put this in, so much the better; but the system we have there is precisely the same as that at U'Ansele, that is, the water is pumped direct from the lake to the pressure tank. If the Government cannot see their way at the present time to do this, it might be done later on. Mr. Paulin assures me, with the changes suggested above, the plant will operate satisfactorily.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Bro. Woodsworth:

Your night letter re-building site and telegram to Dr. Scott to hand just before I left Brandon. While I have acknowledged the same, this is a further reply.

About two months ago, I wrote you and pointed out that your primary duty was to locate the place and size of your boy's playground, assuring you when this was done it would be a very easy matter to select the site for your new building. Since then you have sent me a couple of sketches of your campus, showing the site you have selected for the building and giving your reasons for this selection; but you have not a sketch of any kind as to where you intend the boy's playground to be. Had you sent the plans for a playground, the whole matter could have been settled at once.

A short time ago Mr. Goodland sent me a friendly letter setting forth the advantages of the site of building, and a plea for me to endorse it. Since he did not deal with my objections, viz., that it was robbing the boy's playground of the west side. To his letter I replied, "that I could not consent to a building going up now, nor at any time in the future, that in any way would interfere with the most suitable site of a boy's playground." I also informed him that Mr. Banner and that I had reason to believe Dr. Manning was also opposed to the site chosen by Mr. Woodsworth for the building. Had you the contents of this letter when you wired Dr. Scott?

You assure Dr. Scott that the site you have selected has no relation to the boy's playground and does not encroach on it. Did you make this clear to Dr. Scott when he was with you, and also state it as emphatically as your telegram does? If not, why did you not state in your message that Mr. Ferrier was of the very opposite opinion and this was his chief objection to your selection? I enclose you a rough pencil sketch of the site of the playground and its proximity to the main building. Kindly place on this the position of the site you have chosen, giving the distance it is from the playground, and also from Mr. Goodland's present home, and the main building. This will be a very easy way to prove your statement and of showing me I am wrong. All I desire is to secure the most suitable playground for the boys for all time to come.

Why have you treated my request for a sketch showing your selections for a boy's playground—also my instructions as to where to build—in silence and lack of courtesy, and adopted a mode of procedure that is hardly in harmony with the policy our Church has pursued in doing business with the Indian Department.

Dear Brother Barrier;

I shall try another letter and sketch which is the same as the last two I sent you. However there may be more detail in this one. Kindly keep the different colored lines quite distinct.

The red lines now mark the bounds of the girls' and boys' playgrounds. The arrows on the boys' playground indicate that they can go as far as they wish north and east. This is where the boys have been playing for some time now, and we have found "no man's land," 50 yard wide, a very satisfactory barrier between the boys and the girls. One of our problems has been to keep the boys away from the chapel windows and the kitchen windows where the girls are. As it is, the boys' playground is just off the door yard between the school and the utility building.

Now kindly note the purple line. This is the playground which would exist according to your figures and distances. In your last letter your smallest distance West and East of main building which should be used as playground is 150 yards. Lair 750 ft. It is only 45 yards from the main school building across the lawn to Mr. Goodlands house. So your plan would cut the town in two, destroy all our roads, and make a mud hole of all that ground in front of the house. Besides having foot ball and other ball right in front of the house, and surely people have some rights of privacy even if they do happen to live at an Indian school. Moreover, all approaches to the utility building would be through the boys' play ground. Even if you do insist that the house be placed due north of Mr. Goodlands present house his front door would be within a few yards of the foot ball ground. I would like to draw your attention also to another rule you laid down in a former letter respecting play-grounds. You maintained that it should be at least 50 yards from any building. I cannot see where you are consistent. Again, six years ago when we were moving Mr. Goodlands house you insisted that it be removed from the exact spot where now you insist that I build this house. This was
boundary, you said, it was too near the barn farm. The spot I have chosen is farther from the barn and yet, what I consider, to be, within the residential district.

Kindly note what I have marked "Door Yard." This is exactly what it is. It is not a play ground as such. Of course I have no objection to the boys playing between the school and the utility building at odd moments and in what always be useless, but for organized play I cannot see its possibilities. The spaces are limited here. The coal is brought around here. The boys use this space for going and coming between barns and school. The entrance to the utility building occupies a good deal of room. I cannot see where you get a play ground out of it, unless you unite into one heterogeneous whole, playground, lanes, road-ways and four yards.

I do not think I can say very much more. If this does not appeal to you or Dr. Scott, I must of course obey departmental orders. I have tried to be absolutely fair in my presentation of the case and have given you my opinions and convictions very frankly. I feel that my close contact with actual conditions as they exist on the spot should count for something, as should also my experience. I have submitted the location to several men of judgment and they all agree with me. Dr. Scott was very definite when he was here. I shall now leave the matter in your hands to decide with Dr. Scott.

I remain

Very sincerely yours,

J. F. Woodworth
Ottawa, October 26, 1927.

Rev. T. Ferrier
McKellar General Hospital
Fort William Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith Inspector Hurison's report of an inspection made at the St. Albert and Edmonton Indian Residential Schools.

The report on St. Albert is very satisfactory. I would recommend that the Department meet the request of the Sisters at this institution that a grant be given the Callihoo girl so that she may attend Normal School in September. I believe this is a case where further education would be of benefit.

I am glad to note that decent mattresses have been supplied for the dormitories at the Edmonton School. I should be glad to see the straw-filled mattresses discarded at all schools where they are still in use.

I am not prepared to recommend that a second well be put down at this institution at the present time. There is more water in the existing well than can be used, and it seems to me that some means should be found by which this water could be pumped to different parts of the grounds. To sink another well would mean almost the same expense as was incurred in putting down the first one, and there is no necessity for this, in my opinion. The matter of saving money is not very much considered at this school.

You will-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

[Handwritten note:]
18/1925 (this was urgent)
You will note that the cold storage facilities at the Edmonton School are very poor, in fact they could not be much worse. I would again repeat that I think we should install a Frigidaire plant.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
I visited this school on February 7th, and made a general inspection of the buildings. I found the buildings and equipment in excellent condition. The main building was clean and tidy throughout. Since my last visit wool mattresses have been supplied for the dormitories, and they add materially to the appearance and comfort of the beds.

The fire fighting equipment was carefully examined and found to be in good condition. A soft water storage tank has been provided to supply the boilers with water, and has been a source of satisfaction.

The question of a second well, which was discussed some time ago, was mentioned to me, and I looked over the situation and find that if it is thought advisable to sink a second well, this could be put down in close proximity to the present well and the present pumphouse utilized for the second pumping unit. The discharge pipe from the
from the second unit could be connected with the present main water pipe to the school. The only building required would be a small lean-to over the well to the present pumphouse.

I found the hog pen in a damp condition owing to ice forming on the roof of the building. This condition is bad for the hogs, and it was noted that several were crippled with rheumatism. In order to avoid this condition, it will be necessary to have a ceiling put in to permit of an air space and proper ventilation.

I have already reported on the desire of the Principal to develop cattle and hog raising, and if they are to increase their effort in this direction, it will surely be necessary to provide more housing accommodation for the stock.

I would again point out that they have no storage facilities for meat, even in the winter time. I noted that their meat supply was kept in a small vestibule at a little used outside entrance to the building.

Their stock consisted, at the time of my visit, of 125 hogs, 34 cows, 7 calves, and 14 work horses. They sold 7 steers and 3 cows last fall for $937.00.

There were 207 pupils in residence at the time of my visit. They presented a clean and tidy appearance and there was very little sickness in the school. I consider this a very excellent institution, and am pleased to report that the Indians are looking upon it with increasing favour, as is indicated by the fact that practically every Protestant child of school age from the Saddle Lake Agency is in attendance, and when I subsequently visited the Saddle Lake Agency, I did not hear a complaint against this school and a number of the parents
parents of the children expressed their satisfaction in connection with it.

Mr. Woodsworth, the principal, is energetic, capable, and earnest in his efforts to promote the best interests of his school. Miss McDonald, the Matron, is a very capable woman and appears to co-operate in a harmonious manner with the principal. Care appears to be exercised in the selection of the staff at this school.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

REGINA, SASK., April 15th, 1930

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that I was at the Edmonton Indian Residential School on the 8th instant, and went into several matters that had been pending for some considerable time.

One of the matters discussed was an additional water supply. There is only one well here, which is the sole source of water supply for the school, and if something should happen, such as the rods breaking or becoming disconnected in the well it might be a matter of days before it could be fixed and the school would be without water in the meantime. In the event of anything like that happening the supplementary supply would be imperative, and for this reason I feel like recommending that a second well be sunk.

If water can be reached at about 140 feet, the cost for drilling and casing should not be more than between $600.00 and $800.00. A pump and engine would, of course, have to be supplied, and this might cost another $600.00. However, I do not see how we can get along without this additional well. At one time I did think that some other plan could be devised, but after visiting the school and looking carefully into the situation I am convinced that this is the only course to follow. The total cost should not exceed $1800.00.

Another matter-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Another matter that was brought to my attention was the necessity for lining the hog pen. This would take about 5000 ft. of lumber, which could possibly be delivered for $250.00. I would strongly recommend that it be allowed.

The need of a barn for young heifers and calves was also gone into. I am getting figures on this and they will be submitted to you. We have such buildings at other schools and I think one should be supplied here.

The matter of supplying a refrigerator has been brought to the attention of the Department before. This, of course, is absolutely necessary; it is just a question of what is the best type to install.

The Calgary Power Company's line passes by this institution and I do not think the Department should do anything about the lighting system until we can use this power.

A request was also made to have two carloads of sand sent there for use in the small children's playground. This might cost $200.00 or perhaps a little more, and I think it should be allowed.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Sir:

When I was at Edmonton a short time ago, I discussed with Mr. Woodsworth the question of supplying him with a rough shed for sheltering young cattle during the winter months, similar to sheds we have at other schools. He promised that he would submit a plan to me for this shed, and it was pretty well understood that it should be a simple type of building. I now get a plan for a most elaborate shed; in fact, it is not a shed, it is a barn showing subdivision, stalls, etc., for which the lumber alone will cost $1,297.90, to say nothing of the cost of construction. I am utterly opposed to spending $2,000.00, or anything like it, for a shed for the Edmonton School. We have erected one of the finest barns in Alberta there, and another good cattle barn last year, and he now wants me to erect a third. If the Department wish me to give him a cow shed, I will go ahead and undertake the work. When I was with Mr. Woodsworth, he never suggested anything like what he is now asking for. I find Mr. Woodsworth most extravagant in his ideas and unfair in his demands.

Kindly advise me what you wish me to do in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Mr. Graham's letter of the 2nd instant refers to a supplementary water supply at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. $4,000 is available this fiscal year for the purpose. You will note that Mr. Graham states there is no necessity for another well; but, if you refer to his 403-11 A of May 18, 1925, you will find that he wrote in part: "I wish to bring to your attention the inadequate water supply for fire protection at the Edmonton School. It seems to me we should sink another well so that in event of one giving out the other could be brought into action. I consider this a very important matter."

Attached hereto is the Dominion Water Power Engineer's report and estimate and also another communication of November 13, 1929, from Commissioner Graham.

Will you please bring the matter to the attention of Dr. Scott and, when the decision is reached, let me know if the funds are going to be used.

[Signature]

It should be forwarded as funds are low.

May 2, 1930.

Sir,

I beg to refer to your letter of the 20th of May last year, with reference to the water supply system at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Since your report was submitted some of the items included in your recommendation have been carried out but no action has yet been taken regarding the providing of an additional well. Funds are now available for this work, but if possible I should like to provide the water supply system required at a more reasonable cost, and I will be glad to receive a report from your Calgary office with any suggestions for the providing of more water for this school at a more reasonable cost than mentioned in your letter of May 20th last.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

F. MacKenzie,
Acting, Ass't Deputy and Secretary.

May 5, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 403-11A U. of the 15th ultimo, with reference to a supplementary water supply and other requirements at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. The Department has asked the Dominion Water Power Branch to report concerning a supplementary system. The earlier recommendation involved a large amount of money, and I am asking for an inexpensive scheme that would remedy the situation. Funds are available for the urgent improvement to the hogpen, at a cost of $250, and for two earloads of sand for the children's playground, and you may proceed with the work. Please see that no unnecessary expense is incurred.

I regret there are no funds at the present time for a second barn for young stock nor for a refrigerator at this school. A refrigerator, of course, would have to stand until we had power, and I shall be glad to know definitely concerning the location of the Calgary Power Company's line.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:-

On the 23rd ultimo I wrote you in regard to furnishing a cattle shed at the Edmonton Residential School. I have now received a modified proposal from the Principal, in which he states that, if he is furnished with $1,200.00, he can move and alter an old building which can be made suitable for the suggested purpose. I would recommend that this amount be allowed him, and I shall be glad to have the Department's sanction to make the expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 5th instant with reference to a supplementary water system and other requirements at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, and note that the Department has asked the Dominion Water Power Branch to report concerning a supplementary system. If when this report is received you find it rather an expensive proposition, I would suggest that you do not act on it, as from what I know of the Dominion Water Power Branch they have expensive ideas.

We could supply a well and pump for the amount stated in my letter of April 15th, namely $1800.00. When we drilled the existing well at the Edmonton School the drillers went several hundred feet beyond water, with the object of making more money, and the cost was very heavy.

I do not think the school will suffer very much from the lack of a cow barn this year, although they should at some time be supplied with a barn for the young stock. However, I wrote you further on the 3rd instant, pointing out that the Principal has reduced his estimate for this barn to $1200.00.

I am writing to the Principal regarding the improvement to the hogpen, and the supplying of sand for the playground, for which you say funds are available.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

With reference to your No. 110-0-5 of the 5th instant, I have received from Mr. Woodsworth particulars in regard to the cost of connecting the Edmonton school with the Calgary Power line. He informs me that the Calgary Power line will run about two miles distant from the school; that practically all charges will be absorbed in the regular monthly tariff which will be chargeable to the school, but that there will be probably about $100.00 cost in connection with switchboard changes and that they may require $100.00 deposit as a guarantee. He adds that the only other charges will be the motors required, which will cost about $200.00 a piece. At the present time I cannot see that more than two motors will be necessary. The initial cost therefore, of the change, based on the figures the Principal has supplied, will be approximately $600.00. Mr. Woodsworth states that the rates which were quoted to him will nearly cut their present cost in two, while giving them twice as much service.

I shall be glad to know if this expenditure will be sanctioned.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
May 28, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 403-11A U. of the 22nd instant, with reference to power which will be available in the near future for the Edmonton Indian Residential School. You may make arrangements, when timely, to connect up with the Calgary Power line. I note that the installation will cost approximately $200 and that two motors, at a cost of about $200 each, will be required. The present generating plant at Edmonton will be used at one of our other schools - instructions in relation thereto will be directed to you at a later date.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

The Secretary;

Dear Sir;

I enclose herewith the following Vouchers:

No. 456 in favor of Smith's Drug Store for $39.80.

I may say that the goods indicated here were ordered entirely by Doctor Williamson. Most of it in connection with his treatment of Syphilis cases. This before the supply sent from Ottawa.

No. 457 in favor of Johnston's Drug Stores for $13.25.

Some years ago we secured a very effective Prescription for Scabies from Dr. Holmes when he was medical officer. Since then we have been using this ointment whenever necessary. It costs $2.00 a pound.

No. 458 in favor of National Drug and Chemical Company Limited for $17.50. This is our quarterly drug account. Which I think is very low.

No. 459 in favor of The Edmonton Paint and Glass Co. Ltd. for $41.50. This account consists of a variety of material for repairing and freshening up the school and property. We have done the work with our own help. There was considerable repair work to be done after this year of having such a full school, and I wish to keep the plant in fairly good repair.

Under another cover I am sending forward the quarterly report for June 16th 1930. In the case of the two Brandon Boys who ran away on April 27th, I only counted their attendance to the date on which they left. The other cases are normal.

On July 15th I sent Elizabeth Cardinal to her father near Fort McMurray. I shall send the account later.

The Brandon Children were returned in safety to Brandon on July 9th. Every one was in good health according to the doctor's examination. I sent to Dr. Doyle a statement of their health and any recommendations by the doctor. We have had a good year with them and nothing to regret except the six boys who deserted. I trust the Department is satisfied with our treatment.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

J.J. [Last Name]

Dear Sir:

The Jacket Heater upon which we depend for our hot water has cracked badly, it is very badly corroded so that it has become practically worthless for heating. In order to repair it would cost at least $75.00 and then would be a questionable job. It has been in use constantly for five years. A new one will cost less than $100.00. I request permission from the Department to purchase a new heater. The old one is practically junk.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, September 25, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 19th instant, I have to inform you that the Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase and installation of a new jacket heater for use at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, to replace the present heater which has become practically useless. It is noted you estimate the cost of the new jacket heater to be approximately $100. After you have made the purchase, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

I enclose herewith specifications and a price on installing a Frigidaire plant in the school. On June 21st 1929, letter No.110-0-5 you wrote asking me to furnish information regarding cold storage facilities.

The enclosed plan will fit into a room just off the kitchen and by all means the most convenient place in the building. Along with Mr. Inspector Murison I considered an outside building, but this would mean considerable expenditure, including concrete and the extensive use of ice. The cost in putting up one like they have at St. Albert would be considerably more than the cost of this Frigidaire. This would be a walk-in cupboard and quite up to date. The recent installation of the Calgary Power has also made it possible to install this new system with economy.

I asked the company to include all costs in their price, such as a little brickwork and connections etc. If we can save anything we will of course do so.
