AGREEMENT made and entered into this 27th day of AUGUST.

A.D. 1930. BETWEEN:

CALGARY POWER COMPANY LIMITED, a body corporate with its head office at the City of Montreal in the Province of Quebec, (hereinafter called "the Power Company"),

OF THE FIRST PART,

AND

HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH, represented by the Minister of the Interior of Canada (Department of Indian Affairs) and represented herein by J. F. Woodsworth, the acting Principal of the "Indian Residential School" situate on the North East quarter of Section Eleven (11), Township Fifty-Four (54), Range Twenty-Five (25) West of the Fourth Meridian, (hereinafter called "the Customer")

OF THE SECOND PART.

WHEREAS the Power Company is a corporation duly incorporated under the laws of the Dominion of Canada and operates an hydro-electric power system in the Province of Alberta as a licensee of Dominion Water Powers by virtue of licenses granted to it by the Minister of the Interior of Canada pursuant to and subject to the provisions of the Dominion Water Power Act, being Chapter 210 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1927, and (or) The Dominion Lands Act and the Dominion Water Power Regulations passed by the Governor-General in Council under the authority of the said Acts;

AND WHEREAS the Power Company proposes to extend its
electrical transmission system so as to be in a position to supply the Customer with electrical power and energy as hereinafter provided.

AND WHEREAS the Customer is willing to purchase from the Power Company all the Customer's entire requirements of electrical power and energy for use in said Indian Residential School and all buildings connected, used or operated for the purposes of said School; said School and said buildings being hereinafter referred to as "said School premises";

NOW THEREFORE THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that the parties hereto covenant, promise and agree the one with the other as follows,-

1. COMMENCEMENT OF SUPPLY.
   The Power Company shall commence the supply of electrical energy and power hereunder to the Customer on or before the thirty-first day of October, A.D.1920.

2. TERM OF CONTRACT.
   This Contract shall remain in full force and effect for a period of five (5) years from the date of commencement of supply hereunder. The Customer shall from the date at which supply hereunder can be commenced purchase from the Power Company the Customer's entire requirements of electrical energy and power in said school premises during the life of this agreement. The Power Company shall, from the date at which it commences supply hereunder, sell and deliver to the Customer all
electrical energy and power required by it from time to time for use in said school premises, during the life of this Contract.

2. **VOLTAGE AND FREQUENCY**

The electrical energy and power to be supplied hereunder shall be furnished in the following manner:

(a) For power purposes in the form of three phase alternating current at a normal pressure of two hundred and twenty (220) volts; and

(b) For lighting and domestic purposes single phase three-wire service at a normal pressure of approximately 110 - 220 volts;

Provided always that said electrical energy and power to be supplied as aforesaid shall have a normal frequency of sixty (60) cycles per second, with a variation in the aforesaid respective voltages or generally not more than six (6) per cent above or below normal, and a variation in frequency of generally not more than one (1) per cent above or below normal.

4. **SERVICE**

The Power Company shall endeavour to maintain normal voltage and frequency and render service equal to that usually furnished by modern hydro-electric systems where conditions are similar, and the Customer shall use the electrical energy and power to be supplied hereunder only for the Customer's aforesaid purposes, and all apparatus and equipment shall be installed and maintained and said electrical energy and power shall be used by the Customer in such a manner as not to cause sudden fluctuations.
In the demand for the said energy and power such as would cause disturbance to the system of the Power Company.

5. CONTINUITY OF SERVICE.

The Power Company shall cause to be taken all usual precautions to guard against interruptions or diminutions in the supply of electrical energy and power to the Customer, and shall cause to be terminated such interruptions and diminutions with all possible despatch. If interruptions or diminutions are necessary or unavoidable for repair, overhauling or inspection of equipment or for improving or adding to its equipment the Power Company shall give the Customer reasonable notice of the same, if possible, and shall cause such interruptions or diminutions to be made at such time as to cause the minimum inconvenience and loss to the Customer.

6. RATES OR PRICES.

The maximum rates or prices which the Power Company shall charge the Customer for electrical energy and power during the term of this Agreement, shall be in accordance with the
following Schedule,-

COMMERCIAL RATES.

Available for all purposes where Power Rate does not apply.

Service charge of $1.40 per month for the first 500 watts of installed capacity and 40¢ per month for each additional 250 watts together with an energy charge on the following basis:

First 100 hours' use of Installed Capacity - 10¢ per K.W.H.
Next 100 hours' use of Installed capacity - 5¢ per K.W.H.
Over 200 hours' use of Installed capacity - 3 1/2¢ per K.W.H.

The Minimum monthly charge shall be no less than the Commercial Service charge during one month.

Prompt payment discount - 10 per cent on the even Dollars

POWER RATES

Summer and Winter Schedule.

Power Service, (alternating current) available for motors and commercial heating apparatus such as irons, coffee urns, hot water heaters and stoves.

SERVICE CHARGE - $1.00 per month per Kilovolt Ampere (K.V.A.)
of installation. (One motor horse power or one kilowatt in electric heating apparatus to be considered equivalent to 1 K.W.A.).

ENERGY CHARGE.

First 50 K.W.H. per month per K.W.A. of installation by per K.W.H.
Next 50 K.W.H. per month per K.W.A. of installation 3 1/3¢ per K.W.H.
Over 100 K.W.H. per month per K.W.A. of installation 1 2/3¢ per K.W.H.

Minimum charge shall not be less during any one month than the Service Charge applying to such Power Service.

Prompt Payment Discount - 10 per cent on the even dollars.

7. CARRYING CHARGE.

During each month of the term of this Agreement the Customer shall pay to the Power Company monthly in addition to the foregoing rates and charges, a sum computed on the basis of one (1) per cent per month of the cost for connecting the Power Company's main transmission line with said School premises, the cost of said connection not to exceed the sum of Thirty-six Hundred ($3600.00) Dollars.

8. METERING EQUIPMENT.

The electrical energy and power to be supplied by the Power Company to the Customer shall be measured by suitable recording meters to be supplied and installed by the Power Company on the low tension side of the Power Company's step-down transformers to be located at such a point on the premises of the Customer as may be mutually agreed upon; or, if the Power Company so desires, such transformers to be located at such a point on the
premises to the Customer, in which case the metering equipment shall be located and installed at a point on the Customer's premises to be mutually agreed upon, and for the purposes of this Agreement the metering equipment shall be deemed to be the point of delivery of electrical energy and power supplied hereunder to the Customer.

9. REPAIRS OF METERS.

The meters for the measurement of the electrical energy and power supplied hereunder shall at all times be kept in good working order, and shall be tested from time to time to determine their accuracy.

The Power Company shall notify the Customer whenever it intends to have the Customer's metering equipment tested so that the Customer may have a representative present at the test if the Customer so desire.

10. TESTING OF METERS.

If at any time the Customer is not satisfied as to the accuracy of its said metering equipment it may upon giving ten (10) days' notice to the Power Company have the said metering equipment tested or calibrated by a competent person delegated so to do by the Department of Trade and Commerce of the Dominion of Canada. If such test or calibration shows that such metering equipment is in error by more than two (2%) per cent then such metering equipment shall forthwith be corrected or replaced by one that is accurate. If the inaccuracy of the metering equipment as shown by such test demanded by the Customer is found to be such that
the quantity of power delivered as recorded by it is in error by more than two (2%) per cent then the Power Company shall bear the cost of the test. The bills for power supplied during the two calendar months preceding such tests shall be corrected in the proportion of the error of the metering equipment provided such error exceeds the aforementioned limit of two per cent (2%) and such correction shall be accepted by the Customer and the Power Company as settlement in full to that date of all claims on account of inaccuracy of metering equipment.

11. **WIRING.**

The Customer shall assume all obligations, risk and responsibility in connection with all wiring done or caused to be done by the Customer on said School premises from the point of delivery, including therein all wiring done by the Power Company on said school premises from the point of delivery at the request of or under Agreement with the Customer.

12. **PAYMENT OF ACCOUNTS.**

The Power Company shall render its account to the Customer in each calendar month for the electrical energy and power supplied during the previous month and the Customer agrees to make payment of the same within ten (10) days of the rendering of every such account; all payments to be made at the Edmonton Office of the Power Company.

The Power Company may, on giving five (5) days' written notice to the Customer, and without prejudice to any of its other legal remedies, cut off the supply of electrical energy and power to the Customer, in the event of any amount due for
Electrical energy and power under the provisions of this Agreement concerning the existence of which there is not bona fide dispute, remaining unpaid after the same shall have become due under this Agreement.

13. **RIGHT OF WAY.**

The Customer grants to the Power Company the right, license, liberty, privilege and easement at all times during the period of this Agreement to enter upon and build and maintain upon and over the Customer's property and premises, such metering equipment, transformer stations and transmission and distribution lines as may be required for the delivery and supply of the electrical power and energy herein provided for, the locations and routes however to be such as may be mutually agreed upon. At the termination of this Agreement the Power Company shall be allowed a reasonable time to remove its metering and transformer equipment and transmission and distribution systems from the premises of the Customer.

14. **ACT OF GOD, ETC.**

If at any time during the continuance of this Agreement the operation of the works of either of the parties hereto is suspended or curtailed owing to war, rebellion, Act of God, or other cause beyond the control of such party, the party whose operations are so suspended or curtailed shall not be liable to the other party under this Agreement until the cause of such suspension or curtailment has been removed. Provided that each of the parties hereto shall take all reasonable precautions and adopt all reasonable measures to prevent or remove the cause of
such suspension or curtailment.

15. **PROVIDED**, however, and it is understood between the parties hereto that the Power Company in order to be in a position to supply electric energy and power hereunder, will be called upon to build and extend its transmission system from a point on its present system near St. Albert, Alberta, to said school premises of the Customer, and that if for any reason the Power Company is prevented or hindered in the extension of its said electric transmission system by reason of weather conditions or other unforeseen cause, the date of the commencement of supply hereunder as provided in paragraph 1 hereof shall be extended accordingly.

16. **ASSIGNMENT.**

This Agreement and everything herein contained shall enure to the benefit of and be binding upon the parties hereto, their and each of their successors and assigns respectively.

Sir:-

I am enclosing herewith Voucher No. 476 in favour of the Electrical Engineers, Limited, of Edmonton, for $994.54, in connection with the installing of motors, lights, etc., at the Edmonton School, as authorized by Dept. letter 110-0-5 of the 23th May, 1930.

Mr. Woodsworth, Principal of the School, has exceeded his authority by nearly $400.00, and my opinion is that he could very well have taken the matter up with this office before spending this additional money.

He was asked in the first place for a full report covering what was actually needed, and he explains now that as the workmen proceeded they discovered extra work that would have to be done. This is probably true, but at the same time there are some things included in this account which were not absolutely necessary. He states that a new motor was put in for the cream separator. He should be written to and told that this installation should not have been made without the proper authority. He had lights installed in the pigpen. It was not necessary for him to do this until he had authority.

This is not the first time Mr. Woodsworth has exceeded his authority, in fact he generally does so, and then comes back with a letter of this kind. If we carried on all our business in this way we would be called upon to increase our appropriations at every turn. I think in future it would be well to have one of our officers go to the Edmonton School when there is work to be done, and outline same and close the contract.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, February 3, 1931.

Memorandum:

Mr. Paget.

Mr. Ferri.

I have noted the remarks written on Mr. Graham's letter of the 27th January with reference to Mr. Woodsworth's unauthorized expenditure at the school. Under the circumstances I do not think we should be asked to pay this and if he incurs unauthorized expenditures he should be prepared to charge it to his own revenue, which he should do in this case.

D.S.G.I.A.
Ottawa, February 3rd., 1931.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 27th ultimo, No. 403-11 A.U., enclosing voucher No. 476 in favor of the Electrical Engineers Ltd., of Edmonton, for $994.84, in connection with the installing of motor, light, etc., at the Edmonton Residential School, I am directed to state that, in view of the representations made in your letter, the Department does not think that we should be asked to pay the extra expenditure incurred by the Principal, which was not authorized, and he should therefore be prepared to pay these extras from his own revenue. The first item was authorized in the Department's letter of the 26th May last and will be paid when further funds become available, and an amended voucher covering that item only should be submitted later.

The Principal should also be informed that if he incurs unauthorized expenditure of this nature in future, he should be prepared to charge the same to the revenue of the institution. The voucher is herewith returned.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Indian Commissioner,

Dear Sir;

I enclose herewith Voucher 477 in favor of Marshall-Wells Alberta Company Limited for .

This voucher to be charged to my appropriation of $1200.00.

These accounts include practically all the hardware used in connection with the repairs to plant since last April. It of course includes the hardware used for our barns etc., such as nails, screws, bolts etc. The item of $25.56 covers the fixtures for the doors. There is, you will note, a number of plumbing items. We put a water line into the pig pen. Did all the work ourselves. All the items are for plant, and will I trust be found in order.

This is I think the last of the accounts involved in that appropriation of $1200.00. The following is a summary:

Moving old Barn .................. $86.00
Hayward Lumber Co. .............. 240.95
Northwest Lumber co. ............. 559.08
Edmonton Paint and Glass co.... 29.95
Marshall-Wells Alberta Co ....... 157.84

Total ................................ $1073.82
Unused Balance .................... $126.18

$1200.00

As indicated before considerable of this money has been used for other general purposes usually included under emergency so that in this appropriation I have not overstepped the mark. We have done all our own work and have made every item count. You will no doubt receive a report of our work from Mr. Murison.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Principal
Sir:-

I beg to forward Edmonton Residential School Voucher No. 477 for the sum of $157.84 in favor of Marshall-Wells Alberta Limited. I also enclose a copy of the Principal's covering letter, from which I gather that he received authority from the Department to expend the sum of $1200.00 on repairs etc., during the fiscal year. He refers to his appropriation of $1200.00 and it does not appear that I have any record of this on file. May I ask if there are many schools in the West submitting estimates direct to the Department independent of the estimates received from Indian Agents. It seems to me that some uniformity should be exercised with regard to estimated requirements of our residential schools.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, February 6, 1931.

Sir:

I have your 403-11 A.U. of the 30th ultimo, with reference to an account in connection with the Edmonton Indian Residential School. You did not enclose the voucher nor the copy of the Principal's letter. It is possible that he refers to the estimate of $1,200 for repairs during the year.

Certain prairie province Indian residential schools, that do not come under the jurisdiction of any particular Indian agent, submit requests from time to time, either through your office or direct to Ottawa. This group of schools comprises the following: Brandon, Elkhorn, Qu'Appelle, Edmonton and St. Albert. Of course, practically all Indian residential schools forward requests for estimates through their church authorities.

Principal Woodsworth has not received authority from the Department to expend any specified sum on repairs. I find that the only authority in this connection that was directed to him during the calendar year 1930 was permission to install a jacket heater, at an approximate cost of less than $100. This, of course, was an emergency. He has submitted a few small accounts for repairs to mechanical plant. Whenever funds can be found, the Department supplies at least the materials that are necessary to keep the government-owned buildings in repair. At other times, the principal is asked to meet the cost from school earnings.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter 110-0-5 of 6th instant informing me that Edmonton School voucher 477 and copy of the Principal's letter were not attached to my letter of 30th ultimo. In reply I beg to say they were sent out for mailing clipped or pinned to the letter and I shall be glad if you will cause search to be made in case they have been placed on the wrong desk. It is possible that they found their way into the wrong envelope but if so it is difficult to understand why the letter, which arrived safely, did not accompany them.

I will secure further copies from the Principal of the school.

I may say the $1200.00 appropriation referred to is the amount authorized for repairs to the Cow Barn.

Your obedient servant,

The fire hose and extinguishers were examined
and found in good condition. The building is provided
with pole as well as iron stairway fire escapes.
The Principal pointed out that the pole escapes from
the dormitories were too long an unbroken drop and in
practice serious injuries to the smaller children have
been averted only by a member of the staff catching
them as they came down the pole. This danger could
be overcome by placing a landing platform at the second
floor which would cut the length of the drop in half.
I would recommend that this be done.

It was also noted that there are no seating facilities
in the boys' playroom and they have been using the wash
stands to rest on. I would suggest that plank seats or
lockers be furnished for this room. A second bath is
also needed for the boys. Only the tub is required,
as there is a connection already in place and practically
no expense will be entailed in installing the second tub.

The pumping equipment is working satisfactorily
and there appears to be an inexhaustible supply of water
in the well. I mentioned in a former report that a second
well would be advisable to ensure a continuance of the
water supply in the event of the pump in the present well
going out of business as it did at one time leaving the
institution without water for several days. I am still

Sir,-

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection in connection with the proposal to improve the water supply of the Edmonton Indian Residential School near St. Albert, Alberta.

Date of inspection: June 27, 1930

Since I reported on this water supply on May 10, 1929, several improvements have been made. In the first place an underground rain water tank has been constructed of about 9,000 gals. capacity. Water is drawn from this by means of a steam ejector to supply the small service tank from which the boilers draw their supply by their own injectors; provision is also made for heating the tank by means of a jet of steam; last winter, the rain water supply being insufficient, snow was shovelled into the tank and melted by this jet. This work appears to have been very economically carried out.

The power head or pump jack which was condemned in my last report has been replaced by a new Myers self oiling power head; repairs have also been made to the drop pipe and pump rods in the well which makes them more accessible.

Additional hydrants have been provided in the building.

It has been proposed, and I understand sanctioned, to bring power in from the Calgary Power Company's line which I believe is about 1½ miles away at present. I have not concerned myself with the details of this, but assume for this report that three phase, 60 cycle, 110-120 volt electricity will be available.

I further understand that the purchase of a 7½ h.p. motor to replace the gasoline engine driving the pump jack has been sanctioned.

The proposed improvements outlined by Mr. Woodsworth are briefly as follows:

1. To drill a new well about 20 feet from the existing well in a position where he feels sure of tapping the same supply at a depth of 165 or 175 feet; the power head at this well to be worked from the same motor as the existing well by means of a line of shafting.
2. To put in two additional 1000-gallon pressure tanks in line with the existing two and a small one at the pump house to supply the stock watering troughs.

If we accept the general principle of these improvements I should modify them slightly. The location of the new well is chosen because Mr. Woodsworth feels certain that it is possible to get water there from the same source as the existing well. This is quite true, but I think that if a new well is drilled it is worth while attempting to strike an independent source of supply. Last year there seemed to be good reasons for putting the new well near the boiler house and I think these reasons still hold. I consider that an expenditure up to $400 would be justified in trying out another site before returning to the locality of the original well.

In any case I should prefer the pumping machinery on the new well to be entirely separate unit. This need not entail increased expenditure as a 12" strike power head with air compressor attachment coupled to a 5 h.p. motor with automatic starter equipment can be purchased for less than the price of the power head on the existing well and will be quite sufficient to supply the school. The provision of an automatic starter will ensure the pressure tanks being reasonably full at all times instead of practically empty as they must be in the mornings at present.

The proposed small pressure tank in the pump house can be almost automatically eliminated. A check-valve will be needed above each well to prevent one pumping into the other; at present there is a check-valve at the pressure tanks in the boiler house which prevents back pressure on the well. If this be removed to just above the well the farm trough can be fed from the pressure tanks.

The cost of this installation will be as follows:

Allowance for trial well (may not be needed) $400
Cost of well 175 feet deep with 5 5/8 casing 4" drop pipe, brass cylinder and cypress rods. $1000
Myers 12" stroke self oiling working head with 5 h.p. 3 phase motor, air compressor and automatic starter. 420
Two 1000-gal. pressure tanks each $500 1000
Valves and piping 80
Housing pump, motor and pressure tanks 400
Contingencies 300

$3600

If a well of good quality and quantity be obtained and this machinery be installed, the school will have a first class water supply for domestic purposes.

I do not feel that the same can be said about fire protection. The two existing pressure tanks and the two new ones will have a total capacity of 4000 gallons but when deduction is made for air space, and the probability of them being partially empty, about 2000 gallons is the
most that can be relied on in case of fire. This might give about twenty minutes supply at two nozzles, in which time the two pumps would supply about 400 gallons additional.

There is the rain-water tank with a capacity of about 9000 gallons; it had to be filled with snow last winter, and is almost empty at present. The water in it is there to be used and is only replaced when rainfall occurs. In the circumstances I do not consider that any expenditure on pumping machinery to make it available in case of fire would be justified. If water is in this tank when the fire brigade arrives from Edmonton it will be available for them to use.

Although the main shell of the building is of brick and hollow tile construction this quantity of water appears to be a somewhat meagre provision. If development is to be along the lines set out above further pressure tank storage can be provided at 80¢ to $1.00 per gallon of water actually available for fighting fire up to the limit that the Department is able to spend.

On the other hand a 20,000-gallon elevated tank 100 feet high (the building is about 50 feet) would cost in the neighbourhood of $8,000 and could be kept practically full so that water would be available at about 40¢ per gallon.

By the method outlined in my report last year some 20,000 gallons exclusive of rainfall would be available for fire fighting purposes at a cost on an equivalent basis of between $5000 and $6000 or about 20¢ per gallon. This system suffered from the disadvantage that it would be necessary to start up an engine if a fire should occur.

As regards the pressure, the pressure-tanks would give the best pressure at first, while the pump method would give more than the elevated tank, but the last mentioned method would be the least liable to break down.

It is very difficult to decide upon a recommendation without some knowledge of how much the Department is prepared to spend and unwise to make partial expenditures which do not form part of a co-ordinated whole.

If the Department is only prepared to spend some $3000 or $4000 then the scheme set forth seems to be the best, but if the amount they have available exceeds $6,000 and particularly if it amounts to $6,000 I should recommend that it be spent upon storage and fire fighting equipment rather than well drilling.

The existing well is an excellent well; its quality is fair although it contains some soda which makes it unpalatable after storage. In quantity it is quite adequate. It is said to have yielded 40 gallons per minute on test without lowering. When I was there last week the pump was only making 18 strokes per minute or about 10 gallons. Even on a laundry day it would apparently not run more than half time so that there is a large reserve supply.
The case for an additional well is based upon the possibility of a break-down. This might happen through the failure of the engine or motor drive or of the power head or of something going wrong in the well itself such as a break of the rods or the drop pipe. I am also informed that sand is coming slowly into the well and that at some date it will require cleaning out.

The repairs to the well have removed most of the dangers of a break-down there and the existing gasoline engine might serve as a stand-by to the motor already sanctioned, so that the case for an additional well does not seem so strong as it was a year ago.

If storage is provided the objection to using the stored water for drinking purposes could be overcome by bye-passing it and using directly from the existing system; while the taste might be endured for the time when repairs are being made.

I am not prepared to say that a second well will not be required at some date but my own opinion is that with adequate storage it can be indefinitely delayed.

My report of last year included a considerable amount for piping separate firelines to the hydrants and for other fire fighting equipment, which may be eliminated if it is not considered desirable to spend so much money. It would also appear that by helping the contractor with labour and cartage Mr. Woodsworth can carry out concrete and building work at a cheaper rate than a direct contract can be let at.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) F. R. Burfield
Sir:

I am attaching for your information two copies of Mr. F. R. Burfield's report dealing with his inspection in connection with the proposal to improve the water supply at the Indian Residential School near St. Paul, Alberta.

From Mr. Burfield's report you will note that he is not altogether in favor of drilling a second well in the vicinity of the present one but prefers to drill at another site first and so have an entirely independent source of supply. On this point I quite agree with Mr. Burfield, should it be found necessary at any time to put down another well.

It is pointed out in the report that it is exceedingly difficult to arrive at any conclusion until we are advised what funds can be made available for improving the water supply conditions at this site. It would seem that by the construction of an elevated tank of some twenty thousand gallon capacity, one hundred feet high, adequate fire protection would be ensured and no doubt the present supply would be sufficient to take care of this reserve. If, on the other hand, sufficient funds are not available for this expenditure—which Mr. Burfield has estimated at approximately eight thousand dollars, the other minor changes which he has suggested in the earlier part of his report would seem the most desirable.

We are of the opinion that under existing conditions there is not adequate provision for fire fighting. If a fire occurred, especially in winter, it could be handled more expeditiously with an automatic pumping system. Also, an elevated storage tank affords greater security than any other kind.

Another matter:- The Department authorized last year the expenditure of $1200.00 for a new pig or cattle barn. I sent in vouchers for only $1073.82 leaving an unused balance of $126.18. In these vouchers I included many items usually sent into the Department as emergency, such as plumbing, etc. I also
Drew a small load of lumber for the Lister people for crating the two engines sent to Saskatchewan. We used all our own labor and I did my best to save the Department in every way. Would it be in order to request that this unused $126.82 be applied on this electric account. $400.00 is a lot of money to take out of per capita for capital expenditure. I do not mind paying some for taking a little independent action, but another $400.00 on the top of assuming the main construction charge is rather heavy. I know that I have done this more than once, but I have always asked for inspection and my action has always been approved.

I trust this letter has not been too long or too detailed, but I feel that I have much to justify any initiative in the matter. I may add that at this time we had dozens of children sick in bed with measles and flu and were without lights, so I was anxious for the work to be completed. I trust that you will forward this letter, or a copy to Ottawa with this further information.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

I believe you have a copy of the complete account.

Ottawa, June 10, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th ultimo, enclosing copy of a communication which you forwarded to Mr. Commissioner Graham, Regina, in reference to settlement in full of the account of Electrical Engineers Limited covering the cost of work carried out by them at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the full amount the Department was able to provide in settlement of this account was $596.45. Our appropriation has been considerably reduced for the current year, and I regret that it will not be possible to pay the balance of the account rendered by the above firm. We will be unable to apply the unexpended amount in the erection of the cattle barn towards payment of the expenditure incurred in the work carried out by Electrical Engineers Limited, as all our accounts for the last fiscal year have now been closed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Principal.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that on my recent visit to the Edmonton Residential School I was surprised to see that the roof of this building is in bad shape and will require considerable repairing and painting at once. A large number of the asbestos slate shingles have blown off and will need replacing. Upon examination it will no doubt be found that others are in bad shape. The ridge board has blown off and will have to be replaced. The woodwork around the windows and doors outside will certainly have to be painted next spring and an amount should be put in the school estimates to provide for this. In my opinion this work cannot remain over for another year.

Reverend Woodsworth, the Principal, has an idea that we should extend the fire escape nearer to the ground or build some kind of platform for landing purposes. I question whether this should be done. I think that if a fire took place some person could catch the children as they come down. However, I would like to have your opinion on this.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,

The Secretary;
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ctawa.

Dear Sir;

In reply to your letter of Oct. 1st 1931 No. 110-0-5 and also that of Nov. 12th, I may say that I have at last some information regarding the repairs to the roof of this building.

As far as I can learn there is no agent here for the asbestos slate shingles which were put on this building in the first place. Then it will be necessary to send to Winnipeg to get any shingles of this type. Yesterday I had an agent of this shingle firm out to the school to look into the needs of the case. The shingles which were put on were of the lightest nature and evidently were put on very carelessly. About 120 feet of the ridge shingles are off. Have from time to time been blown off by the wind, and several dozen of the flat roof shingles, also some of the flashing. The ridge shingles will cost about $60.00, the other shingles $23.50 for the six pieces, and the flashing and other material say $16.50, making a total for material of about $100.00. The labor may be estimated at about $50.00, and roof work is not very easy. This is just an estimate, but I think it is fairly close.

Yours Truly:

J. F. Woodworth
Principal.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the materials required in repairing the roof of the building at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

After the repairs have been completed, please forward your account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the materials and for the labour employed.

REGINA, SASK., 28th October, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to advise the Department that when the Edmonton Residential School was furnished a power bread mixer was supplied and has never been used. Mr. Woodsworth informed me when I was making an inspection of the school that, if this bread mixer could be used at any other point, he would be glad to turn it over. Recently the Reverend Henry Ellis, Principal of the C. of E. Indian Residential School at Onion Lake requested me to take up the matter of getting a bread mixer for him. I informed him regarding the one at Edmonton and at the same time wrote to the Reverend Mr. Woodsworth. I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Woodsworth stating that he would very gladly turn over the bread mixer to Mr. Ellis if he had proper authority.

I would recommend that the authority be granted to make this transfer with the understanding that Mr. Ellis pay the transfer charges. I would be glad to have the Department's decision at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

W. Morrison,
Inspector,

Ottawa, November 3, 1932.

Sir:

I have your 309-11A C.E. of the 25th ultimo, regarding a power bread mixer surplus to requirements at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, and recommending that this machine be transferred for use at the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department understands this machine is of 2 bbl. capacity, and it is thought it would be too large for the requirements at the Onion Lake C.E. School. You might state if the Onion Lake School has sufficient power to operate the bread mixer and also if you consider it would not be too large for practical use at this school.

Your obedient servant,

NOV 12 1932

W. REGINA, SASK., 24th November, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 110-0-5, dated the 2nd instant, with reference to transferring the bread mixer from the Edmonton Indian Residential School to the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School. I may say that I have examined this mixer and am satisfied that the Onion Lake School has sufficient power to operate this bread mixer. It is not necessary to operate the machine at its full capacity, and, in view of the fact that this bread mixer has never been used and has been lying idle at the Edmonton School, if the Principal of the Onion Lake School wants it and is willing to pay the transportation charges, I cannot see that there should be any serious objection to letting him have it. The Principal understands that, if supplied with this machine, its possession must not in any way interfere with teaching the Indian girls the art of bread making by hand.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary;

Dear Sir;

I enclose herewith Voucher 762 in favor of The Edmonton Paint and Glass Company Limited for $50.97.

It is about a year now since I presented a voucher from this firm for necessary paint and repair about the institution. We have white-washed the dormitories, painted and whitewashed the hospital wards, patched the walls where the plaster has broken away and in other ways tried to keep the place in repair.

I trust the account will receive the favorable consideration of the Department.

Yours truly,

J.F. Woodsworth
Principal.
Ottawa, June 14, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing a voucher in favour of the Edmonton Paint and Glass Company, Limited, to the amount of $50.97, for materials supplied for use in connection with repairs, etc., at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to inform you that the total amount provided in our Estimates for the current fiscal year for all purposes at your school is $300. Our Appropriation was so greatly reduced, that this was the full amount allowed. The Department is paying the voucher which you submitted. This will therefore leave the sum of approximately $250 available for the balance of the current fiscal year. You may incur expenditure, from time to time, up to that amount. I may say, however; it is considered that quite a number of the items on the accounts which you submitted are a fair charge against the school funds and should be paid, in future, from per capita allowance or other receipts of the school. It is necessary, this year, that you use every endeavour to keep all expenditures within the amount appropriated, as any expense over that amount will have to be met from school receipts.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, B.A.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alta.

June 19th 1933.

The Secretary;
Department of Indian Affairs,
Lttawa.

Dear Sir;

I received today your letter of 14th inst. No. II0-0-5 in reference to the voucher in favor of the Edmonton Paint and Glass Co. I may say that the total account sent us by this firm for repairs was nearly twice the voucher sent to you, and if there were a few items which might have been charged to my school account it was more than made up of the accounts for repair which I have paid.

I note your reference to the balance of $250.00 still remaining to my credit for expenditure outside the per capita grant. As a matter of information: Does this amount include the grants usually made by the Department for advanced education and transportation? Or are these over and above this $250.00. If I am confined to this amount I shall have to curtail my advanced education next year.

I presume this amount does not touch medical services.

If possible I would like to have this information before holidays, as a number of things hinge on it.

Yours Truly:

J.F. Woodsworth
Principal.
Ottawa, June 26, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the amount provided in our Estimates for the current fiscal year for the Edmonton Indian Residential School. I regret that our letter of the 14th instant regarding this amount is not quite clear. The sum of $300 is all that is provided for repairs, replacement to equipment and general expenditure.

Regarding the advanced educational grant, the Department will decide this matter when we have a list from you of the pupils who will be taking courses in higher education during the next academic year.

The total amount that can be allowed your school for transportation expenses this year is $200. This includes expenses for children going on holidays, for new pupils entering the school and for pupils who are being discharged at the end of the current academic year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Reverend Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 9th instant, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of a new hot water jacket heater, at a cost of approximately $100.00, for use at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. The cost of same is to be included in the appropriation allowed you for repairs and equipment, as mentioned in official letter dated June 14th, last. As stated in that letter, the sum of $300 is all that is available for all purposes at your school this present fiscal year. After the purchase of the heater has been made, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

I have also the account which you forwarded, in favour of the Drew Machine Company, for $45.00, covering the cost of welding casting for large mangle. This account is being paid and charged to the appropriation mentioned above. You will observe that, after paying this account and the cost of the jacket heater and including the account in favour of the Edmonton Paint and Glass Company, Limited, for $50.97, there will be only the sum of approximately $105 available from the appropriation provided for your school.

Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

I herewith request permission to purchase lumber, sand, and lime to the amount of about $50.00. This is required for general repair work. We need gates, repair to brick work, certain board protectors for windows and other necessary repair jobs. At present we have not a stick of lumber on the place.

I would also like permission to purchase fencing and screening for windows and hardware to the extent of $25.00.

Both these items to be charged to my appropriation. I may say that the heater will not cost more than about $75.00, so there is still a margin available for school purposes.

See your letter of October 17th 1933., No. II0-0-5.

Yours Truly,

J.F. Woodsworth.
Principal.
Ottawa, November 22, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 13th instant, I have to say that you may incur an expenditure of approximately $50.00 in the purchase of lumber, sand, and lime, for general repair work at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. The cost of the above supplies is to be included in the appropriation allowed you for repairs and equipment, as mentioned in official letter dated June 14th, last.

After the purchase of these materials has been made, please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

The Secretary;

Dear Sir;

I enclose herewith Voucher 782 in favor of Alberta Concrete Works for $38.15.

As noted this is for the repair of the Septic Tank. It seems that about every year the outlet gets clogged up, and as it is no fit job for the boys of the school I send for proper help from town. It appears that the gravel gets clogged with the solid material and has to be cleared away. The siphon is not working properly, and it would be quite an expensive job to put it right, so this cleaning out once a year or so is perhaps the best way. In the meanwhile, there is sufficient gravel and purifying process not to cause any danger to health.

I saved $25.00 on my tank heater, so there will be sufficient out of my appropriation to meet this account.

Yours Truly,

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that I forwarded a report of inspection on the Edmonton Indian Residential School recently, but in doing so I omitted to state that the school was very much in need of cold storage facilities. At the present time they only have an ordinary refrigerator and they informed me that it was very difficult in the summer months to keep the food properly. Dear Sir;

For some years past the Department has allowed me a sum of money, usually $300.00, for repairs and construction. Two years ago I spent it, largely upon the rebuilding of the pig pen. Last year the $300.00 went in part payment of a Frigidaire. This year I wish to rebuild our silo. I may say that this structure has entirely gone to pieces. It is about ten years old, and the timbers have rotted away, so we have torn it down as it was unsafe. The material in a very moderate new structure will cost over $300.00, we are prepared to pay labor costs, besides considerable other repair. I would be glad if the Department would authorize at least $300.00 for this work.

Dear Sir;

I have to report that last week one of the pipes in the water main leading from the pump to the school sprung a leak. Of course immediate action was necessary. A trench twenty five long and eight or ten feet deep in the frozen ground had to be dug. This was of course no job for boys and I had the work done by men accustomed to that kind of labor. Our own engineer looked after the mechanical work. We had to purchase a new length of pipe and have it cut etc. The repair work is finished satisfactorily, and the trench being filled up. For over a day we were without water, but we managed to get along. This is the first time in nearly 14 years since the water main has been put in, that it has caused us trouble.

I trust that I may send the necessary accounts to the Department.

Dear Sir;

The main water supply pipe from the well to the main building is giving us a great deal of trouble. During the last year and a half there have been some eight breaks which have required digging and repairing, usually at a cost of some $10.00 a break. Recently the breaks have been more frequent. Last week a break and again this morning. It is now about 15 years since this pipe was installed with the opening of the school, and the constant vibration has worn the joints and by friction has caused holes in the pipe where a little pebble has been in contact. Evidently this whole main line requires to be renewed. It is about 300 feet from the pump house to the main building. It will cost between six and seven hundred dollars to dig this and replace the pipe and make adjustments. The repairs which we have made have been for the most part temporary, the leaks being held with clamps.

I request authority to have this work done during the holidays. I mentioned the matter to Mr. Schmidt when he was here last week. No doubt he will make a report on it.

Yours Truly,

J.F. Woodsworth

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with reference to the water supply pipe from the well to the main building of the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

I note that you estimate the cost of replacing this pipe and making the necessary adjustments at between $600.00 and $700.00. In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was found possible to include an amount of $300.00 only for repairs, improvements and any new equipment that might be necessary at the Edmonton Residential School. The present set up of our appropriation makes it impossible for us to expend a larger amount than is specifically provided. Under these circumstances you will note that we only have $300.00 available.

We have no objection to using this amount to cover part of the cost of repairing the water supply pipe provided the balance could be met from school funds.

If you wish us to use our share for the purchase of the new pipe that is required you should let me have full particulars in order that the matter may be placed before our Purchasing Branch. The new purchasing regulations require that all articles for which we are supplying the funds shall be purchased by our Purchasing Agent.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Voucher 946 in favor of Harold N. Woodsworth for $65.00 for digging drain in connection with our water supply as per correspondence.

Harold is my eldest son attending University. He was home a few days before sessions started when the matter of this work came up. He offered to do the work as cheaply as anyone else, being anxious to earn a little money for his course. Being harvest time it was very difficult to get help and so I decided to let him go ahead.

Earlier in the year when I first wrote to you I had secured a price from Cris Skove who had done considerable work for us in digging drains and cleaning our septic tank at times. For the 300 feet which we originally intended to dig he gave us a price of $117.00, which even at that time of year was considered very reasonable. I have put in an account for Harold of $65.00 which is considerably less than that figure. We decided that 200 feet was sufficient, so you will note that the charge is reasonable. I trust this acct. is satisfactory.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir;

I believe that for repairs to plant I have still about $100.00 left for the fiscal year ending March 31st 1939. See your letter of June 17th 1938, No. II-0-5. There was a sum of $300.00 available for repairs to plant. Of this amount, $134.30 went to Marshall-Wells for pipe for drain. See my voucher of Nov. 23rd 1938. Then $65.00 was expended for labor in digging drain.

It is now 15 years since this school was opened and naturally repairs are beginning to be necessary. For some time we have been repairing toilets and bowls, but during the coming year replacements will be necessary, also plumbing of various kinds. Also four lengths of fire hose is practically useless. I would like permission to spend $100.00 on repairs as indicated in enclosed quotations. These quotations have been obtained without committing the Dept. in any way and are for your information, and will perhaps expedite matters.

Metals Limited appear to have the lowest figures.

I may say that for next year extensive repairs will be necessary on our low pressure heating boilers. The tubes of these are about gone. And it will require more than $300.00 to put them in shape.

I trust these matters will receive your favorable consideration.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir;

Some time ago I mentioned the matter of the retubing of the low pressure heating boilers which I estimated would cost something over $400.00. Since then the boiler inspector has been around (August 31st) and has recommended that our High Pressure boiler be retubed as soon as possible. This recommendation will of course take precedence over the needs of the heating boilers which our engineer thinks may stand over for another year. The retubing of the High Pressure boiler will cost approximately $200.00 counting both labor and material. We will also require gauges costing about $15.00. I would request authority to have this retubing with gauges attended to as soon as possible.

About a year ago the Secretary will recall I had about 200 feet of the main pipe of our water supply replaced at a total cost, counting labor, of something like $200.00. See my Vouchers Nos. 945 and 946. I left 100 feet, which up to that time had not given us any particular trouble, thinking that it might not be necessary to replace this length of pipe. However this spring several leaks broke out and I decided to replace this portion of the pipe. I bought the pipe at Marshall-Wells where the former order had been placed. See Voucher 945 and had the work done. I absorbed all labor so that my only request for this job is material—amounting with credit to $95.85.

Dear Sir;

I am enclosing invoice from the J. H. Ashdown Hardware Co. Ltd., for $266.70. This is for repairs to our pump jack, which were absolutely necessary in order that the pump should not entirely give out. On the advice of my engineer I sent away for these repairs and the work was done during the holidays. I may say that the pump was installed a good many years ago and has given us very little trouble. However, the engineer stated that various parts were wearing down very seriously owing to vibration and general wear and tear and unless something was done immediately, it would probably involve a great deal of expense and trouble. I therefore thought it best to order the parts and have the work done.

I may say that the operation cost us considerably more than this invoice. We absorbed the matter of the labor and a great many small items for minor parts purchased locally. However, all of the parts mentioned on this invoice had to be ordered from the United States and this invoice is the only one I am asking the Department to meet as part of maintenance of permanent plant. It has been the custom of the Department to allow me some $300.00 for repairs each year and this is the only repair bill, I believe, that has been sent in this year.

I trust the Department will be able to meet the bill. I am only sending along one copy of the account so that you will be able to see what it is and if acceptable, I shall have copies made out in triplicate and properly certified to.

I have not presented this account before on account of pressure of business but I trust that as it will be in before the end of the Government fiscal year, you will be able to deal with the matter satisfactorily.

Yours very truly,

JFW/R

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of Feb. 11th, 1942, file No. 110-0-05, in connection with Inspector Scott's report re lighting and ventilation of a school room.

I may say that one particular room is referred to in this report. The room has had this condition ever since the opening of the school some 18 years ago. It is quite true that both the lighting and the ventilation are very poor but they are exactly as laid out by the Department in building the school. The classroom is situated in the school so that only one side is open to daylight and that is the West side. There are four windows lighting the room. In comparison with modern classrooms, this is decidedly antiquated. There are four electric bulb outlets in the room and it may be that the only solution would be to turn 100 watt lamps in these but it would be rather expensive. On the other hand, while the Inspector's report may be correct, I do not think the criticism is very serious, and after a little personal investigation, I find that most of the children can see fairly well. However, the lighting is poor.

The ventilation is very decidedly bad. This room is ventilated, as are our other classrooms, by means of a flue through which pass heated steam pipes. This may work fairly well in extremely cold weather when the pipes do heat the flues but in ordinary weather there is little draft in these flues, and for a classroom there seems to be very little movement of air around these ventilators. The only way we can ventilate this room is to open the doors and windows but you will realize that during cold weather it is not desirable to have the children exposed to drafts of cold air.

Since receipt of your letter, I have arranged that during recess and noon hour, the doors and windows of this room be opened to allow as much fresh air as possible to get in this room.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I have another account which I would like to submit to the Department for payment.

Some time before Christmas the steel tank which was connected with the jacket heater giving us our hot water system, gave out so completely that it was necessary to get a new tank. The old tank had been in operation for a good many years and had been springing leaks in many places from time to time but the engineer had managed to patch it up, until the final break which necessitated a new tank.

This tank is about the same size as the last and we had a good deal of difficulty in getting one at all under wartime conditions.

You will recognize that this is part of the permanent equipment to the plant and I would be glad if the Department would give this account favorable consideration. I am enclosing the account merely as a sample - the price is way down for a tank of this description, being made by this firm especially, as we could not secure a tank through the regular wholesale houses for anything like this price.

I quite realize that the funds of the department are limited in regard to special grants and for this reason I am sending you no account for travel as has been sent you for many years. If the department can favorably consider this account it will be quite satisfactory in regard to other grants which have usually been made.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of June 7th No. II0-0-5 in reference to the leaky roof as reported by Mr. Morris. I presume Mr. Morris had in mind the condition of the walls in various parts of the building which were in bad condition owing to the seepage of water through the brick work, which is destroying the plaster and brickwork.

I may say that this is due to a structural defect in the construction of the building. The gutters under the eaves are placed too close to the bricks, then when the snow and severe frost comes it bursts the metal gutters at the seams and the water comes through the walls with the above result.

This condition has existed since the school was built 20 years ago. I am quite sure that the matter has been brought to the attention of inspectors and agents from time to time, but it is possible that I have not made any direct report to Ottawa. However we have plastered and repaired the walls from time to time ourselves and kept things looking fairly decent. However the condition has now got beyond us and requires extensive alterations. It is no use re-plastering without reconstruction of the entire gutter and eaves system. There are about 600 feet of eaves and this will require a considerable outlay, possibly running into several thousand dollars. Owing to the nature of the repair and the extent of the work I would suggest that the Department authorize me to secure the services of a competent contractor who would be able to give a more exact figure and also supply the Department with a more detailed description of the work to be done. At present I can only guess at the required outlay, but Mr. Lobb, the engineer, thinks the job would run perhaps to three or four thousand dollars. There is a small job on the roof where the asbestos shingles have blown off, and also the steeple which is poorly constructed and which lets in the rain. This might be repaired for $150 or $200. (present costs).

I may say that if serious structural losses are to be avoided the sooner this work is done, the better. This rain water is beginning to seriously eat into the brickwork of parts of the school.

If the Department would like further information regarding this matter I shall be glad to furnish further details, but for the present I think this letter covers the general outline of required repairs.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir:

Some ten days ago we drew the sucker rods of our deep well in order to replace the valves and washers on the plunger. It is some three years since the sucker rods have been up and the flow of water indicated that these repairs were necessary. Some months before this we had ordered these repairs through Gorman's Limited, but as they had to come from the States it was only a couple of weeks ago that the repairs came to hand. The first operation was quite simple and the well was once more in operation. For a day it worked satisfactorily and then quite suddenly the water supply dwindled off once more. Upon pulling the sucker rods the second time we found that they were alright. It then became necessary to pull the well casing. We found the thread of the bottom link practically eaten away by chemical action and by vibration. It became necessary to entirely replace the whole one hundred and twenty-five feet (125 feet) of the four inch (4") galvanized pump casing. This casing is over twenty years old and an engineer was very emphatic that it would be very unwise to put any of this casing down again. He had for his reason our former experience with the piping from the well to the pressure tanks where a first break was followed at all seasons of the year by numerous other breaks. And in view of the costly nature of the well we felt that we could not take any such risk.

We were able to secure after a good deal of difficulty a sufficient supply of this galvanized casing to make a completely new and satisfactory pump outfit, and this was put down in the well.

We expected that the operation would be completed yesterday afternoon, but when within ten feet of the bottom we found that the sucker rods stuck some place in the casing. After numerous efforts we were forced to give up for the time being.

Memorandum:

Re: Repairs to Edmonton Indian Residential School, Alberta.

We are now in receipt of a report prepared by Mr. A.R. McDougall of our Banff office, after his inspection of roof conditions at the above. The report has been analyzed by our Architect and comment is furnished for your information as follows:

The building erected over twenty years ago has never had any major repair work, and is now badly in need of extensive roof repairs, repairs to interior plaster work and to a lesser degree, repairs to exterior brickwork.

While a concealed eavestrough built into the cornice is considered to be the source of most of the trouble, the asbestos shingles have become loosened, and sections of the ridge roll are missing. Nearly all metal flashing needs repair or replacement, and the louver openings in the cupola are so built as to admit water to the roof space.

The concealed eavestrough has proven unsuitable for buildings subject to heavy snow and severe frost conditions. It is placed behind the top members of the cornice, above the face brick in the wall, and due to continual expansion and contraction from freezing and thawing of ice retained in the trough during the winter, the joints in the metal lining have been forced open. As a consequence the brick and tile walls have become saturated, the wooden members of the cornice are rotted and plaster on the inside as well as brickwork on the exterior face of the walls has suffered considerable damage.

To overcome the existing condition, it will be necessary to remove the concealed trough and rebuild the cornice. Extension members should be spliced to the rafters and the cornice should be rebuilt to provide additional projection for an exposed eavestrough. While Mr. McDougall does not refer to them, the attached photographs show that only portions of the rainwater conduits remain in position. These conduits appear originally to have spilled rainwater on the ground against the building. They should be replaced, and should be furnished with bams to divert roof water away from foundation walls.

Mr. McDougall has obtained an estimate from the Poole Construction Co. of Edmonton covering various items as follows:

(a) Renewing cornice, and installing 4" eavestrough........................................$4900.
(b) Repairs to roof shingles, flashings and louvers in cupola.................................304.
(c) Repairing plasterwork..........................250.
(d) Painting cornice, all exterior sash, frames and doors.................................945.
(e) Repairs to front steps.........................25.

Total........................................$6424.

Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Survey and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Mr. McDougall's report makes no reference to the need for painting exterior sash, frames and doors, nor to the repairs to front steps included in the Poole estimate. Further the Poole estimate shows no specific cost for repairs to brickwork or renewing rain water leaders. Mr. McDougall states that a large proportion of the estimated cost of renewing the cornice would be for the erection of scaffolding. The attached photographs show deteriorated paint work and it is felt considerable economy would be effected if all work could be carried out while the scaffolding was in place.

To cover items described as necessary but for which no estimate has been furnished, as well as to provide funds for engineer's expenses, it is considered likely that a total expenditure of about $7,000 would be required.

Mr. Walker and Mr. McDougall recommend that the repairs should be undertaken as soon as possible, and we concur in their recommendation.

While at the Edmonton school, our officer noted several other items which should be pointed out to the Indian Affairs Branch. These are as follows:

1 - The brick walls supporting the heating boilers are crumbling and should be repaired.

2 - A large flatware ironer in the laundry, which has been welded after having been in a fire some years ago, is allowing the escape of steam during operation. It appears advisable to obtain cylinder replacements for the machine.

3 - Most of the fire escapes at the school, as shown in the photographs, are equipped with poles instead of steps below the top fire escape balconies.

Mr. McDougall reports that some of the smaller Indian children cannot use this method of escape. Consideration should be given to providing the usual steel stairs and rails for all such units.

Since we have only been furnished with the one set of photographs attached, and as Mr. Walker states they were taken on a privately owned camera it would be appreciated if you would return the prints when they have served your purpose.

Encls. 3

Chief Engineer.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Further to our report of July 26th describing the immediately necessary repairs to eliminate the infiltration of water into the above building, a general examination of the school reveals the necessity of further repairs and replacements to the building and equipment, to which the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch should be directed. In particular, the following items are noted:

**SEPTIC TANK**
A large proportion of the shingles of the pitched roof have been removed by pupils, exposing the sheeting and allowing water to enter the tank. The sheeting will doubtless deteriorate unless recovered.

**REAR DOORS**
The double exterior panelled doors to both boys' and girls' entrances at the rear of the building have been damaged by pupils kicking mud from their boots. Although repaired roughly by planks, the doors are ineffective in keeping out the weather.

**IRON STAIRS**
The iron staircases throughout the building have corroded in places. This is particularly true of the flight from the basement to the ground floor where the stairs are rusted away for several inches at the junction of the risers and treads, and badly pitted where treads abut the stringers. The mastic material of the treads has broken away. It is considered that the deterioration of material of this flight constitutes a possible hazard to the safety of the pupils.

**ROOF, BOYS ENTRANCE**
The galvanized iron roof leaks, allowing water to enter the passage.

**CEILINGS**
The ceilings of ground floor classrooms are stained and some patches of plaster have deteriorated, due to overflowing of dormitory toilets on the floor above.

**ATTIC DORMITORIES**
The plaster walls where the heads of beds are placed is broken along the entire length of wall, and the destruction of plaster is likely to continue unless a dado rail is placed here.

**BASEMENT PIPES**
The galvanized iron cold water pipes are corroded, containing an Alkali deposit which has caused deterioration, and leaks are being continually repaired.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
LAUNDRY

The flatwear ironer is being used with difficulty; steam escaping from the heaters. It is considered not possible to make further repairs.

BOILER BASE

The face of the brick base has crumbled along all four sides.

BOILERS

The school engineer reports that the tubes of one Low Pressure Boiler will soon be beyond repair. The insulation to these boilers is broken in many places. The vertical tubes of the High Pressure Boiler require constant attention and the engineer stated they are not likely to last much longer.

The water for the heating system is obtained from a large concrete storage tank, to which rain water leaders from the roof are connected.

BASMENT TOILETS

Two toilets have loose soil connections and are movable from the floor. These and other toilets have loose and damaged floor fastenings. The metal partitions have rusted and their connections have broken away from the floor. Only the wall attachments hold them in place.

BASMENT FLOORS

The basement floors are of rough concrete, and not mastic as shown on original plans. They are difficult to clean and to keep in a sanitary condition.

BASMENT WALLS

The exterior cement finish at top of these walls has broken away in many places, exposing the concrete aggregate to the weather, and possibly is permitting the absorption of moisture into the exterior of the walls.

FIRE ESCAPES

The fire escapes have landings provided with poles to the ground, and are not practical for younger pupils. In this connection, it may be noted that in order to keep the older boys and girls within the dormitories during the evenings, locks have had to be attached to each of the doors and windows leading to fire escapes.

STORM SASH AND SCREENS

Due to lack of help during the war, the storm sash have been allowed to remain in place during the summer and only where rooms are occupied have screens been used. The storm sash and screens are badly in need of paint.

REAR ENTRANCE

The approach to the rear entrances becomes very muddy in the spring and fall and is the cause of much mud being carried into the building. The Principal would like to see these rear areas paved. The soil is clay and is of gumbo consistency when wet.

POTABLE WATER

The water supply, except for the boilers, is from a 160 feet deep well with a 4" pipe and 6" casing.

The water contains sodium carbonate in solution and is of a chalky colour when it comes from the faucets. When allowed to settle, a small amount of soda settles to the bottom of the receptacle, leaving the water clear. The taste is not unpleasant. The Principal states the water has a slight laxative effect.
Minor repair work is carried out by the school staff. In one case noted, however, a structural change was made which might have had serious consequences, and it is strongly recommended that such alterations be referred to this Service. The alteration in question involved the cutting of an opening through the 17" wall between the kitchen and bakery rooms, and a piece of structural steel was employed to support the brickwork above, which is now resting on the third course of the door frame. The wall in question is a bearing wall, and the first course of brick above the door frame is loose; but it is felt that the arching action of the upper brickwork has prevented any serious consequences.

No estimate of the cost of carrying out this work would be possible without further examination and investigation.

The items noted herein, are presented for the information of the Indian Affairs Branch in determining any action they may decide to take.

Chief Engineer.

With reference to your letter of September 15th, addressed to Mr. Woodworth, copy of which was sent to me, I beg to state that I went out to the school yesterday afternoon and checked over the different items referred to in the report with Mr. Woodworth & the school engineer.

In this letter I will only deal with the items which I consider are most important, which should be given immediate attention. The other items will be dealt with in a later report.

1. Septic Tank

As reported, the shingles of the roof have practically all disappeared, but I do not think these were removed by the pupils. The shingle nails have all rotted through & the wind just wires the shingles off at will. While I was there I saw several of the remaining shingles disappear in this way.

I would suggest that for the present, the sheathing of the roof be covered with two thicknesses of tarpaper, secured in place by lathes, then in the spring the roof could either be shingled with good shingles which are impossible to obtain now, or another layer of shiplap could be put on over the tarpaper & tarred. I think this would make the most satisfactory job.

However, outside of putting on the tarpaper, none of this work can be undertaken now, on account of the condition of the septic tank itself, which has not been cleaned out for several years — is filled right up with solids — though it may be providing drainage, I am satisfied it is not functioning as a septic tank.

When inspecting the tank, I noted that quite a number of the rafters had sagged away from the sheathing, caused by the rotting of the nails — it will not be possible to do anything towards remedying this condition until the tank has been cleaned out.

I understand the cleaning of this tank has cost $75.00 on previous occasions, but I very much doubt if it can be done for that now and I would suggest that a sum of $100 be set aside for this so that Mr. Woodworth be authorized to have the work done. The tarpaper & lath nails will cost about $18.00 & I have told Mr. Woodworth to purchase this & get it on, before the snow comes.

2. Basement Toilets.

I checked on the toilets throughout the building & for the most part they are not in very good shape. It will be necessary to install six new bowls — in one, the base is also broken & will have to be replaced. Three new cisterns
will also be required to replace three that are so badly
damaged that they are of no further use.

With regard to the metal partitions, I would suggest
that where the floor connections have rusted off, pieces
be welded on to these uprights & the uprights reset in the
concrete floor. To do this it would be necessary to bring
a welder out to the school, but this would be better than
dismantling the partitions & taking the uprights to Edmonton.

The material necessary could all be get ready & the
welding itself would not take long.

The installing of the toilet bowls & cisterns could
all be done by the school engineer, but it is just possible
that he might require a little help with the base of the one
toilet.

The cost of the different items mentioned above would
be as follows:

| Item                          | Cost |
|-------------------------------|------|
| Toilet Bowls                  | $6.00|
| 3 Flush Cisterns              | $1.00|
| Welding partitions & material (est) | $20.00|
| Fittings for toilets (agt)    | $10.00|
| Work on toilet base & material (est) | $20.00|
| Unforeseen                    | $5.00|

Total: $75.00

I would recommend that this work be done immediately
and although there are no bowls or cisterns in stock in
Edmonton at present, a shipment is expected about next
Thursday & in order that we may be in on these, an order
has been placed for the number required, but if there are
any objections to this, the order can be cancelled without
any trouble, as there is a long waiting list for such
fixtures.

J.T. Faunt,
Indian Agent.

When out at the Edmonton School yesterday, I noted that a start had not yet been made on the repairs to the roof, walls &c., and as the season is getting late & there is considerable mortar & brick work to be done, I think it time that the contractors get going.

It is true that they have had a certain amount of material on the ground since the beginning of the month, but that is not helping the building any, and I had thought you might possibly jack them up a little.

I asked Mr. Woodsworth if he had a copy of the contract, as I wanted to see exactly what work was covered, but he said he hadn't a copy.

Could he be furnished with a copy, in order that he or the school engineer, who is quite a capable mechanic, could check on the work being done to see that it conforms with the terms of the contract.

I myself would also like to know what is covered by the contract, in order that I may make recommendations regarding certain other repairs & improvements which are not included in the contract.

Now that the outside shell of the building is going to be put in shape, I think now would be the time to consider the putting of the interior in shape also, if not this year, then next.

I think it is shameful how the various buildings in connection with this institution have been allowed to
Deteriorate, for the lack of the expenditure of a few dollars at the time it was noted these repairs were necessary.

I might say that sections of the brick veneer on most all of the farm buildings on the Farm Instructor's house are falling away & steps should be taken immediately to tie these back into place, but I am going out there next Wednesday to make a thorough check on what requires to be done and will make you a report.

J. A. Faint,
Indian Agent.
