Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Edmonton Residential School
(Your File 110-0-5 D.I.A.)

I have your letter of August 30th, enclosing copy of report from Mr. Gooderham, your Inspector.

I note that certain questions are asked. I must therefore place before you our views regarding the operation of residential schools—which are based on an agreement relating to the maintenance and management of Indian Boarding Schools, issued in 1911, and which, to the best of my knowledge, has not been changed in any principle. I have no doubt that you will find in the original files that the Methodist Church entered into this agreement.

Without going into too many details, this agreement or contract is that the Church will support, maintain and educate, in a manner satisfactory to the Superintendent General, a certain number of Indian pupils. The conditions are as follows:

(1) Re Admission: This has not much bearing on the problem which we have to face.

(2) The Church agrees to provide at the school teachers and officers qualified to give the pupils religious instruction at the proper times; to instruct the male pupils in gardening, farming, the care of stock, etc.; to instruct the female pupils in cooking, laundry work, etc.; and, generally, to give a proper education to these children.

(3) To supply the pupils of the said School with suitable and sufficient clothing, subsistence, lodging accommodation; and also to supply the said School with mechanical tools, seeds, and all other articles and equipment necessary.

(4) To keep the pupils clean and free from vermin.
(5) It is also provided that the Superintendent General and any person or persons named by him shall have the right to inspect the School.

The Superintendent General, on the other hand, covenants:

(1) To pay to the Church at a certain rate per annum for every pupil, and so on.

(2) To provide the pupils with medicines, school books, etc.

(3) To maintain the buildings at the School, when they are the property of the Government, in good condition and repair, and to provide proper sanitation and sanitary appliances.

That, in general, is my understanding of the contract, and from that I come to the conclusion that if the Church cannot do these things on the amount which is paid it we have to foot the bill. If, on the other hand, by reason of circumstances, there is some slight profit, that belongs to the Church and to no one else. You can understand that if we enter into a contract with the Department to educate children for a certain sum and lose money, and then if the Government says that if we have a slight surplus it belongs to them, the whole business will have to be revised; and I for one would most cheerfully hand over to the Government the financial responsibility for running these Schools.

I hope that the Church will present to the Committee its views on the responsibility of the Government for Indian Education. I am only mentioning the conditions as they are in the contract in so far as they refer to the Edmonton School.

From Inspector Gooderham's report, it would appear that the children have not received the care which the Agent at Hobema and the parents of the Saddle Lake Agency think should be theirs. I can only say in answer to this that, if there are any complaints about any School, I think they should be handled through the proper channels, namely, the Agent, the Inspector and the Church; and until we have a report that the conditions in a School are not satisfactory, we must assume that neither the Agent nor the Inspector has any complaint.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I am sending forward herewith copy of an air mail letter dated August 28, 1946, received by me from Inspector Gooderham.

It is unnecessary to state that the reports recently received by this branch from Inspector Gooderham and Doctor Stone with respect to conditions at the Edmonton school have been to me and to the officials here rather disturbing. The general impression in the department up until now was that the Edmonton school was one of our most up-to-date buildings and one of the most efficiently operated institutions of its kind in the Dominion. It is just possible that Doctor Woodsworth's health in recent years has not enabled him to keep a close grip on the administration of the school. Other school principals have found it necessary to appeal to us from time to time for discarded military clothing and have had this clothing remodelled for distribution to the pupils.

If, on the other hand, by reason of circumstances, there is some slight profit, that belongs to the Church and to no one else. You can understand that if we enter into a contract with the Department to educate children for a certain sum and lose money, and then if the Government says that if we have a slight surplus it belongs to them, the whole business will have to be revised; and I for one would most cheerfully hand over to the Government the financial responsibility for running these Schools.

June 20, 1946
At the request of Mr. Indian Agent Faunt I went with him yesterday to help survey the Edmonton School. You are aware that the present Principal is retiring, to be replaced by Rev. E.J. Staley. Plastering and some other repairs have apparently been authorized and are being done.

The whole building, with the exception of the Chapel, needs re-decorating but this is not a health matter except perhaps on the basis of morale of the pupils and staff.

The following repair will have to be made at once and before the school re-opens:

Replacement of a length of sewer pipe leading from a toilet on the second floor, west end, down through the floor and into a standing sewer which descends through the southwest class room. There is a place in this pipe about 1" X 6" corroded completely through. Mr. Lobb, the school Engineer, has repaired it with putty, etc., but it is now beyond repair. The operation will be difficult and possibly expensive as the connection leads over the top of a steel beam. I suggested that a new route be followed. Mr. Lobb knows the details.

In addition to the above I recommend strongly the installation of one bath tub and two shower heads in the boys' basement wash place. There is only one tub and one shower now, and the school population is likely to increase this year. Present facilities are inadequate.

I was told that the Principal or Indian Agent has authority for the purchase of about 12 new toilet bowls and tanks, but that they are hard to get. Every tank in the school is corroded past safe use and many of the toilet bowls are broken and patched. Anything that could be done to hasten
the getting of these fixtures should be done. The wash basins in the basement wash places are very badly chipped and eaten away by the sodium charged water available at the school. They are perhaps only moderately insanitary, but they are discreditable looking to say the least. It is suggested that replacement be deferred until they can be replaced by a stainless steel trough about 12 feet long with hot and cold taps above so that the pupils can wash in running water, directly from those taps and not in the trough or in wash basins. Taps of small calibre or small delivery could be installed to conserve water. Washing in basins is not a clean process at any time. The taps, of course, would have to be of the mixing kind.

Stainless steel is recommended as the only material I know of which will resist corrosion by the kind of water available at this and probably other western schools. The water at this school has attacked even the clay of which the present enamelled basins are made.

The drinking water installations are not very satisfactory in the basement play rooms. Drinking fountains of the gush type were originally installed but were unpopular and hard to keep in working order. Not one, in fact is working now. I am not sure that a common tap turned sidewise can be improved upon, but it should have some sort of guard to prevent contact with the mouth, and should be fed by a pipe which will not be heated by nearness to some warm object. This paragraph is of general application. Drinking facilities are important at any school. No new ones are immediately suggested at the school in question.

The whole institution shows the effect of lack of maintenance during the war. It is in fact badly run down. Considering this, it is clean from a soap and water point of view.

The immediate action recommended in this report is authority for repair of the sewer pipe, but it is intended to re-inforce other recommendations which will be submitted by the Indian Agent or Principal.

Dear Mr. Gooderham:

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Your report on the above school has just been brought to my attention.

It is unnecessary to state that the condition of the school is to be somewhat disturbing. It was my impression that the Principal at Edmonton had ample funds at all times to keep the Institution in a good state of repair. Why he did not do so is exceedingly difficult to understand. The condition of this school, now brought to our attention, emphasizes again the urgent need for proper and thorough inspection of Indian residential schools by our Indian Agents and by our Provincial Inspectors. In making this statement, I have not in mind the academic work carried on in such schools, but rather the condition of the buildings, including the farm buildings, and particularly the sanitary condition of the dormitories and lavatories. Unless we can make up our minds to do this in the future, the whole residential school system is apt to become completely discredited in the minds of the public.

I have been in touch with the Reverend Doctor Dorsey by long distance telephone this morning and we are convinced that it would be a mistake to postpone the opening of the school until October 1st. Such a postponement would involve family allowance payments and a number of other such matters that should be avoided, unless the obstacles confronting the Principal are simply insurmountable. Would it be possible for the Principal to open early in September, even though the enrolment might be comparatively low? Should

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Your letter dated the 24th was received yesterday. I had only then returned from the official opening of the Charles Cassell Hospital and the installation of Mr. Robertson as Clerk-in-charge, Edmonton Agency.

This school was inspected on the 23rd and over the weekend I had advised the Regional Director of Family Allowances, the Agents at Hobbema, Saddle Lake, and Edmonton that it was not likely to be open for pupils in September.

Mr. Staley was immediately contacted at Morley, and in the afternoon we got together to discuss the whole situation.

I had found the interior of the building in very great need of painting, repairs to plaster, as well as some plumbing and heating repairs. Mr. Staley had an Edmonton painter give figures on the decorating, and as it totaled over $6,000.00, I arranged to meet him, when a price by the yard was secured. Repair to a plumbing fixture and soil pipe is necessary in one dormitory before it is occupied but the building, otherwise, can be fully occupied now. I would, however, advise against this.

Mr. Staley is still at Morley but hopes to get to Edmonton when relieved; possibly next week. He states that he found no clothing and very little bedding in store at this school and has purchased over $6,000.00 worth for delivery about the middle of September, at the earliest. The mattresses are old and filthy and generally the dormitory equipment is in poor condition.

In this connection, it is to be reported that pupils returned home from the school with itch; this was reported to me by the Agent at Hobbema and by parents in the Saddle Lake Agency recently; the latter adding that their children were lousy. The school may not be responsible but bedding and mattresses should be thoroughly examined before used again.

Parents do not want to send their children back to this school as it is today; of this, I am quite certain. I suggest that cleaning up and redecorating be done before they are asked to do so.

(over)
...are asked to do so.

This will be costly; much of the work should have been done from year to year, and Dr. Woodsworth now admits it. Agent Faunt brought it to the attention of the Branch in 1945, but there is nothing in the Estimates, but a memo; Apparently Mr. Woodsworth carried on independently.

He stated to me that he never asked for a money expenditure outside of the per capita grant, either from the Board of Home Missions or this Department; he financed from revenue created at the school.

This brings up another point. From the Auditor's report of 1945, it is noted that Mr. Woodsworth holds Victory Bonds in the amount of $14,700.00 plus whatever funds remain in the Current banking account. To whom does this money belong? If it represents school funds could not part be used in redecorating and purchase of supplies and equipment? I believe it is very important to know what will be done with the Bonds, and I know Mr. Staley wishes to be advised.

The postponement will not seriously affect Family Allowance payments; they will be continued to the parents from lists forwarded by the Agents to the Regional Director in September. Such arrangements had been made for all children in the Province where school facilities are not available. I also believe that we will be less open to criticism from the delay in opening than we will be if the school is opened in its present condition. In all this, Mr. Staley concurs.

Under separate cover are submitted the estimated costs for painting the interior of the school and the assistant Principal's house, with some explanations.

He states that he found no clothing and very little bedding in store at this school and he has purchased over $6,000.00 worth for delivery about the middle of September, at the earliest. The mattresses are old and filthy and generally the dormitory equipment is in poor condition.

In this connection, it is to be reported that pupils returned home from the school with lice; this was reported to me by the Agent at Hobbema and by parents in the Saddle Lake Agency recently; the latter adding that their children were lousy. The school may not be responsible but bedding and mattresses should be thoroughly examined before used again.

Parents do not want to send their children back to this school as it is today; of this, I am quite certain. I suggest that cleaning up and redecorating be done before they are asked to do so.

This will be costly; much of the work should have been done from year to year, and Dr. Woodsworth must admit it. Agent Grant brought it to the attention of the Branch in 1948, but there is nothing in the Estimates but a memo. Apparently Mr. Woodsworth carried on independently.

He stated to me that he never asked for a money expenditure outside of the per capita grant, either from the Board or Home Missions or the Department; he financed from revenue created at the school.

This brings up another point. From the Auditor's report of 1949, it is not clear that Mr. Woodsworth holds Victory Bonds in the amount of $18,700.00 plus whatever funds remain in the Current banking account. To whom does this money belong? If it represents school funds could not purchase new furnishings and purchase of supplies and equipment? I believe it is very important to know what will be done with the funds and I know Mr. Staley wishes...
The postponement will not materially affect
family allowance payments; they will be continued to the parents from
lists forwarded by the Agents to the Regional Director in September. Such
arrangements had been made for the children in the Province where school
facilities are not available. I also believe that we will be less open to
criticism from the delay in opening than we will be if the school is opened
in its present condition. In all this, Mr. Stanley concurs.

costs for painting the interior of the school and the assistant Principal's
house, with some explanations.

Acting upon the request that an inspection be carried out at the school, I visited the premises, inspected the plumbing installations and fixtures, and also the sleeping accommodations.

For various reasons, many of the plumbing fixtures have become unfit for use. I noted that a battery of eight wash basins in the boy's wash room was in a badly cracked and decrepit condition. Therefore, cleansing of the basins could not be satisfactorily carried out. If I may venture an opinion, I should say the condition of the basins was caused more by abuse than by actual wear and tear. However, be that as it may, the wash basins are of no further use as such.

There were also two toilet fixtures and flush tanks in the boy's section (basement floor) in bad condition and should be replaced. In this section also, I noted one shower, whereas provision in the layout of the piping was made for three showers. Two are missing for reasons unknown to myself, but I see no reason why all these should not be made usable.

On the second floor there are two toilets with flush boxes that need replacing and also one on the ground floor.

On the girl's side of the building, there are five toilets with flush tanks in bad repair in the top floor dormitory, second floor dormitory and smaller girl's dormitory, respectively.

In addition to those already mentioned, I would recommend that the two tub baths be made available at the institution at the beginning of the school sessions.

In the infirmary portion of the building, two new toilets should be provided.

I carried out an inspection of the mattresses used in the dormitories and noted many of them in such a condition as to be unfit for further use, in fact those inspected represented a good percentage of the total number of beds available, which would indicate that a complete set of new mattresses was needed. The felt content used for the building up of the mattresses had become lumpy and must be uncomfortable for the user. In many instances the felt was falling out by reason of the outer material being badly worn and torn.

I might add that the cause of so many flush toilets being in bad condition is by reason of their being lined with copper which together with steel causes electrolysis with resultant rusting and pitting of the metal. I should recommend that all such copper lined tanks be replaced with either porcelain or plastic tanks with preference for the porcelain.

I noted one instance where a 4" water pipe was pitted and leaking, and which understood was to be replaced immediately.

SEPTIC TANK SYSTEM. The tank, which I was told, was a combined septic tank and filter bed, was found to be out of commission as such. The cement tank was full and the contents flowing through the emergency pipes without being subjected to any treatment whatever. In other words the tank was only doing the duty of a cesspool with the added danger of the sewage matter flowing out in the same condition as it entered the tank.

I would recommend that the tank be thoroughly cleaned out and converted into a septic tank with the filter with the filter media removed, as I believe the media is the chief cause of the plugging of the discharge pipes. The syphon for the purpose of discharging effluent from the second chamber should also be put in working order.

J. Hutterfield
Provincial Sanitary Inspector.

Calgary, October 2nd, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Further to our report of the 28th August, and departmental telegram of the 6th September, this is to report that an intensive inspection was made of this school on the 30th September.

The Principal had exceeded the authorized expenditure:

(a) Renovating.— The basement - boy's and girls' play-rooms, wash-rooms and the pupils' dining-rooms had been completely re-decorated; and the stairways leading to the basement; a small room on the ground floor, which was in very bad shape, and is designated as the boys' reading room, had also been re-decorated; and on the first floor, two girls' and two boys' dormitories had been done -- at an approximate total cost of $1,500.00.

It must be said that all this work was very badly needed.

(b) Boilers.— The boiler inspector had gone over the heating plant, and one of the boilers proved dangerous under pressure, and permission was not granted to use it unless it were re-tubed, and fittings that had burst or were pitted, replaced; fortunately tubes, which are very scarce, were located and this boiler put into working order at a cost of approximately $500.00.

(c) Plumbing.— Necessary plumbing fixtures -- repairs and replacements -- totalled approximately another $500.00.

The grand total expended will be approximately $2,500.00. Mr. Staley explained, that so far as the plant repairs and replacements were concerned, he had no other alternative but to proceed as ordered; in this it is agreed.

With regard to the renovation, nothing was found to have been done which could very well have been left undone, and still expect the Indians to have the regard for the institution that it is hoped to get.

The above is not all: With knowledge of the past spread of skin disease at this school, the Principal had an inspection made by the Provincial Sanitary Officer; this gentleman's report is attached hereto. Enclosed also is a letter from Dr. E.L. Stone, who made an inspection of the septic system in company with the writer. From these reports it is clearly seen that something has to be done to make this institution more sanitary before the pupils get settled therein:

1. — The bathing facilities are inadequate, and to complete same, two (2) bath-tubs must be purchased, at an estimated cost of $200.00.
2.- Eight (8) toilet bowls and tanks are required, at an approximate cost of $400.00.

3.- The Septic Tank must be cleaned, and then put in running order. Though we are not familiar with this type of plant, it is thought the total cost cannot be very great, if the plant is working at all; it will be mostly labor.

4.- Repairs to a utility building which is allocated for vocational training, will total around $500.00. There are 24 broken windows which must be repaired and replaced.

The total cost of the above, for which immediate authority is asked, should not exceed $1,000.00.

Further, it is to be reported that the contract placed by Mr. C.R. Gorrie of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, in 1946, was not completed, and it was only during my inspection that the flat roofs over the kitchen were being done; these roofs had been so bad, that water poured into the kitchen during every rain storm. This is mentioned because the account for this work will no doubt be submitted very shortly.

It was also pointed out by the Principal that there is very little bedding, and that he will require same to the value of $1,000.00.

Double-decker beds, mattresses and palliasses are being supplied this week by war Assets Corporation.

Mr. Staley has a complete staff, a splendid supply of food-stuff, and the Agencies from which the pupils are to be drawn have been advised to send them in on the 9th instant. This is the earliest possible date on which the School can be opened.

Please wire regarding the items for which immediate authority is asked.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

With further reference to my letter of September 30th, I now beg to enclose herewith Statement of Account from the Saskatoon Welding Ltd. of Edmonton for the retubing of the boiler.

Instructions were given apparently in 1943 by the boiler inspector to have this work done, but nothing was done about it with the exception that our engineer recapped several more of the tubes and it became absolutely necessary to have the retubing completed in order that the boiler function properly.

I am enclosing copy of the boiler inspector's report of 1943, which you will note calls for retubing of this particular boiler.

The 1946 Boiler Inspection Certificate for this boiler reads as follows:

"The following repairs are necessary and must be completed forthwith in accordance with the Boilers Act. Boiler foundation is crumbling. Rebuild when convenient. There is deep pitting on crownsheet, particularly around the base of the staybolts. Use more lime to check this pitting. Note: Boiler retubed September, 1946. The certificate for the other boiler reads as follows:

"Boiler foundation is crumbling. Rebuild when convenient. Lower bank of tubes is badly pitted. Also crownsheet is actively pitting. Use more lime to check this pitting. Renew water column piping."

I shall be glad if you will bring these several matters to the attention of the Department, with a view to having the necessary repairs effected before winter sets in, if possible.

Dear Sir:

Re: Porch, Farm Supervisor's Residence,
Indian Residential School,

On Wednesday, August 28th, I visited the above named residence with you and examined the porch, which has been in a bad condition for a long time.

On October 8th, 1945, I gave a tentative figure which at that time would have put the porch back in fair condition.

This figure would not apply now, as the damage is becoming progressively worse; in fact it is now in the dangerous stage, and should not be allowed to go any further. The porch should be torn down and rebuilt on a better foundation, as the existing footing wall is shivered and broken so badly as to be useless.

Of course the porch could be eliminated, but, if so, the existing platform would have to be extended, necessitating a certain amount of foundation work and the brickwork on the house would still have to be toothed in and brought up to the door on both sides and over the door to the window sills.

There is no doubt also that this procedure would seriously detract from the appearance of the house and would not be a great saving in cost.

I (OVER)
I would say that to take down the porch, install proper concrete foundation and rebuild as it should be done, would run anywhere between $300.00 and $350.00, with the latter as the outside cost, if the work is done before freezing weather. If it is left until then and we have to protect the concrete and the brickwork against frost, the cost will be correspondingly higher.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) "JAS. C. HADDOW"

Dear Mr. Robertson:

We recently had occasion to use one of our fire hoses to flush out a drain, which had become clogged and found that the fabric was rotted through in many places, rendering it useless so far as fire protection was concerned.

An inspection was then made of the other hose throughout the building and it was found that a large proportion of this was in a leaky condition.

In order to have the minimum of safety for the building we should have at least eight, fifty feet lengths of 1" hose and one, one hundred feet length, with what they call I think, expansion couplings.

An inspection was also made of the Fire Guns and Extinguishers throughout the building and ninety per cent of these were found to be out of repair and useless as fire-fighting equipment.

We should have at least two dozen of these placed at strategic points throughout the building and in this connection I might mention that I was recently in the warehouse of the War Assets Corporation in Edmonton and they had a wonderful supply of various types of this equipment, some of which was absolutely new & had never been unpacked.

They had also a quantity of hose, but unless this was new, it would be dangerous to touch it, as it might have been put away wet & would be in no better condition than what we have.

This is a matter that should have immediate attention, as, in the event of our having a fire, we would be in rather a hopeless position in trying to put it out.

Yours very truly,

December 12th 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to our recent letter pointing out the condition of our fire fighting equipment, I might say that a few days ago a pan of grease caught fire in one of the ovens in the kitchen and brought to our attention the exceedingly dangerous position we are in.

There is not a piece of fire fighting equipment in the kitchen and the nearest hose connection is at least a hundred feet away. As a matter of fact there is not a single piece of equipment, water or chemical, in that section of the building in which the kitchen, laundry and boiler room are located, nor in the chapel which is on the floor above them.

In view of this condition we have taken the liberty of ordering three Fire Guns in order that we may be in a position to handle any flash fire which may occur in the kitchen and pending your action in furnishing the equipment asked for.

Also while giving consideration to the question of supplying fire fighting equipment, I trust you will give favorable consideration to the matter of a night watchman for the school.

I might say that I am considerably worried as to what might happen in the event of our having a fire, not only on account of the lack of suitable equipment, but on account of the antiquated system of fire escapes on the building, where the children would have to climb up onto window ledges four feet from the ground in order that they may get onto the ladders outside.

Yours truly,

E.J. Staley
Principal
Indian Residential School

P.S. I wonder if I could be furnished with a copy of the plans of this building, together with an outline of the drainage system and wiring for lighting etc.

December 12th 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

On a recent visit to this school, Mr. Doucet of the Welfare & Training Division, was shown the crowded condition of our classrooms, which would eventually necessitate the opening up of another classroom, and in anticipation of this he advised us he would arrange that we receive another forty desks.

More children have come in since he was here and the opening up of another room has become a necessity, so that, if it can be arranged that we receive the additional desks, steps will be taken towards the opening up of this additional room.

An extra teacher's desk & chair would also be required.

In connection with the manual training classes which have been started at the school, a requisition for a supply of tools was sent in several months ago, but so far we have only received a small portion of what was asked and we have not received any saws, hammers or squares, which are the most essential tools in any shop.

Mr. Doucet also arranged to have sent to us four looms so that the girls could take up weaving in their handicrafts classes and now that these classes are in operation, we shall be glad if these machines can be made available at as early a date as possible.

The question of raising mink at this school was also taken up with Mr. Doucet and in this connection we shall be glad to receive authority to purchase the necessary material for the making of pens, so that the boys could go ahead with these as a manual training project.

Yours truly,

E.J. Staley
Principal.

In regard to $10.00 due Beatty Bros. for barn plans:- I can only say that theirs was ONE of the plans submitted, at our request. They made out the plans according to our instructions at the time and we used them as a basis for subsequent plans, so while they were not entirely satisfactory for our later plans, yet they were not entirely useless.

In regard to the contract for well drilling:- I sent you the contract as written by Mr. Redamel with my letter of May 6th. See note under "Veucker 6" of that letter. I think you will find the letter among the mass of material I sent you at that time.

I also have your letter of August 6th. I shall be glad to give you a weekly report of our work.

At present the barn is about completed with the exception of a few details, and the fitting of fixtures. We already have in it nearly 50 tons of timothy hay. As far as we can judge the barn is complete in every particular.

The staff residence is well under way. The brick work is nearly completed and the partitions are being put in. Another two weeks should put it very nearly completion with the exception of the inside finishings.

It is the well which is giving us more anxiety than any other piece of work. They are down now over 500 feet and have not yet struck water. Tomorrow morning they start using the hydraulic and should make quicker time. In the meantime we are having to haul all our water from the river, a distance of about two miles. For drinking water we have to go to the city, a distance of about five miles. This work takes the time of one man and two teams of horses, and even then we often cannot supply the various groups of workmen with sufficient water to keep them going. When we get water one of our greatest difficulties will be solved.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of August 4th to hand (No. 522,194-5)

As requested I shall forward the cancelled cheques to you as receipts for the wages paid. I was under the impression that the numbers of the cheques as given on the pay-lists would be sufficient.

In regard to the salary of Mr. L.D. Parney, the contractor, I may say that your decision to pay him a salary of only $250.00 is I think very unwise, and should not be final.

When this work was started early last spring I was commissioned by Mr. Ferrier to have charge of the operations, getting out the plans and securing suitable men to undertake the work. A number of contractors were anxious to take the work, and it was only after due consideration that I asked Mr. Parney to be the contractor. He was recommended by a number of independent sources to whom I went for advice and information. I have not yet found a man who gives Mr. Parney anything else but the highest recommendation for honesty and efficiency. He has been a resident of Edmonton for some 15 years, and has done some of the best work in the city. For some years he was employed by the Provincial Government, and was contractor, or head foreman, on the government buildings. When Mr. Ferrier came in touch with him, he congratulated me on my choice of a contractor. He also wrote a letter to Mr. Scott expressing his satisfaction with the work of Mr. Parney, see Mr. Ferrier's letter of March 18th.

In this letter Mr. Ferrier states that he has engaged Mr. Parney.

It seems unfortunate that our terms of engagements are not satisfactory to the Department, particularly as we understand that this was part of our responsibility.
Indian Industrial School

Before the matter is definitely settled, I think the Department should state their basis on which a contractor should be employed. I asked Mr. Parney his terms. He stated $375.00 a month. I left the matter until Mr. Ferrier made his next visit. We discussed a ten per cent commission on the work cost which is a common basis for a contractor to work upon. I pointed out to Mr. Ferrier that this would mean about $4000.00 for this year's work, so the total cost this season will easily be $40000.00. On the present basis Mr. Parney will receive about $3000.00 or less even if the work continues up into December, which it will not. No doubt the Department is aware that at the present time, owing to the uncertain markets contractors are not taking contracts for a whole building program, either a salary or commission basis are taken for work. In our case the wage basis is far the best. As regards the price you offer: At present I am having to pay one of the foremen at the rate of $250.00 a month, or nearly so. James W. Jensen gets $1.00 an hour. In town common carpenters get .90¢ an hour. I can hardly offer Mr. Parney this when he has charge of the whole work: Cement work, brick work, well drilling, and everything connected with the construction. Besides this Mr. Parney is putting his entire time on the work, not eight hours a day, but twelve and thirteen hours a day. He bought a car in order to do the work. He is away at six in the morning and does not get back until eight at night. His work is making it possible for us to put up a plant which is complete as far as it goes and I will gladly welcome any inspection of our work. I shall be glad to have suggestions as to better methods of doing a good job, but we cannot afford to lose Mr. Parney for $375.00, at least this year. A new contract may be made next year. I have probably written at too great length on this subject, but I think that the matter will stand some discussion. I would respectfully suggest that Mr. Parney be engaged at the original figure.

Dear Dr. Scott,

With regard to the proposed new Residential School near Edmonton, Alberta, I have felt constrained to write to you to say that I would much like to be appointed as Inspector of Construction to supervise the carrying out of the Department's building plans for that very important Institution. I believe I could render satisfactory service there. My past record and building experience are known to the Department, particularly, perhaps, in consequence of the School we erected at Kuper Island B.C.

I do not wish to presume to stress my desire for the Edmonton appointment. As a loyal servant of the Indian Department I am prepared to serve to the best of my ability wherever my superiors decide I can be of the most use. I understand that it is the Department's intention to erect a Hospital and a Stock Barn on the Blackfoot Reserve here; and if it is your wish, Sir, that I remain here in connection with this work, or serve anywhere else, it will be my pleasure to do so. However, should my services be more helpful in connection with the larger work at Edmonton, I can only say, in the language of the immortal Dickens, it will be another case of "Barkis is willing".

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 9th ultimo, your file IA-IAI-218, regarding the competition for the position of Inspector of Construction, Edmonton Indian school, I am forwarding herewith eight applications received in response to the advertisement.

I have rated these with the exception of that of Mr. Lindsay in so far as experience is concerned, heading No.1, and physical fitness, No.5. As it was not possible to have an oral interview with these people, it appears to me that we might dispense with the ratings under Nos. 2, 3, and 4. You will note that the qualifications of Mr. Gardner Smith and Mr. Charles May are rated equally. Their experience is extensive. Mr. Smith is known to us, having done work for the Department before, and Mr. May has decidedly excellent recommendations. Mr. Bury and Mr. Donaldson are Civil Engineers, and for that reason, so far as our work is concerned, I have rated them much lower.

As Mr. May lives at Edmonton, and the building is just on the outskirts of the city, he is much more conveniently situated, and considerably less expense in travelling would be involved. I would recommend, therefore, that he be given the appointment, and I would ask for a speedy decision by the Commission, as the work is now under way and the services of an Inspector are urgently needed.

Yours very truly,

Fire Inspection Report
Re - Edmonton Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alberta.

In view of the recent tragic fires which have occurred causing loss of life instructions have been received from Mr. Moore, Superintendent of Insurance & Fire Commissioner, Edmonton, Alta., to inspect all buildings of public assembly, and therefore, while in the St. Albert district, a thorough inspection was made of the above residential school.

The following is a description of the various buildings inspected, their occupancies and recommendations to remedy fire hazards found therein:

ADMINISTRATION BUILDING

This building is three storey and basement - construction brick - interior walls lath and plaster. Built 1924.

Occupancies:
Basement. Wash and bath room, boys and girls playrooms, furnace room, laundry room, kitchen, boys and girls dining room and furnace room.

Recommendations basement:
It is recommended that a stand pipe be connected with the present water pressure pipe in the corridor - North & South wall, with hose and hose bracket - 100 feet of 2" iron hose, to service dining room, kitchen, washroom and boiler room. Approved type of fire extinguishers to be installed in all of the above mentioned rooms; furthermore, all drop cords or extensions from ceiling outlets be removed and rooms wired to conform with the present Canadian Electrical Code.

FIRST FLOOR

Occupancies on this floor are as follows:
Offices of the principal, The Rev. E.J. Staley, and Assistant Principal, J.A. Feunt. Secretary's office, Staff dining room, Sewing room, two playrooms each end of corridor. (East & West) and Church Chapel.

Recommendations 1st floor
Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

(continued)

Hose or hose brackets attached to standpipe be replaced - present hose perished. Flexible electric extensions cords from existing outlets in sewing room dining room (staff) class rooms and corridors be removed and re-wired to conform with Canadian Electrical Code. Pilot light to be installed over electric iron. Extinguishers S & A type to be thoroughly checked and tagged.

End FLOOR

Occupancies of this floor are as follows:
Four children's dormitories - located
No. 1 N.E. corner - accommodates 15 double beds - 30 children - ages 6 years to 12 years
No. 2 N.E. corner - accommodates 15 double beds - 30 children - ages 12 years to 16 years
The other two dormitories are located at the east end of the building, and are duplicate of the last end. There are also staff bedrooms.

Recommendations - see Fire Exit facilities.

3rd FLOOR

The whole of this floor is presently closed off. It is periodically used as dormitories. At present used as storage for beds and mattresses.

Recommendations - see Fire Exit facilities.

FIRE ALARM SYSTEM

Building has the 'break glass type' on own transformer - system services all floors, but not connected with staff residences. Recommend that system be carried to staff quarters.

FIRE EQUIPMENT

There are two standpipes which service the building. Each floor has hose 1½ inch linen, 50 feet; this is attached to hose bracket, with nozzle. Recommend that all hose be condemned and replaced - hose has been in use since 1924.

Each floor has two S & A type fire extinguishers 5 gallon - located each end of corridors - east & west ends. These should all be thoroughly checked and properly tagged.

FIRE EXIT FACILITIES

A very unusual situation exists in connection with these facilities and should be remedied immediately. Fire exit other than main inside
Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School
(continued)

stairway - South centre of building is by the way of double sash windows, located in each of the children's dormitories. In order to reach the sill of each window it is necessary for the children to step up some four feet from the ground level. Because of their short build they cannot do it, while therefore necessitate older children rendering assistance. Such exit facilities are inadequate for an occupancy of this type and would recommend that windows be removed, standard doors installed and to be equipped with approved type of panic bolts. There are two other exits, but these are located in the two staff bedrooms, doors are kept locked and the children deprived of their access.

FIRE ESCAPES

Two stairway type - located North Wall
" pole type " West Wall
" pole type " East Wall

The two stairway type are so situated that their use would only be for the staff, access to these are gained through the two staff bedrooms. Bedroom and exit doors are kept locked at all times.

The pole type of course is the children and as previously mentioned exit to these are gained through a sash window. From the window sill abutting the wall is a small platform and it is by these means the children are expected to make their escape in the case of fire. At the time of this composition no thought has been given to 30 or 40 below zero weather. It is difficult to imagine any person and especially small children, being able to safely make their escape from the building in the event of fire by means of this type of escape. One hundred and thirty children in night attire would, in my opinion, never be able to evacuate the building by means such as are available, especially in winter when the metal would be covered with frost. I would recommend that these pole type of escapes be removed and two steel tubular ones installed at North and East walls, that inter-connecting doors be installed to connect each dormitory and standard door exits to replace windows and equip each door with approved type of panic bolt.

NIGHT STAFF

Nil. None provided by the Department.

Water Supply

There is only one well which meets the ordinary requirements of the building - that is general use. I should also mention that this supply is used by the residences.
Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

There is no reserve and any extra demands made on the well would run it dry. Water supply would be inadequate to put out any fire should there be a rapid spread. Would recommend that supply be increased.

BOILER ROOM

Cement walls and floor - contains three boilers - two low pressure type of 40 lbs. each and one high pressure of approx. 100 lbs. Coal fed. Room has two exits - North and South walls. Engineer in charge. From midnight until six A.M. each day no person is in charge of the boiler room. Furnaces are banked down for the night and left. The matter of a night watchman has been brought to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs by the present principal, but the Department stated that seeing no provisions had been made in the yearly estimates for the payment of one the services of a watchman would have to wait.

The above is one of extreme importance and I would recommend that the services of an night watchman be secured. It is quite evident that if a fire ever started in this building a large loss of life would result.

OUTSIDE BUILDINGS

These consist of the following:
Horse barn, Cow barn, Hog barn, utility building, roothouse and garage.

The hog barn is the only building which has a supply of water and that is through a half inch pipe. No facilities in any of the other buildings in case of fire. Recommend that approved type of fire extinguishers be installed.

STAFF RESIDENCES

No fire extinguishers. Recommend they be installed.

REMARKS:

Inspection shows that buildings have been allowed to deteriorate to a very marked degree, though its cause has not been through the present Principal. Numerous conditions at present prevailing should be remedied. In the matter of fire exits and escapes these should be attended to at once, same applies to all electrical wiring, water supply and fire fighting equipment. In the interests of fire prevention such conditions should not be tolerated especially where the boiler room is concerned. A second engineer, or night watchman should be added to the present staff.
Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

FIRE DRILLS

I omitted to mention that periodic fire drills are held under the supervision of the School Principal. Members of the staff, when available, constitute the volunteer Fire Department.

(sgd.) J. H. Leyland, Insp.

H. R. Moore, Esq.,

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Fire inspection Report

The Provincial Fire Commissioner submitted the attached report to Dr. Stone, Medical Superintendent, Dept. of Health & Welfare, and he has passed it on to this office. In a covering letter from the fire Commissioner he states that his Department has recently undertaken inspection of public buildings in the Edmonton area, with a view to the elimination of fire hazards, and the recommendations respecting egress and public safety. Certain fire fighting apparatus is now being supplied to this institute, but of course not as complete as this inspection report requires. Your attention is drawn particularly to the report on existing fire exits and the recommendations. You will also please note that the inspector recommends a night watchman.

The type of fire escapes in this and many other schools is certainly unsatisfactory, and in this I have always felt there was great room for improvement. Failing the ability to supply good fire exits, the next best thing is to supply (temporary of course) a competent night watchmen. In this and other large residential schools a night watchman should be supplied, if at all possible.

The report is submitted for your consideration and comments.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Dear Sir:

In talking with the engineer at the school, I learned that the electric motor at the pumphouse had not been checked for about twelve years and as it has seen a lot of service during that period, he thought that a checkup and a possible rewinding might be warranted.

He also informed me that two or three years ago, when he was changing some valves in the cylinder in the well, he noted considerable wear in the cylinder and it might be possible that replacement of the cylinder would be called for this year, when the cylinder, valves & rods were being checked.

Replacement of the cylinder I would imagine, would be an expensive job, as I understand it is 4" in diameter and about six or seven feet long, but of what make I have been unable to learn.

I thought it best to advise you of these conditions in order that you may be prepared to meet the expense, should it become necessary to incur same.

In connection with the cylinder, I understand that the one in the well has been in use for over eighteen years.

Yours truly,

E.J. Staley  
Principal.
We cannot see any reason for keeping the doors locked in the two staff bedrooms when the dormitories are occupied. You should inform the principal immediately that the Department expects these doors to be kept unlocked so that if necessary the children can use these exits.

Some years ago we decided to allow an amount for night watchmen to certain Indian residential schools where it was felt a definite fire hazard existed. We never previously considered the Edmonton school in the class just mentioned. However, in view of your recommendation, we are prepared to allow an amount of $40.00 a month until April 30, 1947 towards the salary of a night watchman at the Edmonton school. It should definitely be understood that this is only a temporary measure.

We are in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant enclosing report submitted by the Provincial Fire Commissioner regarding the Edmonton Residential School.

At the request of the principal, we have arranged within the last month, to have our Purchasing Branch secure 24-1 qt. fire extinguishers, 500 feet of hose, and 12 refills for foamite fire extinguishers at present in the school. The commissioner's report reads as follows regarding the fire exit facilities:

"A very unusual situation exists in connection with these facilities and should be remedied immediately. Fire exit other than main inside stairway - South centre of building is by the way of double sash windows, located in each of the children's dormitories. In order to reach the sill of each window it is necessary for the children to step up some four feet from the ground level and some of the children being so small it would therefore necessitate older children rendering assistance. Such exit facilities are inadequate for an occupancy of this type and would recommend that windows be removed, standard doors installed and to be equipped with approved type of panic bolts. There are two other exits, but these are located in the two staff bedrooms, doors are kept locked and the children deprived of their access."

We are not certain if the commissioner's suggestion can be carried out without effecting the building. However, you may make inquiries and let us know. In the meantime it would be advisable to have permanent steps made leading to the windows which are used as an exit to the fire escape.

MEMORANDUM:

January 22nd, 1947.

Re: Fire Escapes - Edmonton Indian Residential School.

With reference to your notation dated January 4th, 1947, on Indian Affairs memorandum of December 20, 1946, and in particular dealing with the Principal's statement in respect to fire escapes, our officer who made an inspection of the School during July, 1945, reports that the window sills are somewhat high for young pupils, particularly in the attic dormitories where the windows are, as stated, 4'-0" above the floor.

The Principal's reference to "antiquated system of fire escapes" is borne out by our officer's report of August 30th, 1945, in which the following item occurs:

"Fire Escapes. The fire escapes are landings provided with poles to the ground and are not practical for younger pupils. In this connection, it will be noted that in order to keep the older boys and girls within the dormitories during the evenings locks had to be attached to the doors and windows leading to the fire escapes."

The above item refers to fire escapes, which apparently were not included in the original design to provide fire exits from dormitories and classrooms. Two standard fire escapes are shown on original plans at the rear of the building and are in place.

Reference was also made to the doubtful utility of the type of fire escape under discussion in a memorandum dated October 7, 1944, with photographs attached, in which it was recommended that consideration be given to providing the usual steel stairs and rails.

The blue prints requested are being prepared and will be forwarded when ready.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir:

Some few months ago you authorised the purchase of fifty double decker beds for this institution and these were duly received and have proved very satisfactory indeed.

The pupilage in the school however, has now reached the 130 mark and more pupils are continuing to come in, so that we could make good use of a further twenty of these beds and would be very pleased if you would authorise their purchase.

We do not need mattresses for these, as we got fifty extra before, as they were such a good buy.

We however are up against it for blankets, as it is just impossible for us to buy them and if you can help us out to the extent of two hundred or even one hundred, it will be greatly appreciated.

When we took over the administration of this school the bedding was in a deplorable condition, necessitating tremendous outlay on our part and it has got to the point where we cannot do any more.

Yours truly,

Attention of the Supt. of Welfare & Training

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Enclosed herewith please find two requisitions, one for parts required to repair plumbing and heating system, and the other one for showers and washbasins.

The Principal of the school submits a long list of supplies which are required to bring the existing plant to proper efficiency. He states that if the material could be made available, most of the repair work required to be done, could be attended to during the summer holidays by members of the school staff and with no additional cost to the Department. Many pipes show signs of being eaten right through, and in attempting to replace a section it gives way.

In regard to the showers and washbasins for the boys, it was noted on our first inspection of this school that the water tanks were in very bad condition, and it is understood that they were the subject of criticism by the Sanitary Engineer. The Principal would prefer two stainless steel troughs with overhead taps, so that the boys could wash their hands and faces under the taps and where there would be a continuous flow of water.

In regard to the showers in the washroom, there would originally appear to have been three showers, but two of them have completely disappeared and the one remaining is unusable. The Principal indicated that he had found these showers were indispensable. By using them it was possible to avoid the spread of skin disease, and he contended that the showers were much more suitable than bathtubs. In this we were in agreement.

These requisitions are submitted in the hope that they will be favorably considered and orders placed for the supplies and articles mentioned therein.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

I am enclosing herewith statement received from the Saskatoon Welding Ltd. of Edmonton in the amount of $23.25 for welding tank at the school.

One of our water storage and pressure tanks sprung a leak, having rusted through and it was necessary to have it welded immediately in order that the supply of water for the school be maintained.

While the tank was empty, I had the welder inspect the tank inside and he reports that it is badly pitted and should be built up this summer, otherwise we may look for trouble.

I had thought that this work might be undertaken during the holidays and with this in mind I asked him to give me an estimate of the cost of putting the two tanks in shape and he quoted me a figure of $75.00 for the two. If this were done it would prolong the life of the tanks by several years.

Would you please take the matter up with the Department with a view to having the expenditure authorised.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Robertson:

In connection with the redecorating etc., which were estimated for last year for this school, I am submitting measurements of some of the rooms, which really should be done and as we had anticipated having these done during the holiday period, I thought it better that you have the figures in order that you may submit them to the Department.

I would presume they would want to call for tenders for the work to be done on a yardage basis, or they might have in mind the furnishing of the paint and having us do the work ourselves with the help of two or three of the bigger boys, who of course would have to be paid. We could not however undertake to do the ceilings as they are of corrugated metal and would be better done with a spray gun, in which case we might have difficulty in getting anyone to undertake the spraying of the ceilings, without having the full job of painting to do.

The linoleum in the halls on the first and second floors, as you know, is all worn out and should be replaced and if it were decided that this should be done, it would require 190 square yards. I would suggest that some kind of a grey marble pattern be supplied, which would not show tracks as the old brown linoleum did.

The Mastic floors in the children's dining room, pantry and back kitchen have become badly pitted and are hard to keep clean and sanitary and some kind of resurfacing should be done. There is a firm, The Taylor Tile and Contracting Co. in Edmonton who do this kind of work and was wondering if it would be in order to have their expert look over the floors and suggest what had best be done, in reason.

There is another matter that I mentioned to you on one of your recent visits and that is that there is not a water tap or basin in any one of the dormitories, which means that if a child should want to have a drink during the night, he or she has to go down to the basement to get it. This is something that should be remedied before the school is reopened in September.
The tables and benches in the children's dining room also, are in a state of repair and drew unfavorable comment from Miss McCready when she visited the school in the spring. I would recommend that something be done about replacing these and if it is decided to do this I would recommend that the tops be either plastic or linoleum covered.

It is our intention to do considerable touching up and painting throughout the building during the summer and with this in mind I would request that we be furnished with the following:

- 5 gals each of Cream, Ivory and White Enamel.
- 5 gals of White paint.
- 5 gals of Green paint (Outside).
- 5 gals each of Turpentine and boiled oil.
- 4 each of 2", 3", and 4" brushes, good quality.

When the painting was done last fall in the children's dining room it was considered that the burlap on the lower portion of the walls should be replaced and the plaster repaired, but it was impossible to obtain new burlap, so the old was painted over, but it was not a good job. Burlap is now available and I am satisfied that if the material were furnished the members of the staff could repair the plaster, put on the burlap and paint same. Could you ask that this be done, please.

The electric wiring throughout the building drew unfavorable comment from the Provincial Fire Inspector, when he visited the school and recommendation was made that it be given attention and I think during the forthcoming holiday period would be the best time to do it and would recommend accordingly.

Yours very truly,

J.T. Waunt,
Acting Principal.

Dear Sir:

In the absence of Mr. Staley I have opened your letter to him of July 9th in regard to War Assets Corporation account for Mattress Covers supplied to this institution, to the value of $178.50.

This account was sent to you through the Edmonton Indian Agency, and was also returned through him, with the remarks that as the account had not been authorised it could not be paid by the Department.

At the time the account was sent in, it was explained that these slip covers were required as a protection to the mattresses which had been supplied by the Department and for which we were very grateful. In the event of their becoming soiled they could be taken off and washed and replaced on the mattresses, which has been done to all of them since the closing of the school at the end of June.

I might go on to explain that when Mr. Staley took over the school, everything was in an extremely run down condition and extensive repairs and replacements were necessary, the cost of which could not begin to be met out of the per capita grant and I might just as well be frank and say that we have not had the money to pay this account and we are only hoping that the grant for the July - September quarter will enable us to get straightened around.

There has been practically no revenue from the farm, which had been allowed to get into a run down and weedy condition and had been leased to outsiders, who allowed it to get into a worse condition. Practically all the livestock had been sold off and all of the machinery so we had to start from the ground up, you might say, but, we are hopeful.

I think under the circumstances and considering the fact that the covers are for the protection of the Department's property, payment of the account might well be considered by the Department and this I would urgently request. The other account for $37.50 will be taken care of by Mr. Staley on his return from holidays.

Yours very truly,

J.T. Faunt, Asst. Principal

Dear Mr. Faunt:

We have your letter of the 14th instant with reference to purchases made by the Indian Residential School from War Assets Corporation.

As you state in your letter, the purchase of the mattress covers was not authorized by the Department. It is simply impossible for us to control our expenditure if every principal of a school assumes responsibility of incurring without authority, expenditures which the Department is expected to pay. In future we will expect that authority will be obtained for any disbursement for which you expect the Department to provide the funds.

The future policy is outlined above but we have decided to pay the amount of $178.50. Please certify the account and return to me immediately.

It is noted that Mr. Staley will pay War Assets the other account amounting to $37.50. I trust that this will receive your early attention because accounts such as this should not be allowed to remain outstanding.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

I was wondering if you had heard anything from the Department in connection with the work requiring to be done at the school, as outlined in my letter of June 4th.

The holiday season is slipping along and it would be a whole lot better for all concerned if the work could be undertaken during the holidays.

There is also the matter of the footings under the boilers which should be given attention during the next six weeks and before the school reopens.

These footings as you know are of brick and have become badly broken and eaten away and there is danger of their collapsing completely; in fact at one place the bricks have given way and there is an open hole through into the ash pit, making it impossible to control the fire.

The boilers would have to be jacked up an eighth of an inch or so, the old bricks or what is left of them taken out, new bricks put in and the boilers lowered again into place.

At the back end of the boilers the asbestos bricking used for insulation has fallen away to a considerable extent and we are therefore losing a considerable amount of the heat generated in the boilers and this also should be given attention.

I have been trying for several weeks to get a man to come out and look at the boilers and last night I finally got a bricklayer to come out and look things over and he figures he could come out in about three weeks or now and do what is to be done.

In the meantime I thought it well to bring the matter to your attention, so that I would be in a position to give this man the go-ahead signal when his services become available.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Copy for Department
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Repairs, Edmonton Indian School...

I am enclosing herewith copy of letter received from the Edmonton School in connection with repairs required to their boilers, also an estimate of the cost of repairs from Wm. Clevette, Brick-Layer.

Mr. Staley has phoned me this morning advising that they found one of the boilers leaking and on having the Saskatoon Welding Co., Edmonton, look it over, they found that it was in very bad shape, the bottom of the boiler being badly corroded and nearly eaten through in several places. The Boiler Inspector was called to look it over and he advised them that under ordinary circumstances he would have to condemn the boiler but as it was impossible to replace it at the present time, he would send them a statement of the minimum repairs he would require before he would pass the boiler. As soon as this comes to hand I will send it to you. In the meantime, will you please advise if it will be in order to go ahead with the repairs he orders. It will probably be quite an extensive job but is absolutely necessary as they must have heat.

The Welding concern are unable to give me any estimate of the cost as they do not know just what will be required until they get the boiler torn down.

E. A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 5th, 1947.

Re: Fire Escapes - Edmonton Indian Residential School

On an inspection of this school in June, I was impressed by the inadequacy of the fire escapes. The only egress from some of the large dormitories was through windows, and it was learned that these windows had invariably an ordinary and storm window on them during the winter months when the danger of fire is greatest. This practically prohibited the use of the windows as fire escapes, because the storm windows were fastened on the outside.

It was suggested, as a temporary measure, to remove the storm windows and weatherstrip the ordinary windows in order to keep out the cold.

Since that time, the Principal got more expert advice on fire escapes, and submitted herewith is a copy of his letter addressed to Mr. Robertson, Indian Agent, Edmonton Indian Agency.

The suggestion of a door in place of a window is certainly better than than the use of a window as a fire escape. It is also the least costly method of giving more fire protection to the pupils. It had been my suggestion to do this, but at that time the principal was not acquainted with the buzzer system used in some of the other schools. He has since stated that he finds that it can easily be installed and is very effective in keeping control of the movement of pupils at all times.

I would recommend that doors, secured by panic bolts, and a light buzzer system be installed as soon as possible.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Re: Fire Escapes, Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Referring to your letter of Aug. 11th, 1947, to the Department in connection with the above.

The best bid I could secure for the installation of the six doors in place of the windows, including the panic bolts, is $750.00. This would appear to be entirely out of proportion to the additional protection it would afford.

Mr. Staley feels that with the additional fire extinguishers provided and the recent repairs made to the fire fighting equipment, they are fairly well protected, and suggests that the replacement of the windows be postponed until such time as funds are available for the installation of an up-to-date system to replace the present poles.

E. A. Robertson,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Fire Escapes, Aderton Indian Residential School

May I refer to my letter of August 11th, file 110-48-3, when it was recommended that doors with panic bolts, replacing windows as fire escapes, together with a light buzzer system be installed. I enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Indian Agent, Mr. Robertson, stating that the installation of doors with panic bolts will cost $710.00, and that the Principal has recommended that nothing be done at present.

I do not concur in this. If it is thought that the cost of the replacement is prohibitive, then there remains one other alternative, which I am sure you will agree, that is to install weatherstrip on the windows so that the storm window can be left off during the winter. The fire escape is certainly of no value and the windows, most of which are solidly fixed to the wall, must be opened before the pupil gets on the fire escape. Furthermore, the value of fire extinguishers is very limited. In buildings made mostly of inflammable material, such as lumber, fire is likely to be used even though the fire is small, but immediately fire spreads to some outside before noticed, and in the natural wind conditions, the fire extinguishers may prove of little value in protecting life.

If doors are not going to be installed, then I seriously recommend that authority be given to put on weatherstripping and give instructions that the storm window be placed at the fire escape. The cost should not exceed $100.00.

When you reply would you please send it direct to the Indian agent and a copy to this office.

[Signature]

C. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Alberta.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

As you know, the basement of the Utility building at this institution is used for the storage of vegetables and in order to serve this purpose, the concrete walls were lined with hollow tile brick to provide insulation.

On one of your recent visits I pointed out to you that all this brick along one side and one end of the building had been broken out and that the vegetables stored came in direct contact with the concrete walls.

Last year we suffered considerable loss from the freezing of vegetables exposed to the concrete walls down which the frost crept and into the vegetables.

I had thought that if I were to set in 2 x 4 or 2 x 6 studs against these outside walls and sheet them up with common boards and then fill in behind the boards with sawdust or planing chips I could prevent a recurrence of this loss.

The lumber required for this purpose will run around 1000' & will cost in the neighborhood of $70.00 and was wondering if you would ask the Department for authority to make this purchase in order that I may go ahead with the work.

Yours very truly,

J.T. Haunt

Dear Sirs:

Re: Decorating Indian Residential School,

I have your letter of October 16th, returning voucher in favor of Mr. Ayris for decorating done by him to the sitting rooms and chapel at the school and also to the farmer's residence, for the reason that you had no record of any authority having been given by the Department for the expenditure.

There was no authority given directly by the Department, but when Mr. Inspector Gooderham was shown the condition in which the farmer's residence, with the plaster all falling down, the roof leaking and paper hanging off the walls, he gave instructions to have what work was necessary done.

This was not the case in connection with the decorating of the sitting rooms and no authority was given to have this work done, but the circumstances were as follows:

After all the other work around the building had been done, halls redecorated, staff dining room redecorated, outer and inner office redecorated, there remained the two sitting rooms just inside the front door to which all visitors and guests were taken when they came to the school. The paper on both the walls and ceilings of these rooms was in very bad shape and in many places was hanging loose. This was caused by the leaky roof which had been repaired by the year before.

It was an unsightly mess and Mr. Ayris having offered to do the two rooms for $50.00 we told him to go ahead and do the job, hoping that the money might be forthcoming from somewhere to pay for it.

Yours very truly,

E.J. Staley
Principal.
Indian Residential School  
UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA  
EDMONTON  
ALBERTA  

October 24th 1947.

Mr. F.A. Robertson:  
Indian Agent,  
Winterburn, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

When you were at the school some little time ago in connection with the estimates for 1948-49, the condition of the heaters in the pump house and milk room was drawn to your attention, with a view to authority being obtained for the purchase of two new stoves.

You will possibly also remember that one of these heaters collapsed last spring with the result that a fire was started in the floor between the pump house and the milk room above and had it not been that the engineer at the school had been able to go down there the building might very easily have gone up in smoke.

You at that time authorised us to buy a new stove, but they were hard to get and having wired up the old stove as well as we could, we were able to get through for the season, but it will be impossible for us to go through the winter with the two stoves we have.

Would it be too much to ask, that you take the matter up with the Department with a view to the necessary authority being obtained for the purchase of the two new stoves so urgently required. Winter may be clamping down on us at any time and it would be well to be prepared against frost damage to our water system.

Yours very truly,

E.J. Staley,  
principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School.

I am enclosing herewith letter received from the Principal of Edmonton Indian School in connection with two new heaters required for their pump house and milk room.

The pumps are in the basement of this building and the milk rooms above them. The present heaters are completely burned out and I would recommend that two new "Quebec" heaters be purchased at a cost of approximately $25.00 each.

E.A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Referring to your letter of Sept. 23rd, 1947, returning voucher No. 402-47, in favor of Saskatoon Welding Co., for $1223.94.

Detailed account from the Saskatoon Welding Co., and is now attached to voucher which is returned herewith. In regard to quotations from other firms, would say that these boilers were in such condition that the Inspector intended to condemn them until it was pointed out to him by one of his assistants that this action would mean closing the school as no new boilers of this kind are available at present. We could not find any other firm who would even consider looking over the job and it was only after a great deal of talking that we were able to persuade the Saskatoon Welding Co. to undertake the work. When the boilers were torn down they were found to be in even worse condition than was at first thought.

In regard to supervision of the work, I was at the shop once while they were working at the job and once when they finishing. The boiler inspectors were there four times to inspect the work being done and either Mr. Stalgay or Mr. Faunt were in the building all the time the work was being done and inspected it on numerous occasions.

E. A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 12, 1947.
